“Say,” says the duke, “I got another idea. Le’s go up stairs and count this money, and then take and give it to the girls.”

Well, that set me back considerable. I reckoned the duke was up to some new devilment, but I couldn’t figure what. The king, he brightened up at the notion, and they both started for the ladder to the loft where we kept the cash. I followed ’em, uneasy-like, wondering what kind of game they was playing now.

When we got up there, the duke spread out the money on the bed—gold and silver, all mixed together—and begun counting it out careful. The king, he licked his lips and watched, his fingers twitching like he wanted to grab it all right then. 

“Now then,” says the duke, “we’ll divide it fair and square. Half for you, half for me, and then we’ll give the girls their share.” 

The king, he nodded, but I could see the greed in his eyes. He wasn’t one to part with money easy, not even for them poor Wilks girls. The duke counted out the piles, slow and deliberate, like he was enjoying the sound of the coins clinking. 

“There,” he says at last, pushing half toward the king. “That’s yours. Now, as for the girls, I reckon they ought to have a third.” 

The king’s face darkened. “A third? Why, that ain’t right! They ain’t done nothing to earn it!” 

The duke just smiled, smooth as butter. “It’s only Christian charity, your majesty. These poor orphans need looking after.” 

I could see the king working hisself up, but he didn’t dare cross the duke just then. So he grumbled and let it pass. The duke took a smaller pile and set it aside. “This here’s for Mary Jane and her sisters. We’ll hand it over tomorrow, proper-like.” 

I didn’t believe a word of it. Them two frauds wasn’t about to give up a cent unless they had to. But I kept my mouth shut, watching and waiting. 

After they’d stashed their shares away, the duke turned to me sudden. “Huck, you run along now. This is grown folks’ business.” 

I didn’t need telling twice. I scooted out of there, but I didn’t go far. I had a mighty strong feeling there was more to this scheme, and I aimed to find out what.

events.title: The King's "Orgies" Blunder and Dr. Robinson's Scrutiny
detailed_summary: The conversation soon shifts back to the deceased Peter Wilks, with attendees reminiscing about his good qualities and the great loss his death represents.

While the King is speaking, a stern-looking, "iron-jawed" man (later identified as Dr. Robinson) enters from outside and stands listening and observing without saying anything, unnoticed by the engrossed audience.

The King, in the middle of his discourse, mentions that particular friends of the deceased are invited for the evening, but that tomorrow everyone is welcome because Peter respected and liked everybody, making it fitting for his "funeral orgies" to be public.
He continues speaking, clearly enjoying the sound of his own voice, and repeatedly brings up the term "funeral orgies."

The Duke, unable to tolerate the King's persistent misuse of the word, writes "obsequies, you old fool" on a scrap of paper, folds it, and, while making his usual "goo-goo" noises, passes it over people's heads to the King.

The King reads the note, puts it in his pocket, and remarks that although his brother William is afflicted, his heart is always right, adding that William was merely asking him to invite everyone to the funeral, which he was already doing.
He then calmly resumes his speech, once again dropping in the phrase "funeral orgies" periodically.
After using the term for the third time, he attempts to justify it, stating that "orgies" is the correct term, not the common "obsequies," which he claims is no longer used in England.

He provides a nonsensical etymology for "orgies," claiming it's derived from the Greek "orgo" (meaning outside, open, abroad) and the Hebrew "jeesum" (meaning to plant, cover up, hence inter), thus concluding that "funeral orgies" means an open or public funeral.

We say orgies now in England. Orgies is better, because it means the thing you’re after more exact. It’s a word that’s made up out’n the Greek orgo, outside, open, abroad; and the Hebrew jeesum, to plant, cover up; hence inter. So, you see, funeral orgies is an open er public funeral.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The king was going on about how the diseased—that is, Peter Wilks—had been the best man he ever knew, and how he’d left a hole in the world that couldn’t never be filled. He carried on so mournful that some of the womenfolk started sniffling into their handkerchiefs, and even a few of the men looked mighty solemn.  

Then, all of a sudden, that big iron-jawed fellow—who’d been standing there quiet as a post—cleared his throat real loud and spoke up.  

“Beggin’ your pardon,” says he, “but I reckon there’s been a mistake.”  

Well, that shut everybody up quick. The king stopped mid-sentence and turned to stare at him, his face twitching like he’d been stung by a hornet.  

“A mistake?” says the king, trying to sound calm but not quite managing it.  

“Yes, sir,” says the iron-jawed man. “I knew Peter Wilks, and I don’t recall him ever mentioning no brothers from England.”  

You could’ve heard a pin drop in that room. The duke, who’d been nodding along with the king’s speech, went pale as a sheet. The crowd started murmuring, and I could see the suspicion creeping into their eyes.  

The king, though, he wasn’t about to back down. He puffed himself up and said, “And who might you be, stranger, to question our grief?”  

The iron-jawed man just folded his arms. “Name’s Dr. Robinson. And I’d like to see some proof you’re who you say you are.”  

Well, that set the cat among the pigeons. The Wilks girls looked back and forth between the king and the doctor, their faces full of doubt. Huck, watching from the corner, knew trouble was coming—and fast.

events.title: Dr. Robinson's Denunciation and Mary Jane's Unwavering Trust
detailed_summary: The narrator remarks that the King was the worst imposter he had ever encountered.
Just then, the iron-jawed man, Dr. Robinson, laughs openly in the King's face, shocking everyone present.
People exclaim, "Why, doctor!" and Abner Shackleford informs Dr. Robinson that the man is Harvey Wilks.
The King, smiling eagerly, extends his hand towards the doctor, asking if he is his poor brother's dear friend and physician.
Dr. Robinson sharply tells the King to keep his hands off, then critiques his speech, stating it's the worst imitation of an Englishman he has ever heard and flatly declares the King a fraud.

The crowd becomes agitated, surrounding Dr. Robinson, trying to placate him and explain that "Harvey" has demonstrated his identity in numerous ways, knowing everyone by name, even the dogs, and begging him not to hurt Harvey's or the poor girls' feelings.
However, Dr. Robinson remains unpersuaded, storming on and asserting that any man claiming to be English who couldn't imitate the accent better was undeniably a fraud and a liar.
The Wilks girls, crying, cling to the King.
Suddenly, Dr. Robinson turns his attention to the girls.

He declares himself their father's friend and, as their honest friend wanting to protect them, warns them to turn away from the "scoundrel" King, calling him an ignorant tramp with idiotic claims about Greek and Hebrew.
He asserts the King is a transparent impostor who has merely gathered some names and facts, which they and their foolish friends are mistaking for proof.
He appeals directly to Mary Jane Wilks, reminding her of his unselfish friendship, and begs her to expel the "pitiful rascal."
Mary Jane straightens up, looking striking in her resolve, and gives her answer by taking the bag of money and placing it into the King's hands.
She tells the King to take the $6,000 and invest it for her and her sisters as he sees fit, without needing to provide any receipt.
Then, she puts her arm around the King, and Susan and Joanna do the same on his other side, demonstrating their complete trust.
The crowd erupts in applause and stomping, while the King holds his head high and smiles proudly.
Dr. Robinson declares he is done with the matter but warns everyone present that a time will come when they will feel sick whenever they recall this day, and then he departs.
The King mockingly retorts, "All right, doctor, we’ll try and get ’em to send for you," a remark that causes the crowd to laugh, deeming it a clever hit.

events.text_segment:
He was the worst I ever struck. Well, the iron-jawed man he laughed right in his face. Everybody was shocked. Everybody says, “Why, doctor!” and Abner Shackleford says:
“Why, Robinson, hain’t you heard the news? This is Harvey Wilks.”
The king he smiled eager, and shoved out his flapper, and says:
“Is it my poor brother’s dear good friend and physician? I—”
“Keep your hands off of me!” says the doctor. “You talk like an Englishman, don’t you? It’s the worst imitation I ever heard. You Peter Wilks’s brother! You’re a fraud, that’s what you are!”
Well, how they all took on! They crowded around the doctor and tried to quiet him down, and tried to explain to him and tell him how Harvey ’d showed in forty ways that he was Harvey, and knowed everybody by name, and the names of the very dogs, and begged and begged him not to hurt Harvey’s feelings and the poor girl’s feelings, and all that. But it warn’t no use; he stormed right along, and said any man that pretended to be an Englishman and couldn’t imitate the lingo no better than what he did was a fraud and a liar. The poor girls was hanging to the king and crying; and all of a sudden the doctor ups and turns on them. He says:
“I was your father’s friend, and I’m your friend; and I warn you as a friend, and an honest one that wants to protect you and keep you out of harm and trouble, to turn your backs on that scoundrel and have nothing to do with him, the ignorant tramp, with his idiotic Greek and Hebrew, as he calls it. He is the thinnest kind of an impostor—has come here with a lot of empty names and facts which he picked up somewheres, and you take them for proofs, and are helped to fool yourselves by these foolish friends here, who ought to know better. Mary Jane Wilks, you know me for your friend, and for your unselfish friend, too. Now listen to me; turn this pitiful rascal out—I beg you to do it. Will you?”
Mary Jane straightened herself up, and my, but she was handsome! She says:
“Here is my answer.” She hove up the bag of money and put it in the king’s hands, and says, “Take this six thousand dollars, and invest for me and my sisters any way you want to, and don’t give us no receipt for it.”
Then she put her arm around the king on one side, and Susan and the hare-lip done the same on the other. Everybody clapped their hands and stomped on the floor like a perfect storm, whilst the king held up his head and smiled proud. The doctor says:
“All right; I wash my hands of the matter. But I warn you all that a time ’s coming when you’re going to feel sick whenever you think of this day.” And away he went.
“All right, doctor,” says the king, kinder mocking him; “we’ll try and get ’em to send for you;” which made them all laugh, and they said it was a prime good hit.

He was the worst I ever struck. I mean, there was something about him that just made my skin crawl, like a snake slithering through wet grass. His name was Pap Finn, my own father, and if ever there was a man meant to make a body hate the very idea of family, it was him.  

From the minute he stumbled back into my life, drunk and reeking of whiskey, I knew trouble had come to roost. He’d disappear for months, even years, then show up like a bad penny, demanding money, food, and a place to sleep. The Widow Douglas had been trying to civilize me, teaching me manners and schooling and such, but Pap? He was the opposite of all that—wild, mean, and rotten to the core.  

The first thing he did when he found me was cuss me out for wearing clean clothes and going to school. "You think you’re better’n your own father?" he’d snarl, his breath hot and sour in my face. Then he’d grab me by the collar and shake me like a dog with a rat. He didn’t want me learning nothing, didn’t want me rising above what he was—a no-account drunk who lived off other folks’ pity and fear.  

Worst of all was the way he’d lock me up in that old cabin by the river, like I was some kind of prisoner. He’d leave for days, and I’d sit there in the dark, listening to the rats scurry in the corners, wondering if he’d ever come back—or if I even wanted him to. When he did return, it was always the same: more whiskey, more shouting, more beatings if I so much as looked at him wrong.  

One time, he got it into his head that I was putting on airs, acting like I was too good for him. He took a knife and held it to my throat, his eyes all bloodshot and wild. "I’ll take you down a peg," he hissed. "You ain’t got no right to be nothing but what I say you are." That was the moment I knew I had to get away, no matter what.  

And I did. I reckon that was the one good thing Pap ever did for me—showing me exactly the kind of man I didn’t want to be. He was the worst I ever struck, but he also taught me, in his own twisted way, that sometimes running ain’t cowardly. Sometimes it’s the only way to save yourself.  

So I lit out. Left him passed out drunk in that cabin and never looked back. And if I ever see him again, it’ll be too soon.

events.title: Room Assignments and Initial Settling In
detailed_summary: After the townspeople depart, the King inquires with Mary Jane about available spare rooms.
Mary Jane generously offers her own larger room to 'Uncle Harvey' (the King) and a spare room to 'Uncle William' (the Duke).
She proposes to sleep on a cot in the room with her sisters, designating a small attic cubby with a pallet for Huck, whom the King refers to as his 'valley' (valet).
Mary Jane shows the King and Duke their rooms, which are described as plain but pleasant.

She offers to clear her personal belongings from her room if they are in 'Uncle Harvey's' way, but the King insists they add to the room's comfortable and homely atmosphere and should not be disturbed.
The Duke's room, though small, and Huck's cubby are deemed perfectly adequate.

events.title: Supper and Social Flattery
detailed_summary: Later that night, a large supper is held, attended by numerous local men and women.
Huck serves the King and Duke at their chairs, while other servants attend to the remaining guests.
Mary Jane, presiding at the head of the table with Susan beside her, politely disparages the quality of the food—claiming the biscuits, preserves, and fried chicken are subpar.
Huck recognizes this as a common social tactic employed by women to elicit compliments.

The guests, fully aware that the meal is excellent, respond with enthusiastic praise, inquiring about her cooking techniques for the biscuits and the origin of the pickles, engaging in the customary flattery typical of such social gatherings.

events.title: Huck's Interrogation and Elaborate Lies
detailed_summary: After the main supper, Huck and Joanna Wilks (whom Huck calls 'the hare-lip') eat leftovers in the kitchen while others clean up.
Joanna begins to question Huck intensely about England, making Huck feel he is navigating a precarious situation with his answers.
Huck claims to have seen King William Fourth, stating the king attends their church, despite Huck knowing William IV had been dead for years.
When Joanna asks if the King attends regularly, Huck confirms, adding that the King's pew is opposite theirs.
Pressed about the King living in London while Huck supposedly lived in Sheffield, Huck pretends to choke on a chicken bone to gain time to think.
He then fabricates that the King visits Sheffield only in the summer for sea baths.

Joanna points out Sheffield is not on the sea; Huck denies saying it was and, after more back-and-forth, explains the King gets sea water delivered in barrels for his baths, similar to how Congress-water is obtained.
Joanna then asks if Huck also attends church, and he says yes, regularly, in their family pew—Uncle Harvey's pew.
When Joanna questions why a preacher like Harvey would need a pew, Huck, realizing his mistake (as Harvey is supposed to be a preacher), again pretends to choke.
He then claims that a church for a king has no fewer than seventeen preachers, mostly for 'style,' with most doing little other than 'loll around' and 'pass the plate.'
Joanna then asks about the treatment of servants in England.
Huck asserts that servants in England are treated worse than dogs and never get holidays like Christmas, New Year's, or Fourth of July.

When Joanna catches him in a contradiction by recalling he said he always went to church, Huck improvises that a 'valley' (valet) is different from a common servant and is legally required to attend church with the family.
Huck feels his explanation was not convincing, and Joanna seems unsatisfied.

events.text_segment:
And when it was all done me and the hare-lip had supper in the kitchen off of the leavings, whilst the others was helping the niggers clean up the things. The hare-lip she got to pumping me about England, and blest if I didn’t think the ice was getting mighty thin sometimes. She says:
“Did you ever see the king?”
“Who? William Fourth? Well, I bet I have—he goes to our church.” I knowed he was dead years ago, but I never let on. So when I says he goes to our church, she says:
“What—regular?”
“Yes—regular. His pew’s right over opposite ourn—on t’other side the pulpit.”
“I thought he lived in London?”
“Well, he does. Where would he live?”
“But I thought you lived in Sheffield?”
I see I was up a stump. I had to let on to get choked with a chicken bone, so as to get time to think how to get down again. Then I says:
“I mean he goes to our church regular when he’s in Sheffield. That’s only in the summer time, when he comes there to take the sea baths.”
“Why, how you talk—Sheffield ain’t on the sea.”
“Well, who said it was?”
“Why, you did.”
“I didn’t nuther.”
“You did!”
“I didn’t.”
“You did.”
“I never said nothing of the kind.”
“Well, what did you say, then?”
“Said he come to take the sea baths—that’s what I said.”
“Well, then, how’s he going to take the sea baths if it ain’t on the sea?”
“Looky here,” I says; “did you ever see any Congress-water?”
“Yes.”
“Well, did you have to go to Congress to get it?”
“Why, no.”
“Well, neither does William Fourth have to go to the sea to get a sea bath.”
“How does he get it, then?”
“Gets it the way people down here gets Congress-water—in barrels. There in the palace at Sheffield they’ve got furnaces, and he wants his water hot. They can’t bile that amount of water away off there at the sea. They haven’t got no conveniences for it.”
“Oh, I see, now. You might a said that in the first place and saved time.”
When she said that I see I was out of the woods again, and so I was comfortable and glad. Next, she says:
“Do you go to church, too?”
“Yes—regular.”
“Where do you set?”
“Why, in our pew.”
“Whose pew?”
“Why, ourn—your Uncle Harvey’s.”
“His’n? What does he want with a pew?”
“Wants it to set in. What did you reckon he wanted with it?”
“Why, I thought he’d be in the pulpit.”
Rot him, I forgot he was a preacher. I see I was up a stump again, so I played another chicken bone and got another think. Then I says:
“Blame it, do you suppose there ain’t but one preacher to a church?”
“Why, what do they want with more?”
“What!—to preach before a king? I never did see such a girl as you. They don’t have no less than seventeen.”
“Seventeen! My land! Why, I wouldn’t set out such a string as that, not if I never got to glory. It must take ’em a week.”
“Shucks, they don’t all of ’em preach the same day—only one of ’em.”
“Well, then, what does the rest of ’em do?”
“Oh, nothing much. Loll around, pass the plate—and one thing or another. But mainly they don’t do nothing.”
“Well, then, what are they for?”
“Why, they’re for style. Don’t you know nothing?”
“Well, I don’t want to know no such foolishness as that. How is servants treated in England? Do they treat ’em better ’n we treat our niggers?”
“No! A servant ain’t nobody there. They treat them worse than dogs.”
“Don’t they give ’em holidays, the way we do, Christmas and New Year’s week, and Fourth of July?”
“Oh, just listen! A body could tell you hain’t ever been to England by that. Why, Hare-l—why, Joanna, they never see a holiday from year’s end to year’s end; never go to the circus, nor theater, nor nigger shows, nor nowheres.”
“Nor church?”
“Nor church.”
“But you always went to church.”
Well, I was gone up again. I forgot I was the old man’s servant. But next minute I whirled in on a kind of an explanation how a valley was different from a common servant and had to go to church whether he wanted to or not, and set with the family, on account of its being the law. But I didn’t do it pretty good, and when I got done I see she warn’t satisfied.

events.title: Joanna's Doubt, Mary Jane's Kindness, and Huck's Resolve
detailed_summary: Joanna directly asks Huck if he has been telling her lies.
Huck denies lying and, at Joanna's insistence, swears on a dictionary that he has told the truth.
Joanna, somewhat mollified, says she will believe some of what he said but not all of it.

Mary Jane and Susan enter at this moment, and Mary Jane gently chides Joanna ('Joe') for speaking unkindly to Huck, emphasizing his vulnerability as a stranger far from his people and how such treatment would make one feel ashamed.
Joanna defends herself, stating she only expressed skepticism about some of Huck's 'stretchers' (exaggerations).
Mary Jane reiterates that the important thing is to treat Huck with kindness and not make him feel alienated.
Huck is profoundly affected by Mary Jane's compassion, feeling a pang of guilt for his role in the scheme to defraud her.
Susan then sharply rebukes Joanna for her behavior.
Mary Jane speaks again, with her characteristic sweetness and gentleness, which effectively silences Joanna, who then offers Huck a beautiful and heartfelt apology.
Huck is so moved by Joanna's apology that he humorously wishes he could tell a thousand more lies just to hear her apologize again, and his guilt over the conmen's plot deepens.
Following this, all the sisters endeavor to make Huck feel at home and among friends.
Overwhelmed by their kindness and his own duplicity, Huck feels deeply ashamed and internally vows to recover their stolen money or 'bust' in the attempt.

“Honest injun,” says I.
“None of it at all?”
“None of it at all. Not a lie in it,” says I.
“Lay your hand on this book and say it.”

“Well, then, I’ll believe some of it; but I hope to gracious if I’ll believe the rest.”

“That’s always your way, Maim—always sailing in to help somebody before they’re hurt. I hain’t done nothing to him. He’s told some stretchers, I reckon, and I said I wouldn’t swallow it all; and that’s every bit and grain I did say. I reckon he can stand a little thing like that, can’t he?”
“I don’t care whether ’twas little or whether ’twas big; he’s here in our house and a stranger, and it wasn’t good of you to say it. If you was in his place it would make you feel ashamed; and so you oughtn’t to say a thing to another person that will make them feel ashamed.”
“Why, Mam, he said—”
“It don’t make no difference what he said—that ain’t the thing. The thing is for you to treat him kind, and not be saying things to make him remember he ain’t in his own country and amongst his own folks.”
I says to myself, this is a girl that I’m letting that old reptile rob her of her money!
Then Susan she waltzed in; and if you’ll believe me, she did give Hare-lip hark from the tomb!
Says I to myself, and this is another one that I’m letting him rob her of her money!
Then Mary Jane she took another inning, and went in sweet and lovely again—which was her way; but when she got done there warn’t hardly anything left o’ poor Hare-lip. So she hollered.
“All right, then,” says the other girls; “you just ask his pardon.”
She done it, too; and she done it beautiful. She done it so beautiful it was good to hear; and I wished I could tell her a thousand lies, so she could do it again.
I says to myself, this is another one that I’m letting him rob her of her money. And when she got through they all jest laid theirselves out to make me feel at home and know I was amongst friends. I felt so ornery and low down and mean that I says to myself, my mind’s made up; I’ll hive that money for them or bust.

events.title: Huck's Moral Dilemma and Plan to Recover the Gold
detailed_summary: Huck announces he is going to bed, but his true intention is to figure out how to return the stolen money.
He contemplates his options, first considering privately informing Dr. Robinson about the frauds.
He quickly dismisses this, fearing Dr. Robinson might inadvertently reveal Huck as the source, leading to severe repercussions from the King and Duke.
Next, he considers telling Mary Jane directly but decides against it, worried that her emotional reaction would tip off the conmen, who, having the money, would promptly flee.
He also foresees complications if Mary Jane were to involve outside help, potentially embroiling him further.
Huck concludes that the only viable solution is to steal the money himself, and to do so in a way that does not arouse the conmen's suspicion of his involvement.
He reasons that the King and Duke will likely stay in town for a while to maximize their fraudulent gains, affording him an opportunity to act.
His plan is to steal the gold, hide it securely, and then, once he is safely downriver and away from danger, write a letter to Mary Jane revealing its hiding place.
He feels a pressing need to retrieve the money that very night, concerned that Dr. Robinson's lingering suspicions might still frighten the conmen into a premature departure.

So, thinks I, I’ll go and search them rooms. Upstairs the hall was dark, but I found the duke’s room, and started to paw around it with my hands; but I recollected it wouldn’t be much like the king to let anybody else take care of that money but his own self; so then I went to his room and begun to paw around there. But I see I couldn’t do nothing without a candle, and I dasn’t light one, of course. So I judged I’d got to do the other thing—lay for them and eavesdrop. About that time I hears their footsteps coming, and was going to skip under the bed; I reached for it, but it wasn’t where I thought it would be; but I touched the curtain that hid Mary Jane’s frocks, so I jumped in behind that and snuggled in amongst the gowns, and stood there perfectly still.
They come in and shut the door; and the first thing the duke done was to get down and look under the bed. Then I was glad I hadn’t found the bed when I wanted it. And yet, you know, it’s kind of natural to hide under the bed when you are up to anything private. They sets down then, and the king says:
“Well, what is it? And cut it middlin’ short, because it’s better for us to be down there a-whoopin’ up the mournin’ than up here givin’ ’em a chance to talk us over.”
“Well, this is it, Capet. I ain’t easy; I ain’t comfortable. That doctor lays on my mind. I wanted to know your plans. I’ve got a notion, and I think it’s a sound one.”
“What is it, duke?”
“That we better glide out of this before three in the morning, and clip it down the river with what we’ve got. Specially, seeing we got it so easy—given back to us, flung at our heads, as you may say, when of course we allowed to have to steal it back. I’m for knocking off and lighting out.”
That made me feel pretty bad. About an hour or two ago it would a been a little different, but now it made me feel bad and disappointed, The king rips out and says:
“What! And not sell out the rest o’ the property? March off like a passel of fools and leave eight or nine thous’n’ dollars’ worth o’ property layin’ around jest sufferin’ to be scooped in?—and all good, salable stuff, too.”
The duke he grumbled; said the bag of gold was enough, and he didn’t want to go no deeper—didn’t want to rob a lot of orphans of everything they had.
“Why, how you talk!” says the king. “We sha’n’t rob ’em of nothing at all but jest this money. The people that buys the property is the suff’rers; because as soon ’s it’s found out ’at we didn’t own it—which won’t be long after we’ve slid—the sale won’t be valid, and it’ll all go back to the estate. These yer orphans ’ll git their house back agin, and that’s enough for them; they’re young and spry, and k’n easy earn a livin’. They ain’t a-goin to suffer. Why, jest think—there’s thous’n’s and thous’n’s that ain’t nigh so well off. Bless you, they ain’t got noth’n’ to complain of.”
Well, the king he talked him blind; so at last he give in, and said all right, but said he believed it was blamed foolishness to stay, and that doctor hanging over them. But the king says:
“Cuss the doctor! What do we k’yer for him? Hain’t we got all the fools in town on our side? And ain’t that a big enough majority in any town?”

So, thinks I, I’ll go and search them rooms. Upstairs I went, quiet as a mouse, not wanting to wake a soul. The old house creaked under my feet, but I paid it no mind. I had business to attend to, and I wasn’t about to let a few noisy floorboards stop me.

First, I tried the door to the judge’s room. Locked tight as a drum. That was no surprise—folks in these parts were mighty careful with their belongings. But I’d seen the judge fiddling with his keys earlier, and I reckoned he might’ve left one lying around. Sure enough, after a bit of poking around, I found a key tucked under the edge of the rug. Slipped it into the lock, turned it slow, and the door swung open without so much as a squeak.

Inside, the room was neat as a pin. A big oak desk stood in the corner, piled high with papers. I tiptoed over, my heart pounding like a drum. What was I looking for? Truth be told, I wasn’t rightly sure. But something told me there was a secret in this house, and I aimed to find it.

I rifled through the papers—deeds, letters, all sorts of legal nonsense. Then my fingers brushed against something different: a small, leather-bound book. I opened it and saw names and numbers scribbled in tight, careful handwriting. Accounts, maybe, or something darker. My gut told me it was important, so I tucked it into my pocket.

Just then, I heard a floorboard groan out in the hall. My blood turned to ice. Someone was coming. Quick as a flash, I ducked behind the heavy curtains, holding my breath. The door creaked open, and I saw the shadow of a man—tall and broad-shouldered—step inside. He walked straight to the desk and started shuffling through the papers. I could hear him muttering to himself, real low and angry-like.

“Where is it?” he growled. “It was right here!”

I didn’t dare move. If he found me, there’d be hell to pay. Then, just as sudden as he’d come in, he turned and stormed out, slamming the door behind him. I waited a good long while before I dared to peek out from behind the curtain. The room was empty again, but my nerves were shot. I knew I had to get out of there fast.

Slipping back into the hall, I made for the stairs. But then I heard voices downstairs—men talking in hushed, urgent tones. I crouched low and crept closer, straining to hear.

“We can’t let him find out,” one man said. “If he gets his hands on that book, it’s all over.”

“Then we’d better find it first,” another replied. “Tear the place apart if you have to.”

My heart near about leaped out of my chest. They were talking about the book in my pocket! I had to get out of that house, and quick. But how? The front door was no good—they’d see me for sure. Then I remembered the window at the end of the hall. It led out onto the roof of the porch. From there, I could shimmy down the trellis and make a run for it.

I inched my way to the window, careful not to make a sound. The latch was stiff, but I wiggled it loose and pushed the window open. A cold night breeze hit my face as I climbed out onto the roof. Below me, the trellis looked rickety, but it’d have to do. I swung my legs over the edge and started climbing down, my fingers gripping the wood for dear life.

Halfway down, I heard a shout from inside the house. “The window’s open! He’s getting away!”

That was all the encouragement I needed. I let go and dropped the rest of the way, landing hard in the dirt. Scrambling to my feet, I took off running into the woods, the book burning a hole in my pocket. I didn’t stop until I was deep in the trees, sure nobody was following me.

Panting, I leaned against a tree and pulled out the book. Whatever was in here, it was worth a lot of trouble. And I aimed to find out why.

events.title: The Gold is Re-hidden and Immediately Stolen by Huck
detailed_summary: As the King and Duke prepare to go back downstairs, the Duke voices his opinion that they haven't hidden the money in a secure location.
This comment encourages Huck, who had been hoping for a clue to the money's whereabouts.

The Duke elaborates on his concern: Mary Jane will be in mourning, and the servant who tends to the rooms might be instructed to pack away Mary Jane's dresses and could stumble upon the money if it's among them, potentially 'borrowing' some.
The King concedes the Duke's point and approaches the curtain where Huck is concealed, fumbling nearby.
Huck remains pressed against the wall, motionless despite his trepidation, briefly contemplating his options if discovered.
Before Huck can fully form a plan, the King retrieves the bag of gold without suspecting Huck's presence.

The conmen then tear a hole in the straw tick mattress beneath the feather bed, stuff the bag of gold deep inside the straw, and declare it safe, reasoning that servants only make up the feather bed and rarely disturb the straw tick.
However, Huck, having witnessed their actions, knows better.
He seizes the opportunity and removes the money from the straw tick before the King and Duke are even halfway down the stairs.

He quickly takes the gold to his own cubby and hides it there temporarily, planning to find a more secure hiding spot outside the house later to prevent its discovery should the conmen realize it's missing and search the premises.
Still fully clothed and too agitated by the night's events to sleep, Huck waits tensely.
He hears the King and Duke return and go to their rooms; he positions himself at the top of his ladder to observe, but nothing further happens.
Huck waits patiently until the house is completely quiet, between the cessation of late-night sounds and the onset of early morning ones, before finally slipping down his ladder.

They took and shoved the bag through a rip in the straw tick that was under the feather-bed, and crammed it in a foot or two amongst the straw and said it was all right now, because a nigger only makes up the feather-bed, and don’t turn over the straw tick only about twice a year, and so it warn’t in no danger of getting stole now.
But I knowed better. I had it out of there before they was half-way down stairs. I groped along up to my cubby, and hid it there till I could get a chance to do better. I judged I better hide it outside of the house somewheres, because if they missed it they would give the house a good ransacking: I knowed that very well. Then I turned in, with my clothes all on; but I couldn’t a gone to sleep if I’d a wanted to, I was in such a sweat to get through with the business. By-and-by I heard the king and the duke come up; so I rolled off my pallet and laid with my chin at the top of my ladder, and waited to see if anything was going to happen. But nothing did.
So I held on till all the late sounds had quit and the early ones hadn’t begun yet; and then I slipped down the ladder.

events.title: Huck Hides the Money in the Coffin

He observes the corpse in the parlor.
Upon hearing someone, later identified as Mary Jane, descending the stairs, Huck quickly decides to hide the bag of money inside Peter Wilks's coffin.
He places the bag under the coffin lid, near the deceased's cold hands.

I crept to their doors and listened; they was snoring. So I tiptoed along, and got down stairs all right. There warn’t a sound anywheres. I peeped through a crack of the dining-room door, and see the men that was watching the corpse all sound asleep on their chairs. The door was open into the parlor, where the corpse was laying, and there was a candle in both rooms. I passed along, and the parlor door was open; but I see there warn’t nobody in there but the remainders of Peter; so I shoved on by; but the front door was locked, and the key wasn’t there. Just then I heard somebody coming down the stairs, back behind me. I run in the parlor and took a swift look around, and the only place I see to hide the bag was in the coffin. The lid was shoved along about a foot, showing the dead man’s face down in there, with a wet cloth over it, and his shroud on. I tucked the money-bag in under the lid, just down beyond where his hands was crossed, which made me creep, they was so cold, and then I run back across the room and in behind the door.
The person coming was Mary Jane. She went to the coffin, very soft, and kneeled down and looked in; then she put up her handkerchief, and I see she begun to cry, though I couldn’t hear her, and her back was to me. I slid out, and as I passed the dining-room I thought I’d make sure them watchers hadn’t seen me; so I looked through the crack, and everything was all right. They hadn’t stirred.

events.text_segment:
When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone. There warn’t nobody around but the family and the widow Bartley and our tribe. I watched their faces to see if anything had been happening, but I couldn’t tell.
Towards the middle of the day the undertaker come with his man, and they set the coffin in the middle of the room on a couple of chairs, and then set all our chairs in rows, and borrowed more from the neighbors till the hall and the parlor and the dining-room was full. I see the coffin lid was the way it was before, but I dasn’t go to look in under it, with folks around.
Then the people begun to flock in, and the beats and the girls took seats in the front row at the head of the coffin, and for a half an hour the people filed around slow, in single rank, and looked down at the dead man’s face a minute, and some dropped in a tear, and it was all very still and solemn, only the girls and the beats holding handkerchiefs to their eyes and keeping their heads bent, and sobbing a little. There warn’t no other sound but the scraping of the feet on the floor and blowing noses—because people always blows them more at a funeral than they do at other places except church.
When the place was packed full the undertaker he slid around in his black gloves with his softy soothering ways, putting on the last touches, and getting people and things all ship-shape and comfortable, and making no more sound than a cat. He never spoke; he moved people around, he squeezed in late ones, he opened up passageways, and done it with nods, and signs with his hands. Then he took his place over against the wall. He was the softest, glidingest, stealthiest man I ever see; and there warn’t no more smile to him than there is to a ham.
They had borrowed a melodeum—a sick one; and when everything was ready a young woman set down and worked it, and it was pretty skreeky and colicky, and everybody joined in and sung, and Peter was the only one that had a good thing, according to my notion. Then the Reverend Hobson opened up, slow and solemn, and begun to talk; and straight off the most outrageous row busted out in the cellar a body ever heard; it was only one dog, but he made a most powerful racket, and he kept it up right along; the parson he had to stand there, over the coffin, and wait—you couldn’t hear yourself think. It was right down awkward, and nobody didn’t seem to know what to do. But pretty soon they see that long-legged undertaker make a sign to the preacher as much as to say, “Don’t you worry—just depend on me.” Then he stooped down and begun to glide along the wall, just his shoulders showing over the people’s heads. So he glided along, and the powwow and racket getting more and more outrageous all the time; and at last, when he had gone around two sides of the room, he disappears down cellar. Then in about two seconds we heard a whack, and the dog he finished up with a most amazing howl or two, and then everything was dead still, and the parson begun his solemn talk where he left off. In a minute or two here comes this undertaker’s back and shoulders gliding along the wall again; and so he glided and glided around three sides of the room, and then rose up, and shaded his mouth with his hands, and stretched his neck out towards the preacher, over the people’s heads, and says, in a kind of a coarse whisper, “He had a rat!” Then he drooped down and glided along the wall again to his place. You could see it was a great satisfaction to the people, because naturally they wanted to know. A little thing like that don’t cost nothing, and it’s just the little things that makes a man to be looked up to and liked. There warn’t no more popular man in town than what that undertaker was.

When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone. There warn’t nobody around but the family and the Widow Douglas and Aunt Sally and Mary Jane and her sisters, all looking mournful and solemn. The air was heavy with grief, and it made me feel mighty uncomfortable, like I was trespassing on something private.  

I crept into the kitchen, where Jim was sitting by the fire, stirring a pot of coffee. He looked up when he seen me and nodded, but he didn’t say nothing. I reckon he felt the weight of the house too.  

“Where’s everybody?” I whispered, though I didn’t rightly know why I was whispering.  

Jim shook his head. “Dey’s all up in dey rooms, Huck. Dey ain’t et nothin’ since las’ night. Dat po’ chile, she took it mighty hard.”  

I knew he meant Mary Jane. She was the oldest of the girls, and the kindest, and she’d been real fond of the old man—Peter Wilks, that was—though I couldn’t for the life of me see why. He’d been a decent enough fellow, I suppose, but he warn’t no saint, and the way they was carrying on, you’d think the world had ended.  

I poured myself a cup of coffee and sat down beside Jim. “Reckon they’ll have the funeral today?”  

“Dey say dis evenin’,” Jim said. “Dey waitin’ on some mo’ folks to come in from de country.”  

I nodded and sipped my coffee, thinking about the mess we was in. Me and the Duke and the King had come here pretending to be the dead man’s brothers, and now here we was, stuck in a house full of grieving folks who believed every word we said. It made me feel low-down and mean, but every time I thought about telling the truth, I remembered the King’s threats and the Duke’s sly looks, and I kept my mouth shut.  

After a while, the door creaked open, and Mary Jane come in. Her eyes was red from crying, and she looked like she hadn’t slept a wink. She give me a sad little smile and went to the stove to warm her hands.  

“You all right, Miss Mary?” I asked, though I could see plain enough she warn’t.  

She shook her head. “No, Huck, I ain’t. But I reckon I’ll have to be, for the sake of my sisters.”  

That made me feel worse than ever. Here was a girl who’d just lost her uncle, and she was worrying about everybody else. And me and them two frauds was fixing to rob her and her family blind.  

Jim must’ve seen the look on my face, ‘cause he give me a sharp glance, like he was warning me to keep my head. I swallowed hard and stared into my coffee.  

Mary Jane turned to us. “Huck, Jim, I want to thank you both for being so kind. You’ve been a comfort to us in this hard time.”  

I couldn’t hardly look at her. “Ain’t nothin’, ma’am,” I mumbled.  

She smiled again, sad and sweet, and then she left the kitchen, her skirts rustling soft on the floor.  

Jim let out a long breath. “Dat’s a good chile, Huck. Too good fo’ dis world.”  

I nodded, feeling sick to my stomach. “Jim, we got to do somethin’. We can’t let them swindlers get away with this.”  

Jim’s eyes got big. “What you reckon we can do? Dem two is sharp as tacks, an’ dey got us tangled up in dis mess.”  

I didn’t know the answer, but I knew one thing—I warn’t gonna stand by and let Mary Jane and her sisters get cheated. Somehow, someway, I was gonna make things right.  

Just then, we heard footsteps on the stairs, and the Duke’s voice calling for me. I set down my coffee and stood up, steeling myself for whatever new devilment them two had cooked up.  

“Comin’,” I called back, but my heart warn’t in it.  

Jim give me one last look, full of worry, and I knew he was thinking the same thing I was—this was gonna end bad, one way or another.

They buried him, and we come back home, and I went to watching faces again—I couldn’t help it, and I couldn’t rest easy. But nothing come of it; the faces didn’t tell me nothing.
The king he visited around in the evening, and sweetened everybody up, and made himself ever so friendly; and he give out the idea that his congregation over in England would be in a sweat about him, so he must hurry and settle up the estate right away and leave for home. events.title: The Heartbreaking Sale and Separation of the Enslaved Family
characters: enslaved people (two sons and their mother)
detailed_summary: The King promptly arranges for the auction of the Wilks estate, including the house and the enslaved people, just two days after the funeral.
The day after the funeral, slave traders arrive, and the King sells the enslaved family—two sons are sent upriver to Memphis, and their mother downriver to New Orleans.
The separation causes immense grief for both the Wilks girls and the enslaved family, who cry and lament their parting.
The girls express their shock, never having imagined the enslaved family would be sold or separated.
Huck is profoundly moved by the scene, stating he could hardly bear it if he didn't know the sale was fraudulent and the enslaved individuals would likely be back in a short time.
The townspeople are also stirred by this event, with many openly condemning the separation of the mother and her children as scandalous.
This public outcry damages the reputation of the King and Duke, making the Duke particularly anxious, though the King stubbornly proceeds with his plans.

Well, blamed if the king didn’t bill the house and the niggers and all the property for auction straight off—sale two days after the funeral; but anybody could buy private beforehand if they wanted to.
So the next day after the funeral, along about noon-time, the girls’ joy got the first jolt. A couple of nigger traders come along, and the king sold them the niggers reasonable, for three-day drafts as they called it, and away they went, the two sons up the river to Memphis, and their mother down the river to Orleans. I thought them poor girls and them niggers would break their hearts for grief; they cried around each other, and took on so it most made me down sick to see it. The girls said they hadn’t ever dreamed of seeing the family separated or sold away from the town. I can’t ever get it out of my memory, the sight of them poor miserable girls and niggers hanging around each other’s necks and crying; and I reckon I couldn’t a stood it all, but would a had to bust out and tell on our gang if I hadn’t knowed the sale warn’t no account and the niggers would be back home in a week or two.
The thing made a big stir in the town, too, and a good many come out flatfooted and said it was scandalous to separate the mother and the children that way. It injured the frauds some; but the old fool he bulled right along, spite of all the duke could say or do, and I tell you the duke was powerful uneasy.

They interrogate Huck about whether he was in their room or saw anyone else enter it, suspecting the money is missing.
Huck denies being near their room since Mary Jane first showed it to them.
When pressed, Huck cleverly suggests he saw the enslaved individuals (referred to as 'niggers' by the characters) coming out of their room on the morning of the funeral, acting secretively.
The King and Duke are initially surprised, then seemingly convinced by Huck's implication that the enslaved people stole the money before being sold.
The Duke laments selling them so cheaply, believing they possessed significant 'histrionic talent' for feigning sorrow at their departure.
The King dismisses Huck sharply when he asks if something is wrong, telling him to mind his own business.
As they leave, the Duke makes a sarcastic comment about 'quick sales and small profits,' leading to an argument with the King about whose fault the supposed loss is.
The King then berates Huck for not informing him sooner about seeing the enslaved people in his room.
Huck feels relieved that he successfully diverted suspicion onto the enslaved people, especially since he believes they are safe and will not be harmed by his accusation, given their fraudulent sale.

Next day was auction day. About broad day in the morning the king and the duke come up in the garret and woke me up, and I see by their look that there was trouble. The king says:
“Was you in my room night before last?”
“No, your majesty”—which was the way I always called him when nobody but our gang warn’t around.
“Was you in there yisterday er last night?”
“No, your majesty.”
“Honor bright, now—no lies.”
“Honor bright, your majesty, I’m telling you the truth. I hain’t been a-near your room since Miss Mary Jane took you and the duke and showed it to you.”
The duke says:
“Have you seen anybody else go in there?”
“No, your grace, not as I remember, I believe.”
“Stop and think.”
I studied awhile and see my chance; then I says:
“Well, I see the niggers go in there several times.”
Both of them gave a little jump, and looked like they hadn’t ever expected it, and then like they had. Then the duke says:
“What, all of them?”
“No—leastways, not all at once—that is, I don’t think I ever see them all come out at once but just one time.”
“Hello! When was that?”
“It was the day we had the funeral. In the morning. It warn’t early, because I overslept. I was just starting down the ladder, and I see them.”
“Well, go on, go on! What did they do? How’d they act?”
“They didn’t do nothing. And they didn’t act anyway much, as fur as I see. They tiptoed away; so I seen, easy enough, that they’d shoved in there to do up your majesty’s room, or something, s’posing you was up; and found you warn’t up, and so they was hoping to slide out of the way of trouble without waking you up, if they hadn’t already waked you up.”
“Great guns, this is a go!” says the king; and both of them looked pretty sick and tolerable silly. They stood there a-thinking and scratching their heads a minute, and the duke he bust into a kind of a little raspy chuckle, and says:
“It does beat all how neat the niggers played their hand. They let on to be sorry they was going out of this region! And I believed they was sorry, and so did you, and so did everybody. Don’t ever tell me any more that a nigger ain’t got any histrionic talent. Why, the way they played that thing it would fool anybody. In my opinion, there’s a fortune in ’em. If I had capital and a theater, I wouldn’t want a better lay-out than that—and here we’ve gone and sold ’em for a song. Yes, and ain’t privileged to sing the song yet. Say, where is that song—that draft?”
“In the bank for to be collected. Where would it be?”
“Well, that’s all right then, thank goodness.”
Says I, kind of timid-like:
“Is something gone wrong?”
The king whirls on me and rips out:
“None o’ your business! You keep your head shet, and mind y’r own affairs—if you got any. Long as you’re in this town don’t you forgit that—you hear?” Then he says to the duke, “We got to jest swaller it and say noth’n’: mum’s the word for us.”
As they was starting down the ladder the duke he chuckles again, and says:
“Quick sales and small profits! It’s a good business—yes.”
The king snarls around on him and says:
“I was trying to do for the best in sellin’ ’em out so quick. If the profits has turned out to be none, lackin’ considable, and none to carry, is it my fault any more’n it’s yourn?”
“Well, they’d be in this house yet and we wouldn’t if I could a got my advice listened to.”
The king sassed back as much as was safe for him, and then swapped around and lit into me again. He give me down the banks for not coming and telling him I see the niggers come out of his room acting that way—said any fool would a knowed something was up. And then waltzed in and cussed himself awhile, and said it all come of him not laying late and taking his natural rest that morning, and he’d be blamed if he’d ever do it again. So they went off a-jawing; and I felt dreadful glad I’d worked it all off on to the niggers, and yet hadn’t done the niggers no harm by it.

I shook my head.

events.title: Huck Comforts Mary Jane and Reveals a Shocking Truth
detailed_summary: Huck, upon waking, finds Mary Jane crying in her room while packing for England, distressed about the separation of the enslaved family sold by the con men.
Feeling sympathy, Huck enters her room and tries to comfort her.
Mary Jane expresses her deep sorrow that the enslaved mother and children will never see each other again.
Impulsively, Huck blurts out that they will indeed be reunited within two weeks, a statement he knows to be true.

Taken aback by his own sudden revelation, Huck pauses to consider whether telling the full truth is wiser than concocting a lie in this difficult situation, ultimately deciding that the truth, though risky, seems safer.
He asks Mary Jane if she can go to a place out of town, Mr. Lothrop's, and stay for three or four days.
Huck strikes a deal with Mary Jane: if he proves how he knows the enslaved family will be reunited, she must go to Mr. Lothrop's and stay for the agreed time, to which she readily consents.
After securing her promise and bolting the door for privacy, Huck gravely informs Mary Jane that her supposed uncles are, in fact, frauds and 'dead-beats.'
Mary Jane is, of course, deeply shaken but then quickly consumed by rage, exclaiming that the impostors should be immediately tarred, feathered, and thrown into the river.

By-and-by it was getting-up time. So I come down the ladder and started for down-stairs; but as I come to the girls’ room the door was open, and I see Mary Jane setting by her old hair trunk, which was open and she’d been packing things in it—getting ready to go to England. But she had stopped now with a folded gown in her lap, and had her face in her hands, crying. I felt awful bad to see it; of course anybody would. I went in there and says:
“Miss Mary Jane, you can’t a-bear to see people in trouble, and I can’t—most always. Tell me about it.”
So she done it. And it was the niggers—I just expected it. She said the beautiful trip to England was most about spoiled for her; she didn’t know how she was ever going to be happy there, knowing the mother and the children warn’t ever going to see each other no more—and then busted out bitterer than ever, and flung up her hands, and says:
“Oh, dear, dear, to think they ain’t ever going to see each other any more!”
“But they will—and inside of two weeks—and I know it!” says I.
Laws, it was out before I could think! And before I could budge she throws her arms around my neck and told me to say it again, say it again, say it again!
I see I had spoke too sudden and said too much, and was in a close place. I asked her to let me think a minute; and she set there, very impatient and excited and handsome, but looking kind of happy and eased-up, like a person that’s had a tooth pulled out. So I went to studying it out. I says to myself, I reckon a body that ups and tells the truth when he is in a tight place is taking considerable many resks, though I ain’t had no experience, and can’t say for certain; but it looks so to me, anyway; and yet here’s a case where I’m blest if it don’t look to me like the truth is better and actuly safer than a lie. I must lay it by in my mind, and think it over some time or other, it’s so kind of strange and unregular. I never see nothing like it. Well, I says to myself at last, I’m a-going to chance it; I’ll up and tell the truth this time, though it does seem most like setting down on a kag of powder and touching it off just to see where you’ll go to. Then I says:
“Miss Mary Jane, is there any place out of town a little ways where you could go and stay three or four days?”
“Yes; Mr. Lothrop’s. Why?”
“Never mind why yet. If I’ll tell you how I know the niggers will see each other again inside of two weeks—here in this house—and prove how I know it—will you go to Mr. Lothrop’s and stay four days?”
“Four days!” she says; “I’ll stay a year!”
“All right,” I says, “I don’t want nothing more out of you than just your word—I druther have it than another man’s kiss-the-Bible.” She smiled and reddened up very sweet, and I says, “If you don’t mind it, I’ll shut the door—and bolt it.”
Then I come back and set down again, and says:
“Don’t you holler. Just set still and take it like a man. I got to tell the truth, and you want to brace up, Miss Mary, because it’s a bad kind, and going to be hard to take, but there ain’t no help for it. These uncles of yourn ain’t no uncles at all; they’re a couple of frauds—regular dead-beats. There, now we’re over the worst of it, you can stand the rest middling easy.”
It jolted her up like everything, of course; but I was over the shoal water now, so I went right along, her eyes a-blazing higher and higher all the time, and told her every blame thing, from where we first struck that young fool going up to the steamboat, clear through to where she flung herself on to the king’s breast at the front door and he kissed her sixteen or seventeen times—and then up she jumps, with her face afire like sunset, and says:
“The brute! Come, don’t waste a minute—not a second—we’ll have them tarred and feathered, and flung in the river!”

By-and-by it was getting-up time. The sun was just beginning to peek over the horizon, casting a golden glow across the river. I stretched and yawned, feeling the damp morning air on my skin. Jim was already stirring, poking at the embers of last night’s fire to get it going again. The smell of coffee started to mix with the scent of the river, and I reckoned there wasn’t much better than waking up to that.

“Mornin’, Huck,” Jim said, his voice low and steady like always.  

“Mornin’,” I mumbled back, rubbing the sleep out of my eyes.  

We didn’t talk much at first, just let the quiet of the morning settle around us. The river was calm, barely making a sound as it flowed past our little camp. Birds were starting to chirp in the trees, and now and then a fish would jump, sending ripples out across the water. It was peaceful, the kind of peace that made a feller forget about all the troubles waiting for him back on shore.  

Jim handed me a tin cup of coffee, strong and bitter, just the way I liked it. I took a sip and felt it warm me up from the inside. “Reckon we oughta get movin’ soon,” I said, looking up at the sky. “Ain’t no tellin’ who might come along this stretch of the river.”  

Jim nodded. “You right ‘bout dat, Huck. Best we put some miles ‘tween us and anybody lookin’.”  

We packed up quick, rolling our blankets and dousing the fire. The raft was right where we left it, tied up to a willow branch that hung low over the water. I untied it while Jim checked the poles and supplies. Then we pushed off, letting the current take us downstream.  

The sun climbed higher, burning off the morning mist. I sat on the edge of the raft, trailing my fingers in the cool water. Jim hummed a tune, something low and sad, the kind of song that made you think about things you’d rather forget. I didn’t ask him about it. Some things a man keeps to himself, and I reckoned Jim had plenty of those.  

After a while, the river widened, and the trees on either side grew thicker. We passed a little town tucked back in the woods, smoke curling up from chimneys. I could hear the faint sound of a bell ringing—maybe calling folks to church or marking the hour. We kept to the middle of the river, far enough away that nobody’d pay us any mind.  

“You ever think ‘bout what’s waitin’ for us downriver?” I asked Jim after a spell.  

He looked at me, his dark eyes thoughtful. “Sometimes. But mostly I thinks ‘bout what’s behind us. Ain’t no use worryin’ ‘bout what you can’t see yet.”  

I reckoned he was right. Still, I couldn’t help but wonder what lay ahead. Freedom for Jim, maybe. For me? I didn’t rightly know. All I knew was that being on the raft with Jim felt more like home than anything I’d ever known.  

The day wore on, the sun beating down on us. We took turns napping in the shade of our little shelter on the raft. When evening came, we found a quiet spot to pull ashore and make camp again. Jim caught a couple of fish, and we fried them up with some cornbread. It wasn’t fancy, but it filled our bellies.  

As the fire crackled, I leaned back and looked up at the stars. They seemed brighter out here, away from towns and people. Jim sat across from me, his face glowing in the firelight.  

“Huck,” he said after a while, “you ever feel like dis river’s carryin’ us someplace important?”  

I thought about it. “Maybe. Or maybe it’s just carryin’ us away from the bad stuff.”  

Jim nodded slowly. “Ain’t nothin’ wrong with dat.”  

I smiled a little. “No, I reckon there ain’t.”  

And with that, we let the night settle around us, listening to the river whisper its secrets as it flowed on into the darkness.

events.title: Huck Outlines a Plan for Justice and Mary Jane's Role
detailed_summary: Huck tempers Mary Jane's immediate desire for vengeance, reminding her to consider her actions carefully.
He explains that a premature exposure of the frauds would endanger another innocent person (Jim), whom they have a responsibility to protect.
Huck then lays out his plan: Mary Jane is to depart for Mr. Lothrop's place and remain there until nine or half-past nine that night.

If Huck hasn't returned by eleven o'clock, she should place a candle in her window as a signal; if he still hasn't appeared by eleven, it means he has escaped and is safe, at which point she can expose the con men and have them jailed.
He instructs Mary Jane that if he happens to be captured alongside the frauds, she must publicly declare that he had confided everything to her beforehand and offer him her full support.

To provide evidence against the con men, Huck writes 'Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville' on a piece of paper for Mary Jane, telling her to give it to the court so they can summon witnesses from that town who can identify the frauds.

Huck reassures her that the ongoing auction and the sale of the enslaved individuals are invalid and that the enslaved people will be returned, emphasizing that the con men are in a difficult position and won't be able to collect any money.

“Oh,” she says, “what am I thinking about!” she says, and set right down again. “Don’t mind what I said—please don’t—you won’t, now, will you?” Laying her silky hand on mine in that kind of a way that I said I would die first. “I never thought, I was so stirred up,” she says; “now go on, and I won’t do so any more. You tell me what to do, and whatever you say I’ll do it.”
“Well,” I says, “it’s a rough gang, them two frauds, and I’m fixed so I got to travel with them a while longer, whether I want to or not—I druther not tell you why; and if you was to blow on them this town would get me out of their claws, and I’d be all right; but there’d be another person that you don’t know about who’d be in big trouble. Well, we got to save him, hain’t we? Of course. Well, then, we won’t blow on them.”
Saying them words put a good idea in my head. I see how maybe I could get me and Jim rid of the frauds; get them jailed here, and then leave. But I didn’t want to run the raft in the daytime without anybody aboard to answer questions but me; so I didn’t want the plan to begin working till pretty late to-night. I says:
“Miss Mary Jane, I’ll tell you what we’ll do, and you won’t have to stay at Mr. Lothrop’s so long, nuther. How fur is it?”
“A little short of four miles—right out in the country, back here.”
“Well, that’ll answer. Now you go along out there, and lay low till nine or half-past to-night, and then get them to fetch you home again—tell them you’ve thought of something. If you get here before eleven put a candle in this window, and if I don’t turn up wait till eleven, and then if I don’t turn up it means I’m gone, and out of the way, and safe. Then you come out and spread the news around, and get these beats jailed.”
“Good,” she says, “I’ll do it.”
“And if it just happens so that I don’t get away, but get took up along with them, you must up and say I told you the whole thing beforehand, and you must stand by me all you can.”
“Stand by you! indeed I will. They sha’n’t touch a hair of your head!” she says, and I see her nostrils spread and her eyes snap when she said it, too.
“If I get away I sha’n’t be here,” I says, “to prove these rapscallions ain’t your uncles, and I couldn’t do it if I was here. I could swear they was beats and bummers, that’s all, though that’s worth something. Well, there’s others can do that better than what I can, and they’re people that ain’t going to be doubted as quick as I’d be. I’ll tell you how to find them. Gimme a pencil and a piece of paper. There—‘Royal Nonesuch, Bricksville.’ Put it away, and don’t lose it. When the court wants to find out something about these two, let them send up to Bricksville and say they’ve got the men that played the Royal Nonesuch, and ask for some witnesses—why, you’ll have that entire town down here before you can hardly wink, Miss Mary. And they’ll come a-biling, too.”
I judged we had got everything fixed about right now. So I says:
“Just let the auction go right along, and don’t worry. Nobody don’t have to pay for the things they buy till a whole day after the auction on accounts of the short notice, and they ain’t going out of this till they get that money; and the way we’ve fixed it the sale ain’t going to count, and they ain’t going to get no money. It’s just like the way it was with the niggers—it warn’t no sale, and the niggers will be back before long. Why, they can’t collect the money for the niggers yet—they’re in the worst kind of a fix, Miss Mary.”
“Well,” she says, “I’ll run down to breakfast now, and then I’ll start straight for Mr. Lothrop’s.”

We got to the house where Mr. Lothrop lived—a fine, big place with white pillars out front, like somethin’ out of a storybook. The duke and the king put on their grandest airs, puffin’ out their chests and adjustin’ their fancy clothes. The king turned to me and whispered, “Now, Huck, you remember—you’re our servant boy. Keep your mouth shut and let us do the talkin’.”

I nodded, though I didn’t like the idea much. But I figured it was best to play along for now.

The door was opened by a tall, stern-lookin’ man with spectacles perched on his nose. “Yes?” he said, lookin’ us up and down like we was a pack of stray dogs.

The king swept off his hat and bowed real low. “Good sir, might we have the honor of speakin’ with Mr. Lothrop? We are men of business, and we have matters of great importance to discuss.”

The man frowned. “Mr. Lothrop is occupied at present. State your business.”

The duke stepped forward, smooth as butter. “My dear fellow, we represent the interests of a certain… charitable organization. Our mission is of a most delicate nature, and we must speak with Mr. Lothrop personally.”

The man hesitated, then sighed. “Very well. Wait here.” He shut the door in our faces.

The king wiped his forehead with his sleeve. “Blamed if that ain’t the coldest reception I ever got,” he muttered.

“Hush,” said the duke. “We’re almost there. Just keep your wits about you.”

After what felt like an hour, the door opened again, and this time a stout, red-faced gentleman stood there, lookin’ us over with sharp eyes. “Well?” he said. “What’s this about?”

The king launched into his tale, all about how we was representin’ a missionary society tryin’ to bring the gospel to the heathens overseas, and how we needed funds to carry on the Lord’s work. He laid it on thick, talkin’ about sufferin’ souls and the need for Christian charity. I near about choked listenin’ to it, but Mr. Lothrop seemed to be takin’ it all in.

When the king finished, Mr. Lothrop stroked his chin. “A noble cause, gentlemen. But I must confess, I’ve never heard of your organization.”

The duke jumped in quick. “Ah, we are a new society, sir. Our work is just beginnin’, but we have the highest recommendations from the most respectable circles.”

Mr. Lothrop’s eyes narrowed. “Is that so? And who might these recommenders be?”

I could see the duke sweat a little. “Why, uh, the Reverend Dr. Blodgett of Boston, for one. And, er, Judge Thatcher of St. Petersburg—”

“Judge Thatcher?” Mr. Lothrop cut in. “I know Judge Thatcher. Strange he never mentioned your society to me.”

The king and the duke exchanged a quick glance. Then the king chuckled, tryin’ to cover his tracks. “Well, now, the judge is a busy man. Likely it slipped his mind.”

Mr. Lothrop folded his arms. “Gentlemen, I think you’d better leave. And if I hear of you tryin’ this game on anyone else, I’ll see to it that the law takes an interest in your… charitable work.”

The duke’s face turned red, and the king sputtered, but there warn’t nothin’ they could say. We backed off the porch quick as we could, and once we was out of sight, the king let out a string of curses that would’ve made a sailor blush.

“Blast that meddlesome old fool!” he snarled. “We was this close, Huck—this close to a fortune!”

The duke was quieter, but I could see the anger in his eyes. “We’ll find another mark,” he said. “There’s plenty of fools in the world.”

But I’d had enough. “Look,” I said, “maybe it’s time we quit this business. Ain’t no good gonna come of it.”

The king rounded on me. “Quit? After all the trouble we gone to? You got a better idea, boy?”

I swallowed hard. “Well, I reckon we could just… travel honest for a while. Work our way along, maybe.”

The duke laughed, but it warn’t a nice laugh. “Work? Son, you ain’t got the first notion of how the world works. Honest men die poor.”

events.title: Mary Jane's Departure and a Final Revelation About the Money
detailed_summary: Huck advises Mary Jane to leave for Mr. Lothrop's before breakfast, arguing that her expressive face would inadvertently reveal her knowledge of the deception to her 'uncles'.
Mary Jane understands and agrees to go, but firmly states she will not send her love to the frauds, a sentiment Huck respects.
Huck then confesses to Mary Jane that he had stolen the bag of gold from the con men, intending to return it to her.
He explains that he was nearly caught and had to hide the money in the first available spot, expressing his deep regret that it might no longer be there and that the hiding place was not ideal.
Mary Jane consoles Huck, insisting it wasn't his fault.

Unwilling to verbally describe the grim location of the hidden money (Peter Wilks's coffin), Huck writes it down on a piece of paper for her to read on her way to Mr. Lothrop's: 'I put it in the coffin.'
Recalling Mary Jane's sorrow at the coffin, Huck is moved, and as he gives her the note, he sees tears in her eyes as well.
Mary Jane shakes his hand firmly, promises to follow all his instructions, and assures him she will never forget him and will pray for him, then departs.

Huck reflects on Mary Jane's remarkable character, her grit, goodness, and beauty, admitting he has thought of her countless times since her departure and is deeply touched by her promise to pray for him.

“’Deed, that ain’t the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,” I says, “by no manner of means; go before breakfast.”
“Why?”
“What did you reckon I wanted you to go at all for, Miss Mary?”
“Well, I never thought—and come to think, I don’t know. What was it?”
“Why, it’s because you ain’t one of these leather-face people. I don’t want no better book than what your face is. A body can set down and read it off like coarse print. Do you reckon you can go and face your uncles when they come to kiss you good-morning, and never—”
“There, there, don’t! Yes, I’ll go before breakfast—I’ll be glad to. And leave my sisters with them?”
“Yes; never mind about them. They’ve got to stand it yet a while. They might suspicion something if all of you was to go. I don’t want you to see them, nor your sisters, nor nobody in this town; if a neighbor was to ask how is your uncles this morning your face would tell something. No, you go right along, Miss Mary Jane, and I’ll fix it with all of them. I’ll tell Miss Susan to give your love to your uncles and say you’ve went away for a few hours for to get a little rest and change, or to see a friend, and you’ll be back to-night or early in the morning.”
“Gone to see a friend is all right, but I won’t have my love given to them.”
“Well, then, it sha’n’t be.” It was well enough to tell her so—no harm in it. It was only a little thing to do, and no trouble; and it’s the little things that smooths people’s roads the most, down here below; it would make Mary Jane comfortable, and it wouldn’t cost nothing. Then I says: “There’s one more thing—that bag of money.”
“Well, they’ve got that; and it makes me feel pretty silly to think how they got it.”
“No, you’re out, there. They hain’t got it.”
“Why, who’s got it?”
“I wish I knowed, but I don’t. I had it, because I stole it from them; and I stole it to give to you; and I know where I hid it, but I’m afraid it ain’t there no more. I’m awful sorry, Miss Mary Jane, I’m just as sorry as I can be; but I done the best I could; I did honest. I come nigh getting caught, and I had to shove it into the first place I come to, and run—and it warn’t a good place.”
“Oh, stop blaming yourself—it’s too bad to do it, and I won’t allow it—you couldn’t help it; it wasn’t your fault. Where did you hide it?”
I didn’t want to set her to thinking about her troubles again; and I couldn’t seem to get my mouth to tell her what would make her see that corpse laying in the coffin with that bag of money on his stomach. So for a minute I didn’t say nothing; then I says:
“I’d ruther not tell you where I put it, Miss Mary Jane, if you don’t mind letting me off; but I’ll write it for you on a piece of paper, and you can read it along the road to Mr. Lothrop’s, if you want to. Do you reckon that’ll do?”
“Oh, yes.”
So I wrote: “I put it in the coffin. It was in there when you was crying there, away in the night. I was behind the door, and I was mighty sorry for you, Miss Mary Jane.”
It made my eyes water a little to remember her crying there all by herself in the night, and them devils laying there right under her own roof, shaming her and robbing her; and when I folded it up and give it to her I see the water come into her eyes, too; and she shook me by the hand, hard, and says:
“Good-bye. I’m going to do everything just as you’ve told me; and if I don’t ever see you again, I sha’n’t ever forget you and I’ll think of you a many and a many a time, and I’ll pray for you, too!”—and she was gone.
Pray for me! I reckoned if she knowed me she’d take a job that was more nearer her size. But I bet she done it, just the same—she was just that kind. She had the grit to pray for Judus if she took the notion—there warn’t no back-down to her, I judge. You may say what you want to, but in my opinion she had more sand in her than any girl I ever see; in my opinion she was just full of sand. It sounds like flattery, but it ain’t no flattery. And when it comes to beauty—and goodness, too—she lays over them all. I hain’t ever seen her since that time that I see her go out of that door; no, I hain’t ever seen her since, but I reckon I’ve thought of her a many and a many a million times, and of her saying she would pray for me; and if ever I’d a thought it would do any good for me to pray for her, blamed if I wouldn’t a done it or bust.

“‘Deed, that ain’t the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,” I says, “by no manner of means; go before breakfast.”  

“Why?”  

“What did you reckon I wanted you to go at all for, Miss Mary?”  

“Well, I never thought—and come to think, I don’t know. What was it?”  

“Why, it’s because you ain’t one of these leather-face people. I don’t want no better book than what your face is. A body can set down and read it off like coarse print. Do you reckon you can go and face your uncles when they come to kiss you good-morning, and never—”  

“There, there, don’t! Yes, I’ll go—and I’ll do it this very minute. I’ll keep my own counsel—and I’ll tell them to send their love to England, if they want to. But I won’t have any love sent to them.”  

“No,” I says, “it ain’t necessary; it would only confuse them.”  

She stood there thinking a minute, then she says:  

“I’m a-going; but I’ll think of you, and I’ll pray for you, too!” and she was gone.  

I thought about her a good deal after that; I reckon I thought about her a many and a many a million times, and said I hoped she was all right; and I knowed she was, too, because she was grit clear through, and had the most sand of any girl I ever see; and just as good as she could be. I don’t care what the others say about her—they can say what they want to; but I reckon they’d have to say she was the best girl that ever was, and the prettiest, too, if they knowed her like I did.  

And when it comes to beauty—and goodness, too—she lays over them all. I hain’t ever seen her since that time that I see her go out of that door; no, I hain’t ever seen her since, but I reckon I’ve thought of her a many and a many a million times, and of her saying she would pray for me; and if ever I’d a thought it would do any good for me to pray for her, blamed if I wouldn’t a done it or bust.  

Well, Mary Jane she lit out the back way, I reckon; because nobody see her go. When I struck Susan and the hare-lip, I says:

“Only think of that, now! What’s the matter with her?”

“Mumps.”  

“Mumps your granny! They don’t set up with people that’s got the mumps.”  

“They don’t, don’t they? You better bet they do with these mumps. These mumps is different. It’s a new kind, Miss Mary Jane said.”  

“How’s it a new kind?”  

“Because it’s mixed up with other things.”  

“What other things?”  

“Well, measles, and whooping-cough, and erysipelas, and consumption, and yaller janders, and brain-fever, and I don’t know what all.”  

“My land! And they call it the mumps?”  

“That’s what Miss Mary Jane said.”  

“Well, what in the nation do they call it the mumps for?”  

“Why, because it is the mumps. That’s what it starts with.”  

“Well, ther’ ain’t no sense in it.
