“’Deed, that ain’t the ticket, Miss Mary Jane,” I says, “by no manner of means; go before breakfast.”

She looked at me kind of puzzled-like, her pretty brow wrinklin’ up, and I could see she was tryin’ to make sense of what I was sayin’. 

“Why, Huck,” she says, “what do you mean? Ain’t it proper to go after breakfast?”

Now, I hadn’t rightly thought it through myself, but I knew somehow that goin’ early was the better way. So I just stuck to my guns. 

“No, ma’am,” I says. “Folks is fresher in the mornin’, and their hearts is softer. If you got somethin’ to say that’s important, best say it when the sun’s just up and the world ain’t had time to get all tangled in its own meanness yet.”

She studied me for a minute, then nodded slow-like. “You might be right, Huck. There’s a wisdom in that, I reckon.”

I felt mighty relieved she took it so well. Miss Mary Jane was one of the finest ladies I ever knew—kind-hearted and straight as a ramrod. If she was fixin’ to do somethin’, she’d do it right, and I didn’t want her to go off half-cocked on account of bad timin’.

“What time would you suggest, then?” she asked.

“Oh, ’bout sunup, I’d say,” I told her. “That’s when the birds is singin’ and the dew’s still on the grass. Makes a body feel hopeful, don’t it?”

She smiled then, and it was like the sun breakin’ through the clouds. “Yes, it does. Thank you, Huck. You’ve got a good heart.”

I reckon I blushed some at that, ’cause I ain’t used to such fine talk, ’specially from the likes of her. But I just ducked my head and scuffed my boot in the dirt. 

“Aw, shucks, Miss Mary Jane, I ain’t done nothin’.”

“You’ve done more than you know,” she says, and with that, she turned and went back inside, her skirts swishin’ soft in the mornin’ air.

I stood there a minute, feelin’ queer but sort of proud too. It ain’t often a feller like me gets to advise a real lady, and have her take it to heart besides. 

Then I got to thinkin’ about what she was plannin’ to do, and my stomach knotted up some. She was fixin’ to confront them two frauds, the king and the duke, about their dirty dealings with the Wilks family. It was a brave thing, but a dangerous one too. Them two was slippery as eels and mean as snakes when cornered. 

I wished I could go with her, but I knew it wouldn’t do. This was her fight, and she had to face it her own way. All I could do was hope the good Lord would look out for her, and maybe keep an eye peeled myself from a distance.

The next mornin’, I was up before dawn, waitin’ by the gate. The sky was just turnin’ pink in the east when I seen her comin’ down the path, all dressed neat and proper, her head held high. 

“You goin’ now, Miss Mary Jane?” I asked, though I knew the answer.

“Yes, Huck,” she says. “It’s time.”

I nodded. “You want me to—I dunno—keep a lookout or somethin’?”

She put a hand on my shoulder, light as a butterfly. “You’ve done enough already. But thank you.”

Then she walked off toward the tavern where them two scalawags was stayin’, and I watched her go, feelin’ about as helpless as a one-legged man at a kickin’ contest.

The sun climbed higher, and the town started wakin’ up. I loafed around, tryin’ to look like I wasn’t up to nothin’, but all the while my ears was pricked for any sound of trouble. 

Then, ’bout an hour later, I seen her comin’ back. And from the look on her face—well, I couldn’t tell if she’d won or lost. She was pale but calm, like she’d seen somethin’ awful but wasn’t gonna let it break her.

“Miss Mary Jane?” I ventured as she got close.

She stopped and looked at me, and her eyes was clear and steady. “It’s done, Huck. They know I know.”

“Did they—I mean, was they—”

“They denied it, of course,” she says. “But the truth has a way of comin’ out. We’ll see what happens now.”

I wanted to ask more, but I could see she was wore out from the strain of it. So I just said, “You done the right thing, ma’am. That’s what counts.”

She give me another of them smiles, though it didn’t reach her eyes this time. “I hope so, Huck. I surely do hope so.”

And with that, we went in to breakfast, where nobody but me knew what she’d been through that mornin’. The others chattered away, not noticin’ how quiet she was, or how her hands shook just a little when she poured the coffee.

But I noticed. And I made up my mind then and there to keep extra close watch on them two villains. ’Cause if they thought they could hurt Miss Mary Jane and get away with it, they had another think comin’—and Huck Finn aimed to see they got it.

events.title: Huck Deceives Susan and Joanna to Cover Mary Jane's Absence
detailed_summary: After Mary Jane secretly leaves, Huck approaches her sisters, Susan and Joanna (the 'hare-lip'), to explain Mary Jane's absence.
He initially tells them Mary Jane rushed off to visit a sick friend from across the river, named Hanner Proctor.

When pressed for details about Hanner's illness, Huck invents a complex and severe disease, describing it as a new kind of mumps mixed with measles, whooping cough, erysipelas, consumption, yellow jaundice, and brain fever.

He convinces the sisters that this 'pluribus-unum mumps' is highly contagious and that they shouldn't tell their 'uncles' about Mary Jane's exposure, as it would delay their trip to England for at least three months.
The sisters, eager to go to England, agree not to tell anyone, especially their 'uncles'.

Huck then refines the cover story, instructing the sisters to tell their 'uncles' that Mary Jane went to ask the wealthy Apthorp family to attend the auction and buy the house, as Peter Wilks would have wished it.
The sisters accept this explanation and go to inform the King and Duke, giving them Mary Jane's supposed love and kisses.

Huck feels satisfied with his elaborate deception, confident that the girls will remain silent due to their desire to go to England, and that the King and Duke will be content with Mary Jane being away, thus keeping her from encountering Doctor Robinson. He prides himself on handling the situation skillfully.

“It ain’t no name for it. They set up with her all night, Miss Mary Jane said, and they don’t think she’ll last many hours.”
“Only think of that, now! What’s the matter with her?”
I couldn’t think of anything reasonable, right off that way, so I says:
“Mumps.”
“Mumps your granny! They don’t set up with people that’s got the mumps.”
“They don’t, don’t they? You better bet they do with these mumps. These mumps is different. It’s a new kind, Miss Mary Jane said.”
“How’s it a new kind?”
“Because it’s mixed up with other things.”
“What other things?”
“Well, measles, and whooping-cough, and erysiplas, and consumption, and yaller janders, and brain-fever, and I don’t know what all.”
“My land! And they call it the mumps?”
“That’s what Miss Mary Jane said.”
“Well, what in the nation do they call it the mumps for?”
“Why, because it is the mumps. That’s what it starts with.”
“Well, ther’ ain’t no sense in it. A body might stump his toe, and take pison, and fall down the well, and break his neck, and bust his brains out, and somebody come along and ask what killed him, and some numskull up and say, ‘Why, he stumped his toe.’ Would ther’ be any sense in that? No. And ther’ ain’t no sense in this, nuther. Is it ketching?”
“Is it ketching? Why, how you talk. Is a harrow catching—in the dark? If you don’t hitch on to one tooth, you’re bound to on another, ain’t you? And you can’t get away with that tooth without fetching the whole harrow along, can you? Well, these kind of mumps is a kind of a harrow, as you may say—and it ain’t no slouch of a harrow, nuther, you come to get it hitched on good.”
“Well, it’s awful, I think,” says the hare-lip. “I’ll go to Uncle Harvey and—”
“Oh, yes,” I says, “I would. Of course I would. I wouldn’t lose no time.”
“Well, why wouldn’t you?”
“Just look at it a minute, and maybe you can see. Hain’t your uncles obleegd to get along home to England as fast as they can? And do you reckon they’d be mean enough to go off and leave you to go all that journey by yourselves? You know they’ll wait for you. So fur, so good. Your uncle Harvey’s a preacher, ain’t he? Very well, then; is a preacher going to deceive a steamboat clerk? is he going to deceive a ship clerk?—so as to get them to let Miss Mary Jane go aboard? Now you know he ain’t. What will he do, then? Why, he’ll say, ‘It’s a great pity, but my church matters has got to get along the best way they can; for my niece has been exposed to the dreadful pluribus-unum mumps, and so it’s my bounden duty to set down here and wait the three months it takes to show on her if she’s got it.’ But never mind, if you think it’s best to tell your uncle Harvey—”
“Shucks, and stay fooling around here when we could all be having good times in England whilst we was waiting to find out whether Mary Jane’s got it or not? Why, you talk like a muggins.”
“Well, anyway, maybe you’d better tell some of the neighbors.”
“Listen at that, now. You do beat all for natural stupidness. Can’t you see that they’d go and tell? Ther’ ain’t no way but just to not tell anybody at all.”
“Well, maybe you’re right—yes, I judge you are right.”
“But I reckon we ought to tell Uncle Harvey she’s gone out a while, anyway, so he won’t be uneasy about her?”
“Yes, Miss Mary Jane she wanted you to do that. She says, ‘Tell them to give Uncle Harvey and William my love and a kiss, and say I’ve run over the river to see Mr.’—Mr.—what is the name of that rich family your uncle Peter used to think so much of?—I mean the one that—”
“Why, you must mean the Apthorps, ain’t it?”
“Of course; bother them kind of names, a body can’t ever seem to remember them, half the time, somehow. Yes, she said, say she has run over for to ask the Apthorps to be sure and come to the auction and buy this house, because she allowed her uncle Peter would ruther they had it than anybody else; and she’s going to stick to them till they say they’ll come, and then, if she ain’t too tired, she’s coming home; and if she is, she’ll be home in the morning anyway. She said, don’t say nothing about the Proctors, but only about the Apthorps—which’ll be perfectly true, because she is going there to speak about their buying the house; I know it, because she told me so herself.”
“All right,” they said, and cleared out to lay for their uncles, and give them the love and the kisses, and tell them the message.
Everything was all right now. The girls wouldn’t say nothing because they wanted to go to England; and the king and the duke would ruther Mary Jane was off working for the auction than around in reach of Doctor Robinson. I felt very good; I judged I had done it pretty neat—I reckoned Tom Sawyer couldn’t a done it no neater himself. Of course he would a throwed more style into it, but I can’t do that very handy, not being brung up to it.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
**Chapter 29: Mary Jane’s Escape**  

When I saw Mary Jane slip out the back way, my heart near about jumped out of my chest. She was gone quick as a flash, and nobody took notice—not even the king and the duke, who were too busy jawing with the townsfolk about the gold being stolen. I reckon she must’ve run straight for the Wilkses’ place, or maybe to Judge Thatcher’s, to tell him the whole crooked business.  

The crowd was in an uproar, all shouting and carrying on like a pack of wild dogs. Some were for hanging the king and the duke right then and there, while others wanted to lock ’em up till the sheriff could sort things out. The two frauds were sweating bullets, their faces white as chalk, and the duke kept tugging at his collar like it was choking him.  

Then old Levi Bell, the lawyer, spoke up. “Hold on, now,” he says. “We ain’t got no proof these men stole that money. For all we know, somebody else could’ve took it.”  

That set the crowd to muttering, but Doctor Robinson wasn’t having none of it. “Proof?” he hollers. “Why, we got all the proof we need! These scoundrels been lying through their teeth since they got here, pretending to be Peter Wilks’s brothers. Ain’t that proof enough?”  

The king, seeing he was in a tight spot, put on his most pitiful face. “Gentlemen,” he says, wringing his hands, “we’re poor, misguided souls, that’s all. We never meant no harm. If we’ve done wrong, it’s only because we loved our dear departed brother so much.”  

I nearly gagged hearing that, but some of the softer-hearted folks in the crowd started looking sorry for him. That’s the way with a smooth talker—he can twist folks around his finger if they ain’t careful.  

Just then, somebody shouts from the back of the room, “Where’s the other sister? Where’s Mary Jane?”  

That set off a fresh wave of confusion. The king and the duke exchanged a quick look, and I could see the panic in their eyes. If Mary Jane had gone to fetch help, they were done for.  

“She—she’s taken poorly,” the duke stammers. “Yes, that’s it. The poor girl’s overcome with grief and had to lie down.”  

But the crowd wasn’t buying it. A couple of men went off to search the house, and when they came back saying she wasn’t there, things got real ugly.  

“They’ve done something to her!” a woman shrieks. “Just like they done to that poor dead Peter Wilks!”  

The king and the duke were backed into a corner now, and I could see they were fixing to make a run for it. But before they could move, the door bursts open, and in walks—Mary Jane herself!  

Only she wasn’t alone. Behind her was Judge Thatcher, looking stern as a hanging judge, and a couple of constables with their pistols drawn.  

“There they are!” Mary Jane cries, pointing at the king and the duke. “Those men are frauds and thieves!”  

Well, that settled it. The crowd let out a roar, and the two scoundrels were seized before they could so much as blink. The constables clapped ’em in irons, and Judge Thatcher turned to the crowd.  

“These men will stand trial for their crimes,” he says. “And as for the money, we’ll see it returned to its rightful owners.”  

Mary Jane looked at me then, and there was something in her eyes—like she knew I’d had a hand in all this, but she wasn’t mad. Maybe even a little grateful.  

I reckon that was the end of the king and the duke’s reign of swindling in that town. But as for me, I knew it was high time to light out myself. Things were getting too hot, and I still had Jim to think about.  

So while everybody was celebrating and carrying on, I slipped out the back way—just like Mary Jane had done. Only difference was, I wasn’t coming back.

events.title: The Auction's Climax and the Arrival of True Claimants
detailed_summary: The auction of Peter Wilks's property takes place in the public square towards the end of the afternoon, proceeding slowly.
The King (the 'old man') is present next to the auctioneer, maintaining his fraudulent persona by interjecting with pious remarks and bits of Scripture.
The Duke is also active, mingling with the crowd and attempting to evoke sympathy with feigned sorrow.
After a lengthy process, nearly everything is sold, except for a small, insignificant lot in the graveyard which the King is eager to offload.
While they are still trying to sell this last piece of property, a steamboat arrives at the landing.
Within minutes, a noisy crowd disembarks from the steamboat, shouting, laughing, and creating a commotion as they make their way up from the river.
The newcomers dramatically announce their arrival, proclaiming themselves as the 'opposition line' and presenting 'two sets of heirs to old Peter Wilks,' offering the townspeople a choice.

events.title: Arrival of the True Heirs
detailed_summary: Two new individuals, an older gentleman and a younger man with his arm in a sling, are brought into town, causing amusement among the crowd.
Huck, the narrator, does not find the situation humorous and anticipates that the duke and king will be disconcerted.
Contrary to Huck's expectation, the duke acts innocently pleased, while the king feigns sorrow over the appearance of what he implies are more impostors.
Several prominent townspeople show their allegiance by gathering around the king.
The newly arrived older gentleman appears utterly perplexed by the situation.
He addresses the crowd, revealing an authentic English accent, different from the king's imitation.
He introduces himself as Harvey Wilks and his companion as his brother William, who is deaf, mute, and further hampered by a broken arm.
Harvey explains their recent misfortunes: William's injury and their baggage being mistakenly left at a different town upriver.
He asserts their true identities and declares their intention to prove them upon the arrival of their baggage in a day or two, stating they will wait at the local hotel.

events.text_segment:
They was fetching a very nice-looking old gentleman along, and a nice-looking younger one, with his right arm in a sling. And, my souls, how the people yelled and laughed, and kept it up. But I didn’t see no joke about it, and I judged it would strain the duke and the king some to see any. I reckoned they’d turn pale. But no, nary a pale did they turn. The duke he never let on he suspicioned what was up, but just went a goo-gooing around, happy and satisfied, like a jug that’s googling out buttermilk; and as for the king, he just gazed and gazed down sorrowful on them new-comers like it give him the stomach-ache in his very heart to think there could be such frauds and rascals in the world. Oh, he done it admirable. Lots of the principal people gethered around the king, to let him see they was on his side. That old gentleman that had just come looked all puzzled to death. Pretty soon he begun to speak, and I see straight off he pronounced like an Englishman—not the king’s way, though the king’s was pretty good for an imitation. I can’t give the old gent’s words, nor I can’t imitate him; but he turned around to the crowd, and says, about like this:
“This is a surprise to me which I wasn’t looking for; and I’ll acknowledge, candid and frank, I ain’t very well fixed to meet it and answer it; for my brother and me has had misfortunes; he’s broke his arm, and our baggage got put off at a town above here last night in the night by a mistake. I am Peter Wilks’ brother Harvey, and this is his brother William, which can’t hear nor speak—and can’t even make signs to amount to much, now’t he’s only got one hand to work them with. We are who we say we are; and in a day or two, when I get the baggage, I can prove it. But up till then I won’t say nothing more, but go to the hotel and wait.”

They was fetching a very nice-looking old gentleman along, and a nice-looking younger one, with his right arm in a sling. The old man had a kind face, with white hair and spectacles perched on his nose, while the younger one, though pale from his injury, carried himself with a quiet dignity. I reckoned they must be quality folks by the way they carried themselves—not like the rough river men I was used to seeing.

The old gentleman tipped his hat as they came aboard, and the younger one nodded politely, though his eyes kept darting around like he was nervous about something. I couldn’t help but wonder what had happened to his arm—whether it was an accident or something more sinister. There was a story there, I was sure of it, but I knew better than to ask outright. Folks on the river had their secrets, and it wasn’t my place to pry.

The steamboat’s whistle blew, and we set off down the river, the paddlewheel churning up the muddy water. The old man struck up a conversation with the captain, talking about the weather and the state of the river, while the younger one leaned against the railing, staring off into the distance. I sidled up near enough to catch bits of their talk, hoping to learn something interesting.

“Trouble up north,” the old man murmured, lowering his voice. “They say there’s been some unrest near the border.”

The captain grunted. “Ain’t no surprise these days. Folks is restless everywhere.”

The younger man’s jaw tightened, but he didn’t say a word. I got the feeling he knew more than he was letting on. Maybe that arm of his wasn’t just an accident after all. Maybe he’d been mixed up in something dangerous.

I decided then and there to keep an eye on those two. Wherever they were headed, I had a hunch it wasn’t just a pleasure trip.

events.title: The King's Deflection and Hines's Accusation
detailed_summary: As the genuine Wilks brothers depart for the hotel, the king vociferously derides their explanation, suggesting their misfortunes are fabrications typical of frauds.
The majority of the onlookers laugh in agreement with the king.
However, a small group, including Doctor Robinson and a lawyer named Levi Bell, who has just arrived by steamboat, remain unconvinced and are seen conferring quietly.
A local man, identified later as Hines, steps forward and directly confronts the king about his account of arriving in town.
The king reiterates his claim of arriving by steamboat from Cincinnati the evening before the funeral.
Hines sharply contradicts the king, stating he personally saw the king, along with Tim Collins and a boy, at 'the Pint' that very morning, having arrived in a canoe.
Doctor Robinson inquires if Hines would recognize the boy again.
Hines immediately points to Huck, confirming him as the boy he saw with the king.

Doctor Robinson then addresses the crowd, expressing his conviction that the king and duke are impostors and proposing they all go to the tavern to confront the two pairs of claimants to ascertain the truth.

events.text_segment:
So him and the new dummy started off; and the king he laughs, and blethers out:
“Broke his arm—very likely, ain’t it?—and very convenient, too, for a fraud that’s got to make signs, and ain’t learnt how. Lost their baggage! That’s mighty good!—and mighty ingenious—under the circumstances!”
So he laughed again; and so did everybody else, except three or four, or maybe half a dozen. One of these was that doctor; another one was a sharp-looking gentleman, with a carpet-bag of the old-fashioned kind made out of carpet-stuff, that had just come off of the steamboat and was talking to him in a low voice, and glancing towards the king now and then and nodding their heads—it was Levi Bell, the lawyer that was gone up to Louisville; and another one was a big rough husky that come along and listened to all the old gentleman said, and was listening to the king now. And when the king got done this husky up and says:
“Say, looky here; if you are Harvey Wilks, when’d you come to this town?”
“The day before the funeral, friend,” says the king.
“But what time o’ day?”
“In the evenin’—’bout an hour er two before sundown.”
“How’d you come?”
“I come down on the Susan Powell from Cincinnati.”

events.title: The Investigation Begins: The Missing Gold
detailed_summary: The crowd, eager for the confrontation, proceeds with all parties to a spacious room in the hotel, where candles are lit.
Doctor Robinson voices his suspicion that the king and duke are frauds and expresses concern that any accomplices they might have could escape with Peter Wilks's gold.
He suggests that if the king and duke are genuine, they should not oppose sending for the money and allowing the townsfolk to keep it safe until their identities are proven.
The king, affecting a sorrowful demeanor, agrees with the sentiment but declares that the money is unfortunately no longer where it was.
He fabricates a story, claiming he hid the gold inside his straw mattress for safekeeping, as he was unaccustomed to 'niggers' and assumed their honesty like English servants.
He alleges that the slaves, whom he subsequently sold, stole the gold the very next morning after he had hidden it, and he hadn't missed it before their departure.
He further states that his 'servant,' Huck, can attest to these events.
The doctor and several others react with audible disbelief to the king's tale.

When questioned, Huck claims he did not witness the slaves stealing the money but did see them surreptitiously leaving the room and hurrying away, which he had assumed was due to fear of having awakened his master.

It was nuts for the crowd, though maybe not for the king’s friends; so we all started. It was about sundown. The doctor he led me along by the hand, and was plenty kind enough, but he never let go my hand.
We all got in a big room in the hotel, and lit up some candles, and fetched in the new couple. First, the doctor says:
“I don’t wish to be too hard on these two men, but I think they’re frauds, and they may have complices that we don’t know nothing about. If they have, won’t the complices get away with that bag of gold Peter Wilks left? It ain’t unlikely. If these men ain’t frauds, they won’t object to sending for that money and letting us keep it till they prove they’re all right—ain’t that so?”
Everybody agreed to that. So I judged they had our gang in a pretty tight place right at the outstart. But the king he only looked sorrowful, and says:
“Gentlemen, I wish the money was there, for I ain’t got no disposition to throw anything in the way of a fair, open, out-and-out investigation o’ this misable business; but, alas, the money ain’t there; you k’n send and see, if you want to.”
“Where is it, then?”
“Well, when my niece give it to me to keep for her I took and hid it inside o’ the straw tick o’ my bed, not wishin’ to bank it for the few days we’d be here, and considerin’ the bed a safe place, we not bein’ used to niggers, and suppos’n’ ’em honest, like servants in England. The niggers stole it the very next mornin’ after I had went down stairs; and when I sold ’em I hadn’t missed the money yit, so they got clean away with it. My servant here k’n tell you ’bout it, gentlemen.”
The doctor and several said “Shucks!” and I see nobody didn’t altogether believe him. One man asked me if I see the niggers steal it. I said no, but I see them sneaking out of the room and hustling away, and I never thought nothing, only I reckoned they was afraid they had waked up my master and was trying to get away before he made trouble with them. That was all they asked me.

It was nuts for the crowd, though maybe not for the king’s friends; so we all started. The king and the duke had been putting on their show for days, swindling folks out of their hard-earned money with their phony performances. But this time, things took a turn nobody expected. The townspeople had caught wind of their tricks, and before long, the whole place was in an uproar.  

We lit out of there as fast as we could, Huck and me, with the king and the duke stumbling behind us, their fancy clothes all torn and their faces pale with fear. The mob was hot on our heels, shouting and waving torches like something out of a nightmare. I reckon they’d had enough of being fooled, and now they meant to teach those two frauds a lesson they wouldn’t forget.  

We ducked into the woods, branches whipping at our faces as we ran. The king was wheezing like an old bellows, and the duke kept muttering curses under his breath. Huck, quick as ever, found a hollow log big enough for us to hide in, and we all squeezed inside just as the mob came crashing past.  

For a long while, we didn’t dare move. The shouts and the flickering torchlight faded into the distance, but none of us felt safe yet. The king finally broke the silence, whispering, “That was a mighty close call, boys. Mighty close.”  

Huck just looked at me, and I could tell he was thinking the same thing I was—that we’d be better off without these two rascals. But for now, we were stuck with them, and the night wasn’t over yet. Somewhere out there, the angry crowd was still hunting, and come morning, we’d have to figure out our next move.  

One thing was certain: the king and the duke’s days of easy pickings were done. And if we weren’t careful, we’d be caught in the middle when the reckoning came.

events.title: Huck's Interrogation and Awkward Testimony
detailed_summary: Doctor Robinson abruptly turns his attention to Huck and questions if he is also English.
Huck affirms that he is, which elicits laughter and expressions of disbelief, such as 'Stuff!', from the doctor and others.
A lengthy and disorganized general investigation commences, continuing for hours without any mention of supper.
Both the king and the newly arrived old gentleman (the real Harvey Wilks) are compelled to share their respective narratives.
Huck privately observes that any unbiased person would easily discern that the old gentleman was telling the truth while the king was lying.
Eventually, Huck is called upon to provide his account of events.
The king gives Huck a subtle, sidelong glance, which Huck understands as a cue to support the king's version of the story.
Huck begins to invent details about their supposed life in Sheffield and information about the English Wilks family.
He does not get very far into his fabricated tale before Doctor Robinson starts to laugh.
Levi Bell, the lawyer, interjects, advising Huck to stop, remarking on his apparent lack of experience and skill in lying, and suggesting he needs more practice.
Although Huck doesn't appreciate the nature of the 'compliment,' he is relieved to be excused from further testimony.

Then the doctor whirls on me and says:
“Are you English, too?”
I says yes; and him and some others laughed, and said, “Stuff!”
Well, then they sailed in on the general investigation, and there we had it, up and down, hour in, hour out, and nobody never said a word about supper, nor ever seemed to think about it—and so they kept it up, and kept it up; and it was the worst mixed-up thing you ever see. They made the king tell his yarn, and they made the old gentleman tell his’n; and anybody but a lot of prejudiced chuckleheads would a seen that the old gentleman was spinning truth and t’other one lies. And by-and-by they had me up to tell what I knowed. The king he give me a left-handed look out of the corner of his eye, and so I knowed enough to talk on the right side. I begun to tell about Sheffield, and how we lived there, and all about the English Wilkses, and so on; but I didn’t get pretty fur till the doctor begun to laugh; and Levi Bell, the lawyer, says:
“Set down, my boy; I wouldn’t strain myself if I was you. I reckon you ain’t used to lying, it don’t seem to come handy; what you want is practice. You do it pretty awkward.”
I didn’t care nothing for the compliment, but I was glad to be let off, anyway.

"Tom Sawyer, I always knew you was a troublesome boy, but I never thought you'd go this far! What in tarnation were you thinking, helping that runaway nigger? “Now, I ain’t saying he’s innocent,” the doctor went on, “but I’ve seen the way he tended to that young feller—Tom Sawyer, wasn’t it?—and I tell you, no man with a wicked heart would’ve done what he did. Old man Silas, who’d been standing at the back with his arms crossed, stepped forward. “Decent or not, he’s still a runaway n*****, and the law’s the law. Ain’t no place for sentiment when it comes to property.”  

The doctor’s face darkened. “Property? That’s a man you’re talking about, Silas. A man who showed more kindness than half the folks in this town.”  

A few in the crowd shifted uncomfortably, but most held their ground. Then Aunt Sally, who’d been listening quietly, spoke up. “Well, I don’t know about all that, but I do know that boy—Jim—he saved Tom’s life. And if that don’t count for something, then I don’t know what does.”  

The doctor nodded at her, grateful for the support. “Exactly. Now, I ain’t saying we ought to just let him go free, but maybe we ought to think twice before we send him back to that Miss Watson. From what I hear, she ain’t exactly the merciful sort.”  

That got folks whispering again. Some remembered the stories about Miss Watson’s temper, how she’d sold off other slaves for the slightest offenses. A few even looked ashamed.  

Just then, Huck, who’d been standing off to the side, his heart pounding, couldn’t take it no more. He stepped forward, his voice shaky but determined. “Jim ain’t just decent—he’s the best man I ever knew. He protected me, taught me things, and he never once complained, no matter how bad things got. If anybody deserves to be free, it’s him.”

Well, what do you think? That muleheaded old fool wouldn’t give in then! Indeed he wouldn’t. Said it warn’t no fair test. Said his brother William was the cussedest joker in the world, and hadn’t tried to write—he see William was going to play one of his jokes the minute he put the pen to paper. And so he warmed up and went warbling and warbling right along till he was actuly beginning to believe what he was saying himself; but pretty soon the new gentleman broke in, and says:
“I’ve thought of something. Is there anybody here that helped to lay out my br—helped to lay out the late Peter Wilks for burying?”
“Yes,” says somebody, “me and Ab Turner done it. We’re both here.”
Then the old man turns towards the king, and says:
“Perhaps this gentleman can tell me what was tattooed on his breast?”
Blamed if the king didn’t have to brace up mighty quick, or he’d a squshed down like a bluff bank that the river has cut under, it took him so sudden; and, mind you, it was a thing that was calculated to make most anybody sqush to get fetched such a solid one as that without any notice, because how was he going to know what was tattooed on the man? He whitened a little; he couldn’t help it; and it was mighty still in there, and everybody bending a little forwards and gazing at him. Says I to myself, Now he’ll throw up the sponge—there ain’t no more use. Well, did he? A body can’t hardly believe it, but he didn’t. I reckon he thought he’d keep the thing up till he tired them people out, so they’d thin out, and him and the duke could break loose and get away. Anyway, he set there, and pretty soon he begun to smile, and says:
“Mf! It’s a very tough question, ain’t it! Yes, sir, I k’n tell you what’s tattooed on his breast. It’s jest a small, thin, blue arrow—that’s what it is; and if you don’t look clost, you can’t see it. Now what do you say—hey?”
Well, I never see anything like that old blister for clean out-and-out cheek.
The new old gentleman turns brisk towards Ab Turner and his pard, and his eye lights up like he judged he’d got the king this time, and says:
“There—you’ve heard what he said! Was there any such mark on Peter Wilks’ breast?”
Both of them spoke up and says:
“We didn’t see no such mark.”
“Good!” says the old gentleman. “Now, what you did see on his breast was a small dim P, and a B (which is an initial he dropped when he was young), and a W, with dashes between them, so: P—B—W”—and he marked them that way on a piece of paper. “Come, ain’t that what you saw?”
Both of them spoke up again, and says:
“No, we didn’t. We never seen any marks at all.”

**Well, what do you think?**  

That’s the question I reckon folks ask themselves after reading *Adventures of Huckleberry Finn*. Some say it’s the greatest American novel ever written, while others argue it’s got its share of troubles—especially with the way it handles race and language. But one thing’s for sure: it ain’t a book you can just shrug off.  

Mark Twain sure knew how to spin a yarn, and Huck Finn’s voice is so real, you’d swear he was sitting right there on the porch telling you his story. The way he talks—rough around the edges, full of slang and misspellings—makes him feel alive. It’s like he’s not some fancy literary character but a real boy, one who’s seen too much and ain’t quite sure what to make of it.  

Then there’s Jim. Now, that’s where things get complicated. Some folks say Twain was ahead of his time, showing Jim as a man with dignity, a father who misses his family, and a friend who risks everything for Huck. Others say the book still leans on stereotypes, and the way Jim talks—written in heavy dialect—can be hard to read today. It’s a fair point. But I reckon Twain was trying to show the world as it was, ugly bits and all, not how folks wished it to be.  

The heart of the story, though, is Huck’s struggle with what’s *right*. Here’s a boy raised to believe slavery’s natural, that helping a runaway slave is a sin. But when he’s faced with turning Jim in or setting him free, he tears up the letter he meant to send and says, “All right, then, I’ll *go* to hell.” That moment—that’s the whole book right there. It’s about choosing kindness over what society tells you is right.  

Course, the ending’s a different matter. After all that deep thinking, the last few chapters turn into a circus, with Tom Sawyer dragging out Jim’s escape like it’s some grand adventure. It feels like Twain didn’t quite know how to wrap things up, so he threw in a bunch of nonsense to lighten the mood. Some say it ruins the book; others say it’s just Twain having fun. Either way, it’s a strange shift.  

But maybe that’s the point. Life ain’t neat and tidy. Huck’s world is full of contradictions—cruelty and kindness, ignorance and wisdom, all mixed together. The book doesn’t give easy answers, and that’s what makes it stick with you.  

So, what do I think? I think *Huckleberry Finn* is messy, brilliant, frustrating, and important. It’s a book that makes you *uncomfortable*, and maybe that’s why we’re still talking about it over a hundred years later. It forces us to look at the past—and ourselves—square in the face. And if a story can do that, well, I reckon it’s done its job.  

What about you? What do *you* think?

events.title: Decision to Exhume the Body
detailed_summary: The contradictory testimonies regarding the tattoo leave the crowd utterly confused and agitated.
Many begin to shout that all the claimants are frauds and call for violent retribution, such as ducking, drowning, or riding them on a rail.
Amidst the uproar, the lawyer, Levi Bell, jumps onto a table, yelling to gain the crowd's attention and pleading for a moment to speak.
He proposes one final method to resolve the matter: exhuming Peter Wilks's corpse to directly examine it for any identifying marks.
This suggestion immediately captures the crowd's approval, and they shout their agreement, ready to proceed at once.
The lawyer and Doctor Robinson interject, instructing the crowd to detain all four men—the king, the duke, and the two real Wilks brothers—as well as Huck, and bring them to the graveyard.
The crowd enthusiastically agrees, vowing to lynch the entire group if the specified marks are not found on the body.
Huck admits to being deeply frightened by this dangerous turn of events.

“Gentlemen—gentlemen! Hear me just a word—just a single word—if you PLEASE! There’s one way yet—let’s go and dig up the corpse and look.”

But there warn’t no getting away, you know. They gripped us all, and marched us right along, straight for the graveyard, which was a mile and a half down the river, and the whole town at our heels, for we made noise enough, and it was only nine in the evening.
As we went by our house I wished I hadn’t sent Mary Jane out of town; because now if I could tip her the wink she’d light out and save me, and blow on our dead-beats.
Well, we swarmed along down the river road, just carrying on like wildcats; and to make it more scary the sky was darking up, and the lightning beginning to wink and flitter, and the wind to shiver amongst the leaves. This was the most awful trouble and most dangersome I ever was in; and I was kinder stunned; everything was going so different from what I had allowed for; stead of being fixed so I could take my own time if I wanted to, and see all the fun, and have Mary Jane at my back to save me and set me free when the close-fit come, here was nothing in the world betwixt me and sudden death but just them tattoo-marks. If they didn’t find them—
I couldn’t bear to think about it; and yet, somehow, I couldn’t think about nothing else. It got darker and darker, and it was a beautiful time to give the crowd the slip; but that big husky had me by the wrist—Hines—and a body might as well try to give Goliar the slip. He dragged me right along, he was so excited, and I had to run to keep up.
When they got there they swarmed into the graveyard and washed over it like an overflow. And when they got to the grave they found they had about a hundred times as many shovels as they wanted, but nobody hadn’t thought to fetch a lantern. But they sailed into digging anyway by the flicker of the lightning, and sent a man to the nearest house, a half a mile off, to borrow one.
So they dug and dug like everything; and it got awful dark, and the rain started, and the wind swished and swushed along, and the lightning come brisker and brisker, and the thunder boomed; but them people never took no notice of it, they was so full of this business; and one minute you could see everything and every face in that big crowd, and the shovelfuls of dirt sailing up out of the grave, and the next second the dark wiped it all out, and you couldn’t see nothing at all.
At last they got out the coffin and begun to unscrew the lid, and then such another crowding and shouldering and shoving as there was, to scrouge in and get a sight, you never see; and in the dark, that way, it was awful. Hines he hurt my wrist dreadful pulling and tugging so, and I reckon he clean forgot I was in the world, he was so excited and panting.
All of a sudden the lightning let go a perfect sluice of white glare, and somebody sings out:
“By the living jingo, here’s the bag of gold on his breast!”
Hines let out a whoop, like everybody else, and dropped my wrist and give a big surge to bust his way in and get a look, and the way I lit out and shinned for the road in the dark there ain’t nobody can tell.

When I struck the town I see there warn’t nobody out in the storm, so I never hunted for no back streets, but humped it straight through the main one; and when I begun to get towards our house I aimed my eye and set it. No light there; the house all dark—which made me feel sorry and disappointed, I didn’t know why. But at last, just as I was sailing by, flash comes the light in Mary Jane’s window! and my heart swelled up sudden, like to bust; and the same second the house and all was behind me in the dark, and wasn’t ever going to be before me no more in this world. She was the best girl I ever see, and had the most sand.
The minute I was far enough above the town to see I could make the tow-head, I begun to look sharp for a boat to borrow, and the first time the lightning showed me one that wasn’t chained I snatched it and shoved. It was a canoe, and warn’t fastened with nothing but a rope. The tow-head was a rattling big distance off, away out there in the middle of the river, but I didn’t lose no time; and when I struck the raft at last I was so fagged I would a just laid down to blow and gasp if I could afforded it. But I didn’t. As I sprung aboard I sung out:
“Out with you, Jim, and set her loose! Glory be to goodness, we’re shut of them!”
Jim lit out, and was a-coming for me with both arms spread, he was so full of joy; but when I glimpsed him in the lightning my heart shot up in my mouth and I went overboard backwards; for I forgot he was old King Lear and a drownded A-rab all in one, and it most scared the livers and lights out of me. But Jim fished me out, and was going to hug me and bless me, and so on, he was so glad I was back and we was shut of the king and the duke, but I says:
“Not now; have it for breakfast, have it for breakfast! Cut loose and let her slide!”

detailed_summary: Upon boarding the raft, the King physically confronts Huck, accusing him of attempting to abandon them.
Huck, feigning distress, fabricates a story about his escape, explaining that during the commotion over the discovered gold, a sympathetic man warned him to flee to avoid being hanged.

He further states that he quickly ran to the canoe, instructed Jim to hurry, and expressed his fear that the King and Duke might not be alive, professing his sorrow.
Jim supports Huck's account, but the King silences Jim and, expressing disbelief, threatens to drown Huck.
The Duke intervenes, ordering the King to release Huck and challenging the King by asking if he would have acted differently or if he had made any effort to find Huck after his own escape.

“Tryin’ to give us the slip, was ye, you pup! Tired of our company, hey?”
I says:
“No, your majesty, we warn’t—please don’t, your majesty!”
“Quick, then, and tell us what was your idea, or I’ll shake the insides out o’ you!”
“Honest, I’ll tell you everything just as it happened, your majesty. The man that had a-holt of me was very good to me, and kept saying he had a boy about as big as me that died last year, and he was sorry to see a boy in such a dangerous fix; and when they was all took by surprise by finding the gold, and made a rush for the coffin, he lets go of me and whispers, ‘Heel it now, or they’ll hang ye, sure!’ and I lit out. It didn’t seem no good for me to stay—I couldn’t do nothing, and I didn’t want to be hung if I could get away. So I never stopped running till I found the canoe; and when I got here I told Jim to hurry, or they’d catch me and hang me yet, and said I was afeard you and the duke wasn’t alive now, and I was awful sorry, and so was Jim, and was awful glad when we see you coming; you may ask Jim if I didn’t.”
Jim said it was so; and the king told him to shut up, and said, “Oh, yes, it’s mighty likely!” and shook me up again, and said he reckoned he’d drownd me. But the duke says:
“Leggo the boy, you old idiot! Would you a done any different? Did you inquire around for him when you got loose? I don’t remember it.”

So the king let go of me, and begun to cuss that town and everybody in it. But the duke says:
“You better a blame sight give yourself a good cussing, for you’re the one that’s entitled to it most. You hain’t done a thing from the start that had any sense in it, except coming out so cool and cheeky with that imaginary blue-arrow mark. That was bright—it was right down bully; and it was the thing that saved us. For if it hadn’t been for that, they’d a jailed us till them Englishmen’s baggage come—and then—the penitentiary, you bet! But that trick took ’em to the graveyard, and the gold done us a still bigger kindness; for if the excited fools hadn’t let go all holts and made that rush to get a look, we’d a slept in our cravats to-night—cravats warranted to wear, too—longer than we’d need ’em.”
They was still a minute—thinking; then the king says, kind of absent-minded like:
“Mf! And we reckoned the niggers stole it!”
That made me squirm!
“Yes,” says the duke, kinder slow and deliberate and sarcastic, “We did.”

The duke finally spoke up, his voice slick as oil. “Your Majesty, perhaps we ought to consider this a lesson in humility. The Lord giveth, and the Lord taketh away.”

The king whirled on him. “Don’t you start preachin’ at me, you two-bit ham actor! If you hadn’t bungled that last scene, we’d have cleared a hundred at least!”

That set ‘em off again, squabbling like a pair of wet hens. I edged toward the wigwam, figuring I’d let ‘em wear themselves out. But just then, the king rounded on me, his eyes narrowin’ like a snake’s. 

“Huck,” he said, too sweet-like, “you wouldn’t know nothin’ about where our real money went, would ya?”

My stomach dropped. I shook my head fast. “No, sir, I sure don’t.” 

He studied me a minute longer, then grunted. “Best keep it that way.” 

I reckon I was in for more trouble. But then again, trouble and me was old friends by then.

events.title: The King's Forced Confession and Drunken Reconciliation
detailed_summary: The Duke directly accuses the King of having hidden the money in the coffin himself.
The King vehemently denies this, prompting the Duke to physically assault him by grabbing his throat.
Under duress, the King quickly retracts his denial.
The Duke then forces the King to confess that he hid the money with the intention of deceiving the Duke later, returning to retrieve it, and keeping it all for himself.
The King attempts to deflect by asking the Duke if he hadn't also considered hiding the money.
The Duke admits the thought had crossed his mind but states he didn't act on it, contrasting this with the King, whom he insists both thought of it and did it.
The King makes one last, desperate denial but, as the Duke continues to choke him, finally gasps out a confession.
Huck expresses his immense relief upon hearing the King's admission.

The Duke releases the King, warning him against ever denying it again, and then launches into a tirade, berating the King for his insatiable greed, for allowing innocent slaves to be blamed, and for his deceitful behavior.
The King meekly attempts to shift blame regarding a previous financial discrepancy, but the Duke dismisses him.
The Duke concludes by pointing out that their actions have led to them losing all the stolen money and most of their own funds.
The King retreats to the wigwam and begins drinking, soon joined by the Duke.
Within about half an hour, both are heavily intoxicated, becoming affectionately close and eventually falling asleep arm-in-arm.
Huck observes that, despite his drunkenness, the King seems to remember not to deny his confession about the money bag, which makes Huck feel secure.
Once the two conmen are snoring, Huck recounts all these events to Jim.

“Yes, sir! I know you do know, because you done it yourself!”
“It’s a lie!”—and the duke went for him. The king sings out:
“Take y’r hands off!—leggo my throat!—I take it all back!”
The duke says:
“Well, you just own up, first, that you did hide that money there, intending to give me the slip one of these days, and come back and dig it up, and have it all to yourself.”
“Wait jest a minute, duke—answer me this one question, honest and fair; if you didn’t put the money there, say it, and I’ll b’lieve you, and take back everything I said.”
“You old scoundrel, I didn’t, and you know I didn’t. There, now!”
“Well, then, I b’lieve you. But answer me only jest this one more—now don’t git mad; didn’t you have it in your mind to hook the money and hide it?”
The duke never said nothing for a little bit; then he says:
“Well, I don’t care if I did, I didn’t do it, anyway. But you not only had it in mind to do it, but you done it.”
“I wisht I never die if I done it, duke, and that’s honest. I won’t say I warn’t goin’ to do it, because I was; but you—I mean somebody—got in ahead o’ me.”
“It’s a lie! You done it, and you got to say you done it, or—”
The king began to gurgle, and then he gasps out:
“’Nough!—I own up!”
I was very glad to hear him say that; it made me feel much more easier than what I was feeling before. So the duke took his hands off and says:
“If you ever deny it again I’ll drown you. It’s well for you to set there and blubber like a baby—it’s fitten for you, after the way you’ve acted. I never see such an old ostrich for wanting to gobble everything—and I a-trusting you all the time, like you was my own father. You ought to been ashamed of yourself to stand by and hear it saddled on to a lot of poor niggers, and you never say a word for ’em. It makes me feel ridiculous to think I was soft enough to believe that rubbage. Cuss you, I can see now why you was so anxious to make up the deffisit—you wanted to get what money I’d got out of the Nonesuch and one thing or another, and scoop it all!”
The king says, timid, and still a-snuffling:
“Why, duke, it was you that said make up the deffisit; it warn’t me.”
“Dry up! I don’t want to hear no more out of you!” says the duke. “And now you see what you got by it. They’ve got all their own money back, and all of ourn but a shekel or two besides. G’long to bed, and don’t you deffersit me no more deffersits, long ’s you live!”
So the king sneaked into the wigwam and took to his bottle for comfort, and before long the duke tackled his bottle; and so in about a half an hour they was as thick as thieves again, and the tighter they got, the lovinger they got, and went off a-snoring in each other’s arms. They both got powerful mellow, but I noticed the king didn’t get mellow enough to forget to remember to not deny about hiding the money-bag again. That made me feel easy and satisfied. Of course when they got to snoring we had a long gabble, and I told Jim everything.

“Yes, sir! I know you *do* know, because you done it yourself!” Huck Finn’s voice trembled with a mix of defiance and fear as he stood before the old man, his fists clenched at his sides. The accusation hung heavy in the air, and for a moment, the only sound was the distant murmur of the Mississippi River lapping against the shore.  

The old man’s face darkened, his bushy eyebrows knitting together. “Boy, you best mind your tongue,” he growled, taking a step forward. “Ain’t nobody taught you respect?”  

Huck swallowed hard but didn’t back down. He had seen too much—knew too much—to let it slide now. “Respect’s got to be earned,” he shot back. “And you ain’t done nothin’ to earn it. Not after what I seen.”  

A flicker of unease passed over the old man’s face, but it was gone as quick as it came. He leaned in close, his breath reeking of cheap whiskey. “You think you’re smart, don’t you? Just ‘cause you been floatin’ down the river with that runaway n*****, you reckon you know everything?”  

Huck’s heart pounded. He hadn’t expected the old man to bring up Jim. That was dangerous territory. But he couldn’t let it go. “I know enough,” he said, his voice steadier now. “I know you stole from them folks up in St. Petersburg. I know you lied about it, too, and let somebody else take the blame.”  

The old man’s eyes narrowed. “You got proof of that, boy? Or you just runnin’ your mouth?”  

Huck hesitated. He didn’t have proof—not the kind that would hold up in a court, anyway. But he had seen the way the old man had slipped into that house, seen the way he’d pocketed the silver when he thought nobody was looking. And he’d heard the whispers afterward, the way folks had turned on poor Mister Wilkes, who’d been blamed for the theft.  

“I seen it with my own eyes,” Huck said firmly. “And I reckon others might’ve, too, if they’d been payin’ attention.”  

For a long moment, the old man just stared at him, his expression unreadable. Then, without warning, he lunged, grabbing Huck by the collar. “You listen here, you little rat,” he hissed. “You go spreadin’ tales like that, and you’ll regret it. You hear me?”  

Huck struggled against his grip, but the old man was stronger. Still, he refused to back down. “I ain’t scared of you,” he spat. “And I ain’t gonna let you get away with it no more.”  

The old man’s grip tightened, and for a second, Huck thought he might hit him. But then, just as suddenly, he let go, shoving Huck backward. “Get outta here,” he snarled. “And if I hear one word about this, you’ll wish you’d never been born.”  

Huck stumbled but caught himself, glaring up at the old man. He wanted to say more, to stand his ground, but he knew when to quit—for now. Without another word, he turned and ran, his bare feet kicking up dust as he disappeared into the trees.  

As he ran, his mind raced even faster. He had to do something. He couldn’t let the old man keep getting away with his lies and thieving. But what could a kid like him do against a grown man who didn’t care who he hurt?  

Then it hit him—Jim. Jim would know what to do. Jim always had a way of seeing things clear, even when Huck couldn’t.  

With renewed determination, Huck picked up his pace, heading for the river where he knew Jim would be waiting. This wasn’t over. Not by a long shot.

events.title: The Con Artists' Failing Schemes and Desperation
detailed_summary: The group travels further south, avoiding towns for an extended period as they journey down the river.
They arrive in a warmer climate, where Huck encounters Spanish moss for the first time, finding its appearance made the woods seem solemn and dismal.
Believing they are no longer in danger, the duke and king resume their attempts to swindle people in villages.
Their temperance lecture fails to generate enough money for them to even get drunk.
An attempt to start a dancing school also fails due to their utter lack of dancing ability, resulting in the public chasing them out of town.
Their efforts at elocution are similarly unsuccessful, with the audience verbally abusing them and forcing their departure.
They try various other cons, including missionary work, mesmerism, doctoring, and fortune-telling, but none bring them any luck.
Consequently, they end up completely broke and dejected, spending their days idly on the raft, lost in thought and despair as they float along.

We dasn’t stop again at any town for days and days; kept right along down the river. We was down south in the warm weather now, and a mighty long ways from home. We begun to come to trees with Spanish moss on them, hanging down from the limbs like long, gray beards. It was the first I ever see it growing, and it made the woods look solemn and dismal. So now the frauds reckoned they was out of danger, and they begun to work the villages again.
First they done a lecture on temperance; but they didn’t make enough for them both to get drunk on. Then in another village they started a dancing-school; but they didn’t know no more how to dance than a kangaroo does; so the first prance they made the general public jumped in and pranced them out of town. Another time they tried to go at yellocution; but they didn’t yellocute long till the audience got up and give them a solid good cussing, and made them skip out. They tackled missionarying, and mesmerizing, and doctoring, and telling fortunes, and a little of everything; but they couldn’t seem to have no luck. So at last they got just about dead broke, and laid around the raft as she floated along, thinking and thinking, and never saying nothing, by the half a day at a time, and dreadful blue and desperate.

Jim and me took turns keeping watch, though there warn’t much to watch for ‘cept the occasional steamboat or a passing raft.  

We’d fish when we was hungry, and sometimes we’d pull up to a little island to cook up a meal. Jim could make a fire quicker’n anybody I ever seen, and he’d tell stories while the bacon sizzled—tales about ghosts and witches and such, till I’d get so jumpy I’d near drop my plate. But I never let on I was scared.  

The river was our road, and it felt like the whole world belonged to us. Sometimes we’d see lights twinklin’ far off on shore, but we kept clear. Folks meant trouble, and we had enough of that already. So we just floated, letting the current take us where it would, and for them days, it was like we was the only two people alive.  

Jim said freedom felt like this—just movin’ without nobody tellin’ you to stop. And I reckon he was right.

So we stayed where we was. The duke he fretted and sweated around, and was in a mighty sour way. He scolded us for everything, and we couldn’t seem to do nothing right; he found fault with every little thing. Something was a-brewing, sure. I was good and glad when midday come and no king; we could have a change, anyway—and maybe a chance for the change on top of it. So me and the duke went up to the village, and hunted around there for the king, and by-and-by we found him in the back room of a little low doggery, very tight, and a lot of loafers bullyragging him for sport, and he a-cussing and a-threatening with all his might, and so tight he couldn’t walk, and couldn’t do nothing to them. The duke he begun to abuse him for an old fool, and the king begun to sass back, and the minute they was fairly at it I lit out and shook the reefs out of my hind legs, and spun down the river road like a deer, for I see our chance; and I made up my mind that it would be a long day before they ever see me and Jim again. I got down there all out of breath but loaded up with joy, and sung out:
“Set her loose, Jim! we’re all right now!”
But there warn’t no answer, and nobody come out of the wigwam. Jim was gone! I set up a shout—and then another—and then another one; and run this way and that in the woods, whooping and screeching; but it warn’t no use—old Jim was gone. Then I set down and cried; I couldn’t help it.

The boy attests to the legitimacy of the capture, stating he personally saw the handbill which described Jim perfectly, including the plantation he was from near New Orleans.
After sharing this information, the boy asks Huck for some chewing tobacco, which Huck does not have, and then the boy departs.

But I couldn’t set still long. Pretty soon I went out on the road, trying to think what I better do, and I run across a boy walking, and asked him if he’d seen a strange nigger dressed so and so, and he says:
“Yes.”
“Whereabouts?” says I.
“Down to Silas Phelps’ place, two mile below here. He’s a runaway nigger, and they’ve got him. Was you looking for him?”
“You bet I ain’t! I run across him in the woods about an hour or two ago, and he said if I hollered he’d cut my livers out—and told me to lay down and stay where I was; and I done it. Been there ever since; afeard to come out.”
“Well,” he says, “you needn’t be afeard no more, becuz they’ve got him. He run off f’m down South, som’ers.”
“It’s a good job they got him.”
“Well, I reckon! There’s two hunderd dollars reward on him. It’s like picking up money out’n the road.”
“Yes, it is—and I could a had it if I’d been big enough; I see him first. Who nailed him?”
“It was an old fellow—a stranger—and he sold out his chance in him for forty dollars, becuz he’s got to go up the river and can’t wait. Think o’ that, now! You bet I’d wait, if it was seven year.”
“That’s me, every time,” says I. “But maybe his chance ain’t worth no more than that, if he’ll sell it so cheap. Maybe there’s something ain’t straight about it.”
“But it is, though—straight as a string. I see the handbill myself. It tells all about him, to a dot—paints him like a picture, and tells the plantation he’s frum, below Newrleans. No-sirree-bob, they ain’t no trouble ’bout that speculation, you bet you. Say, gimme a chaw tobacker, won’t ye?”

events.title: Huck's Agonizing Moral Conflict and the Letter of Betrayal
detailed_summary: After the boy leaves, Huck returns to the raft and sits in the wigwam, deep in thought but unable to find a way out of his predicament.

He is devastated by the realization that their entire journey and all their sacrifices have come to naught, all because the con men could betray Jim for a mere forty dollars, condemning him to a life of slavery among strangers.
He briefly entertains the idea that Jim might be better off as a slave back home with his family and considers writing to Tom Sawyer to inform Miss Watson of Jim's location.

However, he quickly abandons this notion, fearing Miss Watson's anger would lead her to sell Jim further down the river, or, if she didn't, Jim would constantly suffer the stigma of being an 'ungrateful' runaway.
Huck then considers the social repercussions for himself: if word got out that he had helped a slave escape, he would face immense shame and ostracism.
He feels trapped by his past actions and the prevailing societal views, recognizing the desire to hide wrongdoing to avoid disgrace.
His conscience plagues him relentlessly, making him feel increasingly wicked and morally debased.

He comes to view Jim's capture as a divine intervention, a sign from Providence punishing him for the sin of aiding a runaway slave, whom he refers to as 'a poor old woman’s nigger' who had done him no harm.

He attempts to mitigate his guilt by blaming his 'wicked' upbringing, but an inner voice reminds him that he had the option of attending Sunday school, where he would have learned that his actions concerning Jim lead to eternal damnation.

I didn’t have none, so he left. I went to the raft, and set down in the wigwam to think. But I couldn’t come to nothing. I thought till I wore my head sore, but I couldn’t see no way out of the trouble. After all this long journey, and after all we’d done for them scoundrels, here it was all come to nothing, everything all busted up and ruined, because they could have the heart to serve Jim such a trick as that, and make him a slave again all his life, and amongst strangers, too, for forty dirty dollars.
Once I said to myself it would be a thousand times better for Jim to be a slave at home where his family was, as long as he’d got to be a slave, and so I’d better write a letter to Tom Sawyer and tell him to tell Miss Watson where he was. But I soon give up that notion for two things: she’d be mad and disgusted at his rascality and ungratefulness for leaving her, and so she’d sell him straight down the river again; and if she didn’t, everybody naturally despises an ungrateful nigger, and they’d make Jim feel it all the time, and so he’d feel ornery and disgraced. And then think of me! It would get all around that Huck Finn helped a nigger to get his freedom; and if I was ever to see anybody from that town again I’d be ready to get down and lick his boots for shame. That’s just the way: a person does a low-down thing, and then he don’t want to take no consequences of it. Thinks as long as he can hide it, it ain’t no disgrace. That was my fix exactly. The more I studied about this, the more my conscience went to grinding me, and the more wicked and low-down and ornery I got to feeling. And at last, when it hit me all of a sudden that here was the plain hand of Providence slapping me in the face and letting me know my wickedness was being watched all the time from up there in heaven, whilst I was stealing a poor old woman’s nigger that hadn’t ever done me no harm, and now was showing me there’s One that’s always on the lookout, and ain’t a-going to allow no such miserable doings to go only just so fur and no further, I most dropped in my tracks I was so scared. Well, I tried the best I could to kinder soften it up somehow for myself by saying I was brung up wicked, and so I warn’t so much to blame; but something inside of me kept saying, “There was the Sunday-school, you could a gone to it; and if you’d a done it they’d a learnt you there that people that acts as I’d been acting about that nigger goes to everlasting fire.”

I didn’t have none, so he left. I sat there on the bank of the river, feeling mighty low. The sun was just startin’ to dip behind the trees, and the water looked like it was on fire with all them colors reflectin’ off it. I reckon I ought to’ve been feelin’ free, what with bein’ away from Pap and all, but somehow I just couldn’t shake the lonesomeness that had settled in my bones.

Jim had gone off to fetch some firewood, and the quiet was pressin’ down on me like a heavy blanket. I picked up a flat stone and skipped it across the water—one, two, three jumps—before it sank. It didn’t make me feel no better. I thought about all the lies I’d told lately, and how every one of ’em seemed to tangle me up worse than before. Maybe that’s why I was feelin’ so low. A feller can’t keep lyin’ without it weighin’ on him sooner or later.

Then I heard a rustlin’ in the bushes behind me. My heart near about jumped out of my chest, thinkin’ it might be Pap or some other trouble comin’ my way. But it was just Jim, his arms full of sticks and his face all serious-like.

“You ain’t got no business lookin’ so glum, Huck,” he said, droppin’ the wood in a pile. “We’s free now, or near ’bout as free as we can be.”

I shrugged. “Don’t feel free. Feels like there’s a whole mess of trouble followin’ us, and I can’t outrun it.”

Jim sat down beside me and stared out at the river. “Trouble’s always gonna be there, Huck. But we got each other, and we got this here river. That’s more’n most folks got.”

I reckoned he was right, but it didn’t make the weight on my chest no lighter. The sky was turnin’ purple now, and the first stars were peekin’ out. Somewhere off in the distance, a whippoorwill started callin’, and the sound of it was so lonesome it near about broke my heart.

“You ever think about what’s waitin’ for us downriver?” I asked.

Jim shook his head. “Ain’t no use thinkin’ on it too hard. We’ll find out when we get there. For now, we just gotta keep movin’.”

I knew he was right, but it didn’t make the unknown no less scary. Still, there was somethin’ comfortin’ about sittin’ there with Jim, listenin’ to the water and watchin’ the night come on. Maybe freedom wasn’t about bein’ without trouble, but about havin’ the chance to face it on your own terms.

Jim got up and started buildin’ the fire. “Gonna fix us some supper,” he said. “You best quit your mopin’ and help.”

I got to my feet, dustin’ off my pants. The fire crackled to life, chasin’ away some of the shadows—and some of the lonesomeness too. Maybe tomorrow would be better. Maybe it wouldn’t. But for now, we had the river, the stars, and each other. And that was enough.

events.title: The Power of Memory and Huck's Defining Choice for Jim
detailed_summary: The thought of eternal punishment makes Huck shiver, and he decides to pray in an attempt to reform himself and become a better person.
He kneels down, but the words of prayer elude him.

He understands that his inability to pray stems from a lack of sincerity; his heart isn't right because he's only pretending to renounce sin while still clinging to what society deems his greatest offense—helping Jim.
He realizes that one cannot offer a dishonest prayer.
Overwhelmed with trouble and uncertainty, he conceives an idea: he will write the letter to Miss Watson informing her of Jim's whereabouts, and then he will try to pray again.
Upon making this decision, he feels an immediate sense of relief, as if a great weight has been lifted.

Filled with gladness and excitement, he gets paper and a pencil and writes a concise note to Miss Watson, stating that her runaway slave Jim is at Mr. Phelps's place two miles below Pikesville and can be reclaimed for the reward.
He signs the letter 'HUCK FINN.'
For the first time in his life, he feels good and cleansed of sin, confident that he can now pray.
However, instead of praying immediately, he puts the letter down and reflects on how fortunate it was that events unfolded this way, considering how close he came to being 'lost and going to hell.'
His thoughts drift to his journey down the river with Jim, vividly recalling their shared moments day and night, in moonlight and storms, talking, singing, and laughing.

He finds no memories that harden his heart against Jim; instead, he remembers Jim's kindness: Jim taking Huck's watch so Huck could sleep, Jim's immense joy when Huck returned from the fog, and his relief when Huck rejoined him after the feud.
He recalls Jim's constant affection, calling him 'honey,' petting him, and doing everything he could for him, and how consistently good Jim had been.
He specifically remembers the time he saved Jim by lying about smallpox on the raft, and Jim's profound gratitude, calling Huck his best and only friend.
His gaze then falls upon the letter he just wrote.
He picks it up, trembling, fully aware that he faces an irrevocable choice between two paths.
After a moment of intense contemplation, holding his breath, he says to himself, 'All right, then, I’ll go to hell'—and tears up the letter.

It made me shiver. And I about made up my mind to pray, and see if I couldn’t try to quit being the kind of a boy I was and be better. So I kneeled down. But the words wouldn’t come. Why wouldn’t they? It warn’t no use to try and hide it from Him. Nor from me, neither. I knowed very well why they wouldn’t come. It was because my heart warn’t right; it was because I warn’t square; it was because I was playing double. I was letting on to give up sin, but away inside of me I was holding on to the biggest one of all. I was trying to make my mouth say I would do the right thing and the clean thing, and go and write to that nigger’s owner and tell where he was; but deep down in me I knowed it was a lie, and He knowed it. You can’t pray a lie—I found that out.
So I was full of trouble, full as I could be; and didn’t know what to do. At last I had an idea; and I says, I’ll go and write the letter—and then see if I can pray. Why, it was astonishing, the way I felt as light as a feather right straight off, and my troubles all gone. So I got a piece of paper and a pencil, all glad and excited, and set down and wrote:
Miss Watson, your runaway nigger Jim is down here two mile below Pikesville, and Mr. Phelps has got him and he will give him up for the reward if you send.
HUCK FINN.

It was awful thoughts and awful words, but they was said. And I let them stay said; and never thought no more about reforming. I shoved the whole thing out of my head, and said I would take up wickedness again, which was in my line, being brung up to it, and the other warn’t. And for a starter I would go to work and steal Jim out of slavery again; and if I could think up anything worse, I would do that, too; because as long as I was in, and in for good, I might as well go the whole hog.
Then I set to thinking over how to get at it, and turned over some considerable many ways in my mind; and at last fixed up a plan that suited me. So then I took the bearings of a woody island that was down the river a piece, and as soon as it was fairly dark I crept out with my raft and went for it, and hid it there, and then turned in. I slept the night through, and got up before it was light, and had my breakfast, and put on my store clothes, and tied up some others and one thing or another in a bundle, and took the canoe and cleared for shore. I landed below where I judged was Phelps’s place, and hid my bundle in the woods, and then filled up the canoe with water, and loaded rocks into her and sunk her where I could find her again when I wanted her, about a quarter of a mile below a little steam sawmill that was on the bank.

I sat there by the river, feeling lower than a snake’s belly, thinking on what I’d done. events.title: Confrontation with the Duke and a Fabricated Tale
detailed_summary: Huck begins walking up the road from the river.
He passes a sawmill with a sign identifying it as 'Phelps’s Sawmill.'
Further on, as he approaches some farmhouses, he observes his surroundings carefully but sees no one, despite it being well into daylight.
This doesn't concern him, as his plan involves approaching the Phelps place from the direction of the village, not directly from where he landed.
He takes a quick look around and continues towards the town.
The first person he encounters in the village is the duke.
The duke is occupied with posting bills for a three-night run of the 'Royal Nonesuch' performance, reminiscent of their previous scam.
Huck is upon him before he can avoid the encounter.
The duke expresses astonishment at seeing Huck and then, with a somewhat pleased and eager tone, asks about the raft's whereabouts and if it's in a safe place.
Huck cleverly turns the question back on the duke, stating that he was about to ask the same thing.
The duke's joyful expression fades, and he questions Huck's reason for asking.
Huck then launches into an elaborate, fabricated story to explain his presence and the raft's supposed disappearance.
He claims that after seeing the king intoxicated in the tavern, he decided to wander around town to pass the time while waiting for the king to sober up.
He alleges that a man offered him ten cents to help row a skiff across the river and back to fetch a sheep.
According to Huck's tale, the sheep proved too strong, broke free, and led them on a chase all over the countryside until dark.
He claims that when he finally returned to where the raft had been hidden, it was gone.

Huck feigns distress, stating he concluded that the duke and king must have encountered trouble and had to leave, taking 'his' slave, Jim, with them, leaving him stranded, penniless, and alone in a strange place.

The duke then explains his version: the king had made a 'trade' (implying Jim for money) and received forty dollars. However, by the time they found the king in the tavern, loafers had won all his money except what he'd spent on whiskey. When they later discovered the raft was gone, they assumed Huck had stolen it and deserted them.
The duke demands the ten cents Huck mentioned from the supposed sheep-fetching job.

Then I struck up the road, and when I passed the mill I see a sign on it, “Phelps’s Sawmill,” and when I come to the farm-houses, two or three hundred yards further along, I kept my eyes peeled, but didn’t see nobody around, though it was good daylight now. But I didn’t mind, because I didn’t want to see nobody just yet—I only wanted to get the lay of the land. According to my plan, I was going to turn up there from the village, not from below. So I just took a look, and shoved along, straight for town. Well, the very first man I see when I got there was the duke. He was sticking up a bill for the Royal Nonesuch—three-night performance—like that other time. They had the cheek, them frauds! I was right on him before I could shirk. He looked astonished, and says:
“Hel-lo! Where’d you come from?” Then he says, kind of glad and eager, “Where’s the raft?—got her in a good place?”
I says:
“Why, that’s just what I was going to ask your grace.”
Then he didn’t look so joyful, and says:
“What was your idea for asking me?” he says.
“Well,” I says, “when I see the king in that doggery yesterday I says to myself, we can’t get him home for hours, till he’s soberer; so I went a-loafing around town to put in the time and wait. A man up and offered me ten cents to help him pull a skiff over the river and back to fetch a sheep, and so I went along; but when we was dragging him to the boat, and the man left me a-holt of the rope and went behind him to shove him along, he was too strong for me and jerked loose and run, and we after him. We didn’t have no dog, and so we had to chase him all over the country till we tired him out. We never got him till dark; then we fetched him over, and I started down for the raft. When I got there and see it was gone, I says to myself, ‘they’ve got into trouble and had to leave; and they’ve took my nigger, which is the only nigger I’ve got in the world, and now I’m in a strange country, and ain’t got no property no more, nor nothing, and no way to make my living;’ so I set down and cried. I slept in the woods all night. But what did become of the raft, then?—and Jim—poor Jim!”
“Blamed if I know—that is, what’s become of the raft. That old fool had made a trade and got forty dollars, and when we found him in the doggery the loafers had matched half-dollars with him and got every cent but what he’d spent for whisky; and when I got him home late last night and found the raft gone, we said, ‘That little rascal has stole our raft and shook us, and run off down the river.’”
“I wouldn’t shake my nigger, would I?—the only nigger I had in the world, and the only property.”
“We never thought of that. Fact is, I reckon we’d come to consider him our nigger; yes, we did consider him so—goodness knows we had trouble enough for him. So when we see the raft was gone and we flat broke, there warn’t anything for it but to try the Royal Nonesuch another shake. And I’ve pegged along ever since, dry as a powder-horn. Where’s that ten cents? Give it here.”
