As I crept along the road, my heart thumping like a rabbit’s, I couldn’t help but feel a mix of excitement and dread. The sign on the mill—**“Phelps’s Sawmill”**—told me I was close, but close to what, I wasn’t rightly sure. Tom Sawyer had spun tales about his Uncle Silas and Aunt Sally Phelps, but I never reckoned I’d be sneaking up on their place like a thief in broad daylight.  

The farmhouses stood quiet, their windows dark and empty-looking. Chickens scratched in the dirt, and a lone hound lifted its head to watch me pass before flopping back down in the dust. It was mighty peculiar—no folks stirring, no voices calling from the fields. Maybe they was all inside, or maybe they’d gone off to town. Either way, it suited me fine. The less attention I drew, the better.  

I slowed my steps, listening hard. Somewhere off in the distance, I heard the steady *chug-chug* of the sawmill, but no human sounds. Then, just as I was fixing to slip past the last house, a door creaked open behind me. My stomach dropped clean to my shoes.  

“Who’s that trampin’ round here?” a woman’s voice called out sharp-like.  

I turned slow, trying to look harmless. There stood a stout woman in a calico dress, her hands planted on her hips like she meant business. Her face was sunburnt and lined, but her eyes were bright as a hawk’s.  

“Well?” she said. “Cat got your tongue?”  

I swallowed hard. “No’m. I was just… passin’ through.”  

“Passin’ through to where?” She squinted at me. “You ain’t from around here.”  

That much was true. I scrambled for a lie, something that wouldn’t land me in worse trouble. Then it hit me—Tom’s stories. If this was Aunt Sally, maybe I could twist the truth just enough.  

“I’m lookin’ for the Phelps place,” I said, trying to sound hopeful. “My name’s… Tom Sawyer.”  

Her whole face changed. “Tom Sawyer!” she shrieked, flinging her arms up. “Well, I do declare! We been expectin’ you all week!”  

Before I could so much as blink, she had me by the arm, dragging me toward the house like I was a stray pup she’d caught. “Land sakes, where’s your manners, boy? Your Uncle Silas is down at the mill, but he’ll be fit to be tied when he sees you! And your cousin Sid’s been askin’ after you—”  

**Cousin Sid?** My head spun. Tom hadn’t mentioned no Sid. This was fixing to be a sight more complicated than I’d figured.  

Aunt Sally didn’t give me time to think. She bustled me inside, hollering for someone named “Sister” to fetch water for washing. The house smelled of cornbread and lye soap, and every inch of it was scrubbed clean.  

“Now sit yourself down,” she ordered, shoving me toward a chair. “You must be half-starved. And look at them clothes—just rags!”  

I opened my mouth to protest, but she was already rummaging in a trunk. “Here—this’ll do till we get yours mended. Oh, your poor mother wrote us all about your adventures, but I never thought you’d turn up lookin’ like a drowned rat!”  

Adventures? Letters? My stomach twisted. If Tom’s aunt thought I was him, what happened when the real Tom showed up?  

Just then, footsteps pounded on the porch. The door flew open, and in rushed a boy about my size, panting like he’d run a mile.  

“Aunt Sally, there’s a—” He skidded to a stop, gaping at me.  

I gaped back.  

It was Tom Sawyer himself.  

And the jig was up.

events.title: The Duke's Misdirection and Huck's Feigned Compliance
detailed_summary: Although Huck has money, he gives the duke only ten cents, pleading that it is all he possesses and that he is starving, hoping the duke will buy food and share.
The duke remains silent initially, but then suddenly confronts Huck, questioning whether Jim would inform on them, threatening to skin Jim if he did.
Huck deflects by asking how Jim could 'blow' on them if he has supposedly run off.
The duke then reveals the truth: the king sold Jim and kept all the money, which is now gone.
Huck feigns tears and distress, exclaiming that Jim was 'his' slave and therefore the money was rightfully his.
The duke dismisses Huck's supposed sorrow and eyes him with suspicion, questioning if Huck himself might betray them, his expression turning ugly.
Huck continues to whimper, insisting he doesn't want to betray anyone and is only focused on finding 'his nigger.'

The duke appears somewhat troubled by Huck's display and, after some thought, proposes a deal: they will be in town for three days, and if Huck promises not to betray them or allow Jim to do so, the duke will reveal Jim's location.
Huck readily agrees.
The duke begins to tell Huck the truth, starting with 'A farmer by the name of Silas Ph—' but then hesitates, reconsiders, and decides to lie to get Huck out of the way for the three days.
He falsely informs Huck that Jim was sold to Abram G. Foster, who supposedly lives forty miles away in the country, on the road to Lafayette.
Huck pretends to accept this, stating he can walk the distance in three days and will start that very afternoon.
The duke, however, insists Huck leave immediately and maintain silence about their conversation en route, a directive that perfectly suits Huck's own hidden agenda to be free to pursue his real plan.

I had considerable money, so I give him ten cents, but begged him to spend it for something to eat, and give me some, because it was all the money I had, and I hadn’t had nothing to eat since yesterday. He never said nothing. The next minute he whirls on me and says:
“Do you reckon that nigger would blow on us? We’d skin him if he done that!”
“How can he blow? Hain’t he run off?”
“No! That old fool sold him, and never divided with me, and the money’s gone.”
“Sold him?” I says, and begun to cry; “why, he was my nigger, and that was my money. Where is he?—I want my nigger.”
“Well, you can’t get your nigger, that’s all—so dry up your blubbering. Looky here—do you think you’d venture to blow on us? Blamed if I think I’d trust you. Why, if you was to blow on us—”
He stopped, but I never see the duke look so ugly out of his eyes before. I went on a-whimpering, and says:
“I don’t want to blow on nobody; and I ain’t got no time to blow, nohow. I got to turn out and find my nigger.”
He looked kinder bothered, and stood there with his bills fluttering on his arm, thinking, and wrinkling up his forehead. At last he says:

The baker was a fat man with flour dusted all over his apron. He looked us up and down like we was stray dogs, but when my companion slapped the dime on the counter, his expression softened some.  

“Two loaves,” the man said, and the baker handed ’em over without a word.

“Slow down,” he muttered. “Ain’t nobody gonna take it from you.”  

I nodded but kept eating. When I finished, I licked the crumbs off my fingers and looked at him. “Much obliged.”  

He shrugged. “Ain’t nothin’. But you best find some work if you aim to keep eatin’. Money don’t last long in this world.”  

“I know it,” I said, though truth was, I hadn’t thought much past filling my belly.  

He studied me again, then sighed. “You got a place to sleep?”  

I shook my head.  

“Figured as much.” He rubbed his jaw, thinking. “There’s an old shed down by the river. Nobody much goes there. You can hole up there tonight if you want.”  

I perked up at that. “I’d be obliged.”

“I won’t,” I promised.

He mockingly suggests Huck can tell the fictional Mr. Foster anything, even try to convince him Jim is Huck's slave or that the reward handbill is bogus.
Huck senses that the duke is watching him as he leaves, but feels confident he can eventually evade this scrutiny.
He continues in the feigned direction for about a mile before stopping.
Once out of sight, he discreetly changes course, doubling back through the woods towards the actual location of Phelps's farm.
He believes it is crucial to begin his plan to rescue Jim without delay, partly to ensure Jim doesn't inadvertently reveal any information about the duke and king.
Huck is resolute in his desire to be completely free of the two con men, having had his fill of their company and deceit.

The narrator enters the property by climbing over a back stile near the ash-hopper and heads towards the kitchen.

When I got there it was all still and Sunday-like, and hot and sunshiny; the hands was gone to the fields; and there was them kind of faint dronings of bugs and flies in the air that makes it seem so lonesome and like everybody’s dead and gone; and if a breeze fans along and quivers the leaves it makes you feel mournful, because you feel like it’s spirits whispering—spirits that’s been dead ever so many years—and you always think they’re talking about you. As a general thing it makes a body wish he was dead, too, and done with it all.
Phelps’ was one of these little one-horse cotton plantations, and they all look alike. A rail fence round a two-acre yard; a stile made out of logs sawed off and up-ended in steps, like barrels of a different length, to climb over the fence with, and for the women to stand on when they are going to jump on to a horse; some sickly grass-patches in the big yard, but mostly it was bare and smooth, like an old hat with the nap rubbed off; big double log-house for the white folks—hewed logs, with the chinks stopped up with mud or mortar, and these mud-stripes been whitewashed some time or another; round-log kitchen, with a big broad, open but roofed passage joining it to the house; log smoke-house back of the kitchen; three little log nigger-cabins in a row t’other side the smoke-house; one little hut all by itself away down against the back fence, and some outbuildings down a piece the other side; ash-hopper and big kettle to bile soap in by the little hut; bench by the kitchen door, with bucket of water and a gourd; hound asleep there in the sun; more hounds asleep round about; about three shade trees away off in a corner; some currant bushes and gooseberry bushes in one place by the fence; outside of the fence a garden and a watermelon patch; then the cotton fields begins, and after the fields the woods.
I went around and clumb over the back stile by the ash-hopper, and started for the kitchen. When I got a little ways I heard the dim hum of a spinning-wheel wailing along up and sinking along down again; and then I knowed for certain I wished I was dead—for that is the lonesomest sound in the whole world.

events.text_segment:
I went right along, not fixing up any particular plan, but just trusting to Providence to put the right words in my mouth when the time come; for I’d noticed that Providence always did put the right words in my mouth if I left it alone.
When I got half-way, first one hound and then another got up and went for me, and of course I stopped and faced them, and kept still. And such another powwow as they made! In a quarter of a minute I was a kind of a hub of a wheel, as you may say—spokes made out of dogs—circle of fifteen of them packed together around me, with their necks and noses stretched up towards me, a-barking and howling; and more a-coming; you could see them sailing over fences and around corners from everywheres.
A nigger woman come tearing out of the kitchen with a rolling-pin in her hand, singing out, “Begone you Tige! you Spot! begone sah!” and she fetched first one and then another of them a clip and sent them howling, and then the rest followed; and the next second half of them come back, wagging their tails around me, and making friends with me. There ain’t no harm in a hound, nohow.
And behind the woman comes a little nigger girl and two little nigger boys without anything on but tow-linen shirts, and they hung on to their mother’s gown, and peeped out from behind her at me, bashful, the way they always do. And here comes the white woman running from the house, about forty-five or fifty year old, bareheaded, and her spinning-stick in her hand; and behind her comes her little white children, acting the same way the little niggers was doing. She was smiling all over so she could hardly stand—and says:
“It’s you, at last!—ain’t it?”
I out with a “Yes’m” before I thought.
She grabbed me and hugged me tight; and then gripped me by both hands and shook and shook; and the tears come in her eyes, and run down over; and she couldn’t seem to hug and shake enough, and kept saying, “You don’t look as much like your mother as I reckoned you would; but law sakes, I don’t care for that, I’m so glad to see you! Dear, dear, it does seem like I could eat you up! Children, it’s your cousin Tom!—tell him howdy.”

It was a queer sort of feeling, floating down the river with no particular aim, just letting the current take me where it would. The river didn’t ask questions, didn’t tell you what to do. It just carried you, same as Providence did when you stopped trying to steer things your own way.  

I thought about Jim then, and how he was trusting me to get him to freedom. It was a heavy weight, knowing somebody else’s whole future was hitched to your choices. But Jim never seemed worried. He had a way of looking at things that made trouble seem smaller, like it wasn’t nothing but a cloud passing over the sun. Maybe that was his kind of Providence—believing things would work out if you just kept moving forward.  

The more I turned it over in my head, the more I saw that planning too much was like trying to paddle upstream. You wore yourself out fighting against the current, and in the end, the river won anyway. Better to go with it, to let the water do most of the work. events.title: Weaving Lies: Huck Navigates Aunt Sally's Questions
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally's children remain shy, hiding behind her and putting their fingers in their mouths.
Aunt Sally instructs Lize to quickly prepare a hot breakfast for the narrator, whom she believes to be Tom.
The narrator claims he has already eaten breakfast on the steamboat.
Aunt Sally then leads him by the hand into the house, with the children following.
Inside, she has him sit down and sits opposite him on a low stool, holding both his hands, expressing how eagerly she has anticipated this meeting for many years.
She mentions they had been expecting him for a couple of days and asks about the cause of his delay, suggesting his boat might have run aground.
The narrator begins to confirm, saying "Yes'm—she—".
Aunt Sally gently corrects him, telling him to call her "Aunt Sally," and then asks where the boat grounded.
Uncertain whether the boat was supposed to be traveling up or down the river, the narrator relies on his intuition, guessing it was coming upstream from the direction of New Orleans.
Lacking knowledge of specific sandbars in that area, he improvises and claims the delay wasn't due to grounding but because they "blowed out a cylinder-head."
Aunt Sally expresses concern, asking if anyone was injured.
The narrator replies, "No'm. Killed a nigger."

Aunt Sally considers this fortunate, remarking that sometimes "people do get hurt." She recounts a past incident where her husband, Uncle Silas, was on a boat, the Lally Rook, that blew a cylinder-head, crippling a man who later died from mortification after an amputation. She adds that the man was a Baptist.

She informs the narrator that Uncle Silas has been going to town daily to meet him and had left for town again just an hour prior, expecting him back shortly. She asks if he encountered Uncle Silas on the road.

The narrator denies meeting anyone, explaining that the boat landed at daylight, and he spent time exploring the town and countryside to pass the time before arriving at the plantation via the back way.
Aunt Sally then inquires about his baggage.
The narrator claims he gave it to nobody.
She expresses alarm that it will be stolen.
He reassures her, saying he believes it won't be stolen from where he hid it.
She then questions how he managed to get breakfast so early on the boat.
Feeling the situation is precarious, he invents another story, stating that the captain saw him and invited him to eat with the officers in the texas (officers' quarters) before he went ashore.

But they ducked their heads, and put their fingers in their mouths, and hid behind her. So she run on:
“Lize, hurry up and get him a hot breakfast right away—or did you get your breakfast on the boat?”
I said I had got it on the boat. So then she started for the house, leading me by the hand, and the children tagging after. When we got there she set me down in a split-bottomed chair, and set herself down on a little low stool in front of me, holding both of my hands, and says:
“Now I can have a good look at you; and, laws-a-me, I’ve been hungry for it a many and a many a time, all these long years, and it’s come at last! We been expecting you a couple of days and more. What kep’ you?—boat get aground?”
“Yes’m—she—”
“Don’t say yes’m—say Aunt Sally. Where’d she get aground?”
I didn’t rightly know what to say, because I didn’t know whether the boat would be coming up the river or down. But I go a good deal on instinct; and my instinct said she would be coming up—from down towards Orleans. That didn’t help me much, though; for I didn’t know the names of bars down that way. I see I’d got to invent a bar, or forget the name of the one we got aground on—or—Now I struck an idea, and fetched it out:
“It warn’t the grounding—that didn’t keep us back but a little. We blowed out a cylinder-head.”
“Good gracious! anybody hurt?”
“No’m. Killed a nigger.”
“Well, it’s lucky; because sometimes people do get hurt. Two years ago last Christmas your uncle Silas was coming up from Newrleans on the old Lally Rook, and she blowed out a cylinder-head and crippled a man. And I think he died afterwards. He was a Baptist. Your uncle Silas knowed a family in Baton Rouge that knowed his people very well. Yes, I remember now, he did die. Mortification set in, and they had to amputate him. But it didn’t save him. Yes, it was mortification—that was it. He turned blue all over, and died in the hope of a glorious resurrection. They say he was a sight to look at. Your uncle’s been up to the town every day to fetch you. And he’s gone again, not more’n an hour ago; he’ll be back any minute now. You must a met him on the road, didn’t you?—oldish man, with a—”
“No, I didn’t see nobody, Aunt Sally. The boat landed just at daylight, and I left my baggage on the wharf-boat and went looking around the town and out a piece in the country, to put in the time and not get here too soon; and so I come down the back way.”
“Who’d you give the baggage to?”
“Nobody.”
“Why, child, it’ll be stole!”
“Not where I hid it I reckon it won’t,” I says.
“How’d you get your breakfast so early on the boat?”
It was kinder thin ice, but I says:
“The captain see me standing around, and told me I better have something to eat before I went ashore; so he took me in the texas to the officers’ lunch, and give me all I wanted.”

‘There, I reckon it’s done you good. I reckon you ain’t so homesick now, are you?’

‘Now I want you to tell me all about it—how you come to be here, and who you are, and everything.’

I see that warn’t no use to try to go ahead—I’d got to throw up my hand. So I says to myself, here’s another place where I got to resk the truth. I had just one little glimpse of the old gentleman when he come in, then the bed hid him. Mrs. Phelps she jumps for him and says:  

‘Has he come?’  

‘No,’ says her husband.  

‘Good-ness gracious!’ she says, ‘what in the world can have become of him?’  

‘I can’t imagine,’ says the old gentleman; ‘and I must say, it makes me dreadful uneasy.’  

‘Uneasy!’ she says, ‘I’m ready to go distracted! He must a come; and you’ve missed him along the road. I know it’s so—something tells me so.’  

‘Why, Sally, I couldn’t miss him along the road—you know that.’  

‘But oh, dear, dear, what will Sis say! He must a come! You must a missed him. He—’  

‘Oh, don’t distress me any more’n I’m already distressed. I don’t know what in the world to make of it. I’m at my wit’s end, and I don’t mind acknowledging ’t I’m right down scared. But there’s no hope that he’s come; for he couldn’t come and me miss him. Sally, it’s terrible—just terrible—something’s happened to the boat, sure!’  

‘Why, Silas! Look yonder!—up the road!—ain’t that somebody coming?’  

He sprung to the window at the head of the bed, and that give Mrs. Phelps the chance she wanted. She stooped down quick, at the foot of the bed, and give me a pull, and out I come; and when he turned back from the window, there she stood, a-beaming and a-smiling like a house afire, and I standing pretty meek and sweaty alongside. The old gentleman stared, and says:  

‘Why, who’s that?’  

‘Who do you reckon ’t is?’  

‘I hain’t no idea. Who is it?’  

‘It’s Tom Sawyer!’  

By jings, I most slumped through the floor! But there warn’t no time to swap knives; the old man grabbed me by the hand and shook, and kept on shaking; and all the time, how the woman did dance around and laugh and cry; and then how they both did fire off questions about Sid, and Mary, and the rest of the tribe!  

But if they was joyful, it warn’t nothing to what I was; for it was like being born again, I was so glad to find out who I was. Well, they froze to me for two hours; and at last when my chin was so tired it couldn’t hardly go, any more, I had told them more about my family—I mean the Sawyer family—than ever happened to any six Sawyer families. And I explained all about how we blowed out a cylinder-head at the mouth of White River and it took us three days to fix it. Which was all right, and worked first rate; because they didn’t know but what it would take three days to fix it. If I’d a called it a bolt-head it would a done just as well."

But they ducked their heads, and put their fingers in their mouths, and hid behind her. It was a sight that made me feel mighty sorry for them, though I couldn’t rightly say why. There they were, two little tow-headed boys, peeking out from behind their mammy’s skirts like scared rabbits. Their faces was pale, and their eyes big as saucers, like they’d seen a ghost or somethin’ worse.  

The woman—their mother, I reckoned—stood tall and firm, her hands on her hips, glarin’ at me like I was the devil himself. She had a look about her that said she wasn’t afraid of nothin’, not even a ragged boy like me who’d come floatin’ down the river on a raft.  

“Who are you, and what’s your business here?” she demanded, her voice sharp as a whip crack.  

I swallowed hard, tryin’ to think up a lie quick. “Name’s George Jackson, ma’am,” I said, touchin’ my hat like I’d seen proper folks do. “I’m just passin’ through, lookin’ for my uncle down the river a ways.”  

She narrowed her eyes, studyin’ me like I was a fish she was fixin’ to clean. “You don’t look like no George Jackson to me,” she said. “You look like trouble.”  

Them words sent a shiver down my spine. I didn’t want no trouble, leastways not with a woman who looked like she could tan my hide with one hand tied behind her back.  

“No, ma’am,” I said quick. “I ain’t no trouble. Just a boy tryin’ to find his kin.”  

She didn’t look convinced, but she didn’t chase me off neither. Instead, she turned to the little ones hidin’ behind her and said, “Go on inside now, both of you. This ain’t no place for young’uns.”  

The boys didn’t need tellin’ twice. They scampered off like their tails was on fire, leavin’ me standin’ there feelin’ mighty foolish.  

The woman crossed her arms and stared me down. “You hungry?” she asked sudden-like.  

I hadn’t realized it till she said it, but my stomach was growlin’ like a bear. “Yes’m,” I admitted.  

She nodded, like she’d expected as much. “Come on then,” she said, turnin’ toward the house. “But mind your manners, and don’t you go stealin’ nothin’.”  

I followed her inside, feelin’ like a stray dog bein’ let in outta the rain. The cabin was small but clean, with a fire cracklin’ in the hearth and the smell of cornbread fillin’ the air. The two boys was huddled in a corner, watchin’ me with them big eyes of theirs.  

“Sit,” the woman said, pointin’ to a stool by the table.  

I sat, keepin’ my hands in my lap like I was afraid they’d get me in trouble if I moved ’em. She dished up a plate of beans and cornbread and set it in front of me.  

“Eat,” she ordered.  

I didn’t need no more encouragin’. I dug in like I hadn’t eaten in a week, which near enough was the truth. The woman watched me the whole time, her face unreadable.  

When I was done, I wiped my mouth with the back of my hand and said, “Thank you, ma’am. That was mighty kind.”  

She didn’t smile, but her eyes softened just a little. “Kindness ain’t got nothin’ to do with it,” she said. “A body does what’s right, that’s all.”  

I didn’t know what to say to that, so I just nodded.  

She studied me a minute longer, then sighed. “You best be on your way,” she said. “Night’s comin’, and you don’t want to be caught out after dark.”  

I knew she was right. I stood up, touchin’ my hat again. “Yes’m. Thank you again.”  

She didn’t answer, just turned back to her work. But as I stepped out into the twilight, I heard one of the little boys whisper, “Bye, mister.”  

I looked back and saw him peekin’ around the doorframe, his finger back in his mouth. I waved, and he ducked outta sight again, but not before I saw the tiniest smile.  

Somehow, that made me feel a little better about the world.

events.title: The Prank Unfolds: Uncle Silas's Concern and the Grand Reveal
detailed_summary: The narrator recognizes his predicament but understands there's nothing to do but stay still and mentally prepare for whatever consequences might follow.
He catches a fleeting glimpse of an older gentleman, Uncle Silas, entering the room just before the bed obstructs his view.
Mrs. Phelps immediately jumps up and asks her husband if "he" (meaning Tom) has arrived.
Uncle Silas responds that he has not.
Mrs. Phelps feigns immense surprise and distress, wondering aloud what could have happened to him.
Uncle Silas confesses he has no idea and admits the situation is making him extremely uneasy.
Mrs. Phelps dramatically exclaims she is on the verge of distraction, insisting that Tom must have arrived and that Uncle Silas must have missed him on the road.
Uncle Silas counters that he couldn't possibly have missed him.
Mrs. Phelps continues her act, wailing about what "Sis" (Tom's mother, her sister) will say and reiterating her belief that Tom must have come and been missed.

Uncle Silas, already deeply troubled, pleads with her not to exacerbate his distress. He admits he is at his wit's end and genuinely frightened, convinced that something terrible must have happened to the steamboat since Tom couldn't have arrived without him knowing.
Suddenly, Mrs. Phelps points towards the road, exclaiming, "Why, Silas! Look yonder!—up the road!—ain’t that somebody coming?"
As Uncle Silas rushes to the window at the head of the bed to look, Mrs. Phelps seizes the opportunity. She quickly stoops down at the foot of the bed and pulls the narrator out.
When Uncle Silas turns back from the window, he finds his wife beaming triumphantly, with the narrator standing somewhat sheepishly and sweatily beside her.
The old gentleman stares in astonishment and asks who the boy is.
Mrs. Phelps playfully asks him to guess.
Uncle Silas admits he has no idea.
With a flourish, Mrs. Phelps announces, "It’s Tom Sawyer!"

I knew if we got caught, Jim would be sent back to slavery, and I’d be in trouble for helping him. My conscience started gnawing at me—was I doing wrong by stealing a man’s property, like society said? Or was I doing right by helping a friend gain his freedom?  

I tried to reason it out. events.title: Identity Confirmed: Huck's Relief and Elaborate Lies
detailed_summary: The narrator is so profoundly relieved to learn his mistaken identity is Tom Sawyer that he feels he almost collapsed.
Before he has much time to process, Uncle Silas grabs his hand and shakes it vigorously and continuously.
Meanwhile, Aunt Sally joyfully dances around, simultaneously laughing and crying.
Both Mr. and Mrs. Phelps then eagerly start firing questions at him about Sid, Mary, and the other members of the Sawyer family.
The narrator reflects that his own joy at finally discovering "who he was" (in this mistaken identity) was even greater than the Phelpses' happiness; it felt like a rebirth.

For the next two hours, they remained intensely focused on him, and by the time his jaw was tired from talking, he had told them more fabricated stories about his supposed family—the Sawyer family—than could possibly be true for any six actual Sawyer families.
He also elaborates on his invented steamboat problem, explaining that they had blown out a cylinder-head at the mouth of the White River, and it took three days to repair it.
This explanation was perfectly acceptable and effective because the Phelpses had no reason to doubt that such a repair would take three days.
He muses to himself that if he had claimed it was a "bolthead" instead of a cylinder-head, it would have been equally convincing.

detailed_summary: The narrator begins to feel a mixture of emotions: one part of him is quite comfortable with the ease of impersonating Tom Sawyer, but another part is becoming increasingly uncomfortable.
His ease is maintained until he hears the distinct sound of a steamboat coughing its way down the river.
This sound immediately sparks a new fear: what if the real Tom Sawyer is aboard that boat?
He worries that Tom might arrive unexpectedly and call out the narrator's real name before he has a chance to signal Tom to remain quiet and play along.
The narrator decides he cannot allow this to happen, as it would ruin everything.
He resolves that he must go up the road to intercept Tom.
To create an excuse for his departure, he tells the Phelpses that he intends to go to town to retrieve his baggage.
Uncle Silas offers to accompany him.
However, the narrator declines the offer, asserting that he can manage the horse by himself and would prefer that Uncle Silas not go to any trouble on his account.

I says “Hold on!” and it stopped alongside, and his mouth opened up like a trunk, and stayed so; and he swallowed two or three times like a person that’s got a dry throat, and then says:
“I hain’t ever done you no harm. You know that. So, then, what you want to come back and ha’nt me for?”
I says:
“I hain’t come back—I hain’t been gone.”
When he heard my voice it righted him up some, but he warn’t quite satisfied yet. He says:
“Don’t you play nothing on me, because I wouldn’t on you. Honest injun now, you ain’t a ghost?”
“Honest injun, I ain’t,” I says.
“Well—I—I—well, that ought to settle it, of course; but I can’t somehow seem to understand it no way. Looky here, warn’t you ever murdered at all?”
“No. I warn’t ever murdered at all—I played it on them. You come in here and feel of me if you don’t believe me.”
So he done it; and it satisfied him; and he was that glad to see me again he didn’t know what to do.

detailed_summary: Tom is immediately curious about the narrator's adventure and its mysterious nature.

And he wanted to know all about it right off, because it was a grand adventure, and mysterious, and so it hit him where he lived. But I said, leave it alone till by-and-by; and told his driver to wait, and we drove off a little piece, and I told him the kind of a fix I was in, and what did he reckon we better do? He said, let him alone a minute, and don’t disturb him. So he thought and thought, and pretty soon he says:
“It’s all right; I’ve got it. Take my trunk in your wagon, and let on it’s your’n; and you turn back and fool along slow, so as to get to the house about the time you ought to; and I’ll go towards town a piece, and take a fresh start, and get there a quarter or a half an hour after you; and you needn’t let on to know me at first.”
I says:
“All right; but wait a minute. There’s one more thing—a thing that nobody don’t know but me. And that is, there’s a nigger here that I’m a-trying to steal out of slavery, and his name is Jim—old Miss Watson’s Jim.”
He says:
“What! Why, Jim is—”

In about half an hour Tom’s wagon drove up to the front stile, and Aunt Sally she see it through the window, because it was only about fifty yards, and says:
“Why, there’s somebody come! I wonder who ’tis? Why, I do believe it’s a stranger. Jimmy” (that’s one of the children) “run and tell Lize to put on another plate for dinner.”
Everybody made a rush for the front door, because, of course, a stranger don’t come every year, and so he lays over the yaller-fever, for interest, when he does come. Tom was over the stile and starting for the house; the wagon was spinning up the road for the village, and we was all bunched in the front door. Tom had his store clothes on, and an audience—and that was always nuts for Tom Sawyer. In them circumstances it warn’t no trouble to him to throw in an amount of style that was suitable. He warn’t a boy to meeky along up that yard like a sheep; no, he come ca’m and important, like the ram. When he got a-front of us he lifts his hat ever so gracious and dainty, like it was the lid of a box that had butterflies asleep in it and he didn’t want to disturb them, and says:
“Mr. Archibald Nichols, I presume?”
“No, my boy,” says the old gentleman, “I’m sorry to say ’t your driver has deceived you; Nichols’s place is down a matter of three mile more. Come in, come in.”
Tom he took a look back over his shoulder, and says, “Too late—he’s out of sight.”
“Yes, he’s gone, my son, and you must come in and eat your dinner with us; and then we’ll hitch up and take you down to Nichols’s.”
“Oh, I can’t make you so much trouble; I couldn’t think of it. I’ll walk—I don’t mind the distance.”
“But we won’t let you walk—it wouldn’t be Southern hospitality to do it. Come right in.”
“Oh, do,” says Aunt Sally; “it ain’t a bit of trouble to us, not a bit in the world. You must stay. It’s a long, dusty three mile, and we can’t let you walk. And, besides, I’ve already told ’em to put on another plate when I see you coming; so you mustn’t disappoint us. Come right in and make yourself at home.”
So Tom he thanked them very hearty and handsome, and let himself be persuaded, and come in; and when he was in he said he was a stranger from Hicksville, Ohio, and his name was William Thompson—and he made another bow.

“No,” says Uncle Silas, stepping forward, “I’m sorry to say he ain’t here just now. But I’m his brother, and I reckon I can answer just about as well. Won’t you step in?”  

Tom give him a look like he was considerable surprised, and says:  

“Oh, indeed! Then you must be Mr. William Phelps, I presume?”  

“No,” says the old gentleman, looking a little puzzled, “my name’s Silas Phelps. You must be thinking of my brother William—he’s been dead these two years.”  

Tom he shook his head sorrowful and says:  

“I’m truly sorry to hear it. He was a fine man—a very fine man. But I reckon the business I come on can be attended to by you just as well. It’s about a runaway n—”  

I never see a nigger so scared in all my born days as Jim was when he heard that word. He reckoned he was discovered sure, and he made a dive for the bed and crawled under it quick as a wink. But Tom never noticed, and went right on:  

“—a runaway apprentice by the name of Jim. I was sent to fetch him back to his owner down in Orleans.”  

Well, Aunt Sally she lit up at that, and Uncle Silas too, and they both begun firing questions at Tom about Jim and where he was and how he come to be there, and Tom he answered them all smooth as butter, making up a long yarn about how Jim had been hiding out and how he’d tracked him all the way upriver.  

All the while, Jim was under that bed, shaking like a leaf, and I was standing there trying not to laugh, because I knowed Tom was just playing one of his games. But I tell you, it was all I could do to keep from busting out right there in front of everybody.

events.title: The Audacious Kiss and Identity Revealed
detailed_summary: Tom, as William Thompson, spins elaborate tales about Hicksville, making the narrator (Huck) anxious about how this charade will help his situation.
In the middle of his storytelling, Tom leans over and kisses Aunt Sally directly on the mouth, then calmly resumes his seat.
Aunt Sally jumps up, wipes her mouth, and exclaims, 'You owdacious puppy!'
Tom feigns being hurt and surprised by her reaction.
Aunt Sally, indignant, questions his actions and threatens him with a spinning stick, demanding to know why he thought she'd like being kissed.
Tom humbly claims he meant no harm and that 'they' told him she would like it.
When pressed, he insists 'everybody' told him so, appearing distressed and apologizing, promising not to do it again until she asks.
This infuriates Aunt Sally further, who exclaims she'll never ask.
Tom, feigning continued surprise, looks around and asks Uncle Silas if he didn't think she'd like the kiss, to which Uncle Silas hesitantly agrees he didn't.
Tom then turns to the narrator (Huck, whom Aunt Sally believes is Tom Sawyer) and asks, 'Tom, didn’t you think Aunt Sally ’d open out her arms and say, ‘Sid Sawyer—’'
Aunt Sally, recognizing 'Sid Sawyer' (Tom's actual brother's name, which Tom is now using for himself), breaks in, calls Tom an 'impudent young rascal,' and moves to hug him.
Tom playfully fends her off, insisting she ask him first, which she promptly does, leading to joyful hugs and kisses.
After the excitement, Aunt Sally remarks she never expected such a surprise, as they were only anticipating Tom (Huck), and his sister hadn't mentioned anyone else coming.

Well, he run on, and on, and on, making up stuff about Hicksville and everybody in it he could invent, and I getting a little nervious, and wondering how this was going to help me out of my scrape; and at last, still talking along, he reached over and kissed Aunt Sally right on the mouth, and then settled back again in his chair comfortable, and was going on talking; but she jumped up and wiped it off with the back of her hand, and says:
“You owdacious puppy!”
He looked kind of hurt, and says:
“I’m surprised at you, m’am.”
“You’re s’rp—Why, what do you reckon I am? I’ve a good notion to take and—Say, what do you mean by kissing me?”
He looked kind of humble, and says:
“I didn’t mean nothing, m’am. I didn’t mean no harm. I—I—thought you’d like it.”
“Why, you born fool!” She took up the spinning stick, and it looked like it was all she could do to keep from giving him a crack with it. “What made you think I’d like it?”
“Well, I don’t know. Only, they—they—told me you would.”
“They told you I would. Whoever told you’s another lunatic. I never heard the beat of it. Who’s they?”
“Why, everybody. They all said so, m’am.”
It was all she could do to hold in; and her eyes snapped, and her fingers worked like she wanted to scratch him; and she says:
“Who’s ‘everybody’? Out with their names, or ther’ll be an idiot short.”
He got up and looked distressed, and fumbled his hat, and says:
“I’m sorry, and I warn’t expecting it. They told me to. They all told me to. They all said, kiss her; and said she’d like it. They all said it—every one of them. But I’m sorry, m’am, and I won’t do it no more—I won’t, honest.”
“You won’t, won’t you? Well, I sh’d reckon you won’t!”
“No’m, I’m honest about it; I won’t ever do it again—till you ask me.”
“Till I ask you! Well, I never see the beat of it in my born days! I lay you’ll be the Methusalem-numskull of creation before ever I ask you—or the likes of you.”
“Well,” he says, “it does surprise me so. I can’t make it out, somehow. They said you would, and I thought you would. But—” He stopped and looked around slow, like he wished he could run across a friendly eye somewheres, and fetched up on the old gentleman’s, and says, “Didn’t you think she’d like me to kiss her, sir?”
“Why, no; I—I—well, no, I b’lieve I didn’t.”
Then he looks on around the same way to me, and says:
“Tom, didn’t you think Aunt Sally ’d open out her arms and say, ‘Sid Sawyer—’”
“My land!” she says, breaking in and jumping for him, “you impudent young rascal, to fool a body so—” and was going to hug him, but he fended her off, and says:
“No, not till you’ve asked me first.”
So she didn’t lose no time, but asked him; and hugged him and kissed him over and over again, and then turned him over to the old man, and he took what was left. And after they got a little quiet again she says:
“Why, dear me, I never see such a surprise. We warn’t looking for you at all, but only Tom. Sis never wrote to me about anybody coming but him.”

“You owdacious puppy!” she hollered, her face red as a beet.  

I reckon Tom Sawyer never did see a woman so riled up in all his born days. She stood there, hands on her hips, looking like she might take a broom to him any second. But Tom, he just leaned back in that chair, grinning like a possum in a persimmon tree, and says, “Why, Aunt Sally, ain’t that how folks in Hicksville greet their kin?”  

Well, that set her off worse. “Hicksville!” she shrieked. “There ain’t no such place, and you know it! And if there was, they wouldn’t go around kissin’ folks like some heathen!”  

Now, I was sweating bullets, seeing as how this whole mess was supposed to be helping me out of a tight spot, and here Tom was making it worse. But that’s Tom Sawyer for you—always turning a simple plan into a three-ring circus.  

Then Uncle Silas, who’d been sitting there quiet as a mouse, pipes up, “Now, Sally, maybe the boy’s just confused. He’s had a long journey, and—”  

“Confused!” she hollers. “He ain’t confused, he’s plumb deceitful! And I’ll tan his hide if he don’t start tellin’ the truth!”  

Tom, he just sighed, all dramatic-like, and says, “Well, if you don’t believe me, I reckon there ain’t no use in me stayin’.” He made like he was gonna get up, but Aunt Sally pointed a finger sharp as a needle at him.  

“Oh no, you don’t! You sit right there, young man, till I get to the bottom of this!”  

Now, I was about ready to bolt for the door, but Tom caught my eye and winked. That rascal always did have a scheme, and sure enough, just when things looked darkest, he says, “All right, Aunt Sally, I’ll come clean. The truth is… I ain’t your nephew at all.”  

Well, you could’ve knocked her over with a feather. She just stood there, mouth open, while Tom went on, “I’m really… the long-lost Duke of Bilgewater!”  

That did it. Aunt Sally let out a screech like a cat with its tail caught in a door, and Uncle Silas started coughing into his handkerchief, though I suspect he was hiding a laugh.  

Tom, he was just getting warmed up. “Yes, ma’am, kidnapped as a babe and raised by pirates, but I’ve come to claim my rightful—”  

“OUT!” Aunt Sally hollered, snatching up a broom. “OUT OF MY HOUSE THIS INSTANT!”  

Well, Tom didn’t need telling twice. He lit out the door like his pants was on fire, and I was right behind him. We didn’t stop running till we was clear to the creek, and then we both doubled over laughing till our sides hurt.  

“Tom,” I says, gasping, “you’re the most outrageous liar I ever did see.”  

He just grinned and tipped his hat. “Why, Huck, sometimes you gotta stir the pot to keep things interestin’.”  

And that was Tom Sawyer for you—always turning trouble into a grand adventure.

“Huck,” he whispered, stopping sudden, “you know what they’re saying in town? They think you was murdered—that your pap done it and lit out. And Jim’s escape has stirred up a hornet’s nest.”  

I swallowed hard. It was queer hearing about my own death, like listening to a story that wasn’t mine. I told Tom about the king and the duke, their swindles, the way they’d carried on like royalty while decent folks got took. Tom listened, his eyes gleaming in the dark.

events.title: Aftermath of the Mob and Reflections on Conscience
detailed_summary: Huck and Tom realize they arrived too late to offer any assistance to the king and duke.

They inquire with some stragglers from the mob and learn that the townspeople had attended the show, appearing innocent, and then, at a signal, rose up against the performers when the king was mid-act.
Dejected, Huck and Tom walk back home.
Huck feels less bold than before, experiencing a sense of humility, orneriness, and inexplicable blame, despite not having done anything wrong.

We see we was too late—couldn’t do no good. We asked some stragglers about it, and they said everybody went to the show looking very innocent; and laid low and kept dark till the poor old king was in the middle of his cavortings on the stage; then somebody give a signal, and the house rose up and went for them.

Tom Sawyer he says the same.

events.title: Tom's Deductive Discovery and Plan Discrepancy
detailed_summary: After a period of silence and thought, Tom declares he knows Jim's location.
Tom deduces Jim is in the hut by the ash-hopper, reasoning from the observation of a Black man delivering food there, specifically watermelon, which he notes a dog would not eat.

He further infers Jim's status as a prisoner from the man unlocking and relocking the hut, and later fetching a key for Uncle Silas, concluding there's unlikely to be another prisoner on such a small, kind plantation.
Tom expresses satisfaction at arriving at this conclusion through 'detective fashion' and proposes that both he and Huck devise separate plans to free Jim, intending to choose the better one.
Huck, deeply admiring Tom's intellect, begins to formulate a plan, though primarily as a formality, as he already anticipates Tom's plan will be the one selected.

Huck presents his straightforward plan: confirm Jim's presence, retrieve his canoe and raft, steal the key from Uncle Silas's clothes while he sleeps, and then escape down the river with Jim, traveling by night and hiding by day.
Tom criticizes Huck's plan as far too simple and lacking any inherent challenge or excitement, comparing its ordinariness to 'breaking into a soap factory.'
Huck, expecting this reaction, remains silent, confident that Tom's eventual plan will be elaborate and adventurous.

Huck reflects that Tom's plan, while likely effective in freeing Jim, would also be far more stylish and potentially perilous, and he knew Tom would continuously alter and add 'bullinesses' to it as they proceeded.

We stopped talking, and got to thinking. By-and-by Tom says:
“Looky here, Huck, what fools we are to not think of it before! I bet I know where Jim is.”
“No! Where?”
“In that hut down by the ash-hopper. Why, looky here. When we was at dinner, didn’t you see a nigger man go in there with some vittles?”
“Yes.”
“What did you think the vittles was for?”
“For a dog.”
“So’d I. Well, it wasn’t for a dog.”
“Why?”
“Because part of it was watermelon.”
“So it was—I noticed it. Well, it does beat all that I never thought about a dog not eating watermelon. It shows how a body can see and don’t see at the same time.”
“Well, the nigger unlocked the padlock when he went in, and he locked it again when he came out. He fetched uncle a key about the time we got up from table—same key, I bet. Watermelon shows man, lock shows prisoner; and it ain’t likely there’s two prisoners on such a little plantation, and where the people’s all so kind and good. Jim’s the prisoner. All right—I’m glad we found it out detective fashion; I wouldn’t give shucks for any other way. Now you work your mind, and study out a plan to steal Jim, and I will study out one, too; and we’ll take the one we like the best.”
What a head for just a boy to have! If I had Tom Sawyer’s head I wouldn’t trade it off to be a duke, nor mate of a steamboat, nor clown in a circus, nor nothing I can think of. I went to thinking out a plan, but only just to be doing something; I knowed very well where the right plan was going to come from. Pretty soon Tom says:
“Ready?”
“Yes,” I says.
“All right—bring it out.”
“My plan is this,” I says. “We can easy find out if it’s Jim in there. Then get up my canoe to-morrow night, and fetch my raft over from the island. Then the first dark night that comes steal the key out of the old man’s britches after he goes to bed, and shove off down the river on the raft with Jim, hiding daytimes and running nights, the way me and Jim used to do before. Wouldn’t that plan work?”
“Work? Why, cert’nly it would work, like rats a-fighting. But it’s too blame’ simple; there ain’t nothing to it. What’s the good of a plan that ain’t no more trouble than that? It’s as mild as goose-milk. Why, Huck, it wouldn’t make no more talk than breaking into a soap factory.”
I never said nothing, because I warn’t expecting nothing different; but I knowed mighty well that whenever he got his plan ready it wouldn’t have none of them objections to it.
And it didn’t. He told me what it was, and I see in a minute it was worth fifteen of mine for style, and would make Jim just as free a man as mine would, and maybe get us all killed besides. So I was satisfied, and said we would waltz in on it. I needn’t tell what it was here, because I knowed it wouldn’t stay the way, it was. I knowed he would be changing it around every which way as we went along, and heaving in new bullinesses wherever he got a chance. And that is what he done.

Huck sat with his knees drawn up, chewing on a piece of grass, his face all scrunched up like he was working out some mighty troublesome puzzle. Finally, he spat out the grass and sighed. “Jim’s a good man, ain’t he?”  

I nodded. “Best I ever knew.”  

Huck scratched his head. “Then how come folks treat him like he ain’t even a person?”  

That was the question, wasn’t it? I’d heard all the reasons—laws and customs and such—but none of ‘em made a lick of sense when you really thought about it. Jim was kinder than most white folks I knew, braver too. He’d risked everything to get free, not just for himself, but for his family. And here we were, floating down the river like we didn’t have a care in the world, while Jim had to hide whenever another boat passed by.  

“I dunno, Huck,” I said at last. “Reckon some folks just don’t think too hard on it. They do what they’ve always done ‘cause it’s easier that way.”  

Huck scowled. “Well, that’s mighty lazy.”  

I couldn’t argue with that.  

We fell quiet again, the weight of it all pressing down on us. It was one thing to help Jim when it was just the three of us on the raft, away from the rest of the world. But sooner or later, we’d have to face that world again, and I wasn’t sure how we’d explain ourselves then.  

Huck must’ve been thinking the same thing, ‘cause after a while he said, “You ever get the feeling we’re doing something wrong by helping him?”  

I looked at him sharp. “You think it’s wrong?”  

He shook his head quick. “No, sir. But folks’d say it is.”  

“Folks say a lot of things,” I muttered.  

Huck nodded slow, like he was turning it over in his mind. Then he looked me square in the eye, his face set hard. “Well, I reckon if helping Jim’s wrong, I don’t wanna be right.”  

That settled it for me too. We might not have had all the answers, but we knew one thing for certain—Jim was our friend, and we weren’t about to let him down.  

The fire had burned low, so we kicked dirt over it and stretched out on the raft. The river rocked us gentle, and before long, Huck was snoring soft beside me. But I stayed awake a while longer, watching the stars and thinking about the road ahead.  

One way or another, we’d see this through.

events.title: Huck's Astonishment at Tom's Commitment to Freeing Jim
detailed_summary: Huck is certain of Tom's genuine intention to help free Jim, a realization that deeply perplexes him.

He contemplates Tom's respectable upbringing, good character, intelligence, and kind nature, finding it incomprehensible that Tom would stoop to an act that would bring shame upon himself and his family.
Huck feels a moral obligation as Tom's friend to intervene and persuade him to abandon the risky endeavor to save Tom from the consequences.
However, when Huck attempts to express his concerns, Tom quickly dismisses him, asserting his own competence and awareness of his actions.
Tom firmly reminds Huck of his declared commitment to help steal Jim, effectively ending the discussion.
Huck, still baffled by Tom's willingness to engage in such a serious undertaking, decides to let the matter rest, acknowledging Tom's unshakeable resolve.

“Yes.”

events.title: Nighttime Reconnaissance and Tom's Preference for Complication
detailed_summary: Later, with the house quiet and dark, Huck and Tom proceed to the hut by the ash-hopper for an inspection.
They navigate the yard, and the hounds, recognizing them, do not raise an alarm.
Upon examining the cabin, they find a square window hole on the north side, covered by a single stout board.
Huck immediately identifies this as a viable escape route if they remove the board.
Tom dismisses this idea as too simplistic, expressing a desire for a more complex solution.

Huck then suggests sawing Jim out, referencing a past elaborate deception of his own, which Tom finds more appealing for its 'mysterious and troublesome' qualities, yet he still hopes for an even more time-consuming method.
They discover a lean-to structure at the back of the hut, padlocked at its south-end door.
Tom uses an iron tool from the soap-kettle to pry out a staple, allowing them to enter the lean-to.
Inside, they find the shed is not connected to the main cabin, has no floor, and contains only old, discarded tools.

Despite the shed not offering direct access, Tom is pleased and declares their method will be to dig Jim out, a process he estimates will take about a week, satisfying his need for a grand, elaborate scheme.

Upon returning to the house, Tom eschews the simple back door Huck uses, insisting on a 'romantical' entrance by climbing the lightning rod, which he achieves only after several clumsy and painful failures.

When we got home the house was all dark and still; so we went on down to the hut by the ash-hopper for to examine it. We went through the yard so as to see what the hounds would do. They knowed us, and didn’t make no more noise than country dogs is always doing when anything comes by in the night. When we got to the cabin we took a look at the front and the two sides; and on the side I warn’t acquainted with—which was the north side—we found a square window-hole, up tolerable high, with just one stout board nailed across it. I says:
“Here’s the ticket. This hole’s big enough for Jim to get through if we wrench off the board.”
Tom says:
“It’s as simple as tit-tat-toe, three-in-a-row, and as easy as playing hooky. I should hope we can find a way that’s a little more complicated than that, Huck Finn.”
“Well, then,” I says, “how’ll it do to saw him out, the way I done before I was murdered that time?”
“That’s more like,” he says. “It’s real mysterious, and troublesome, and good,” he says; “but I bet we can find a way that’s twice as long. There ain’t no hurry; le’s keep on looking around.”
Betwixt the hut and the fence, on the back side, was a lean-to that joined the hut at the eaves, and was made out of plank. It was as long as the hut, but narrow—only about six foot wide. The door to it was at the south end, and was padlocked. Tom he went to the soap-kettle and searched around, and fetched back the iron thing they lift the lid with; so he took it and prized out one of the staples. The chain fell down, and we opened the door and went in, and shut it, and struck a match, and see the shed was only built against a cabin and hadn’t no connection with it; and there warn’t no floor to the shed, nor nothing in it but some old rusty played-out hoes and spades and picks and a crippled plow. The match went out, and so did we, and shoved in the staple again, and the door was locked as good as ever. Tom was joyful. He says;
“Now we’re all right. We’ll dig him out. It’ll take about a week!”
Then we started for the house, and I went in the back door—you only have to pull a buckskin latch-string, they don’t fasten the doors—but that warn’t romantical enough for Tom Sawyer; no way would do him but he must climb up the lightning-rod. But after he got up half way about three times, and missed fire and fell every time, and the last time most busted his brains out, he thought he’d got to give it up; but after he was rested he allowed he would give her one more turn for luck, and this time he made the trip.

When we got home the house was all dark and still; so we went on down to the hut by the ash-hopper for to examine it. The night was thick with shadows, and the only sound was the rustling of leaves in the faint breeze. Jim and I crept along careful-like, not wanting to wake a soul. The hut stood lonesome at the edge of the yard, its door hanging crooked on its hinges, like it was too tired to stay shut proper.

I pushed the door open slow, and it let out a groan that made my skin crawl. Inside, the air was heavy with the smell of damp wood and old ashes. The moonlight slipped in through the cracks in the walls, painting silver stripes on the dirt floor. Jim held up the lantern we’d brought, and the light flickered over the rough planks and the pile of rags in the corner where Pap used to sleep.

“Ain’t nobody been here in a spell,” Jim whispered, his voice low and steady. I nodded, but my heart was thumping like a rabbit’s. There was something about the place that set my nerves on edge—maybe it was the memories of Pap’s drunken rages, or maybe it was just the quiet, like the whole world was holding its breath.

I stepped further in, my boots scuffing against the floor. Then I saw it—a bottle lying on its side near the ashes, still wet with whiskey. My stomach twisted. Pap had been here, and not long ago. Jim saw it too, and his eyes met mine in the lantern light. We didn’t need words to know what the other was thinking.

“Reckon he’ll be back?” Jim asked after a minute.

I swallowed hard. “Don’t know. But we best not stick around to find out.”

Just then, a noise outside made us both freeze. It was a soft crunch, like a footstep on dry leaves. Jim blew out the lantern quick, plunging us into darkness. We stood there, not daring to breathe, listening. The sound came again, closer this time. My fingers found Jim’s arm in the dark, and I could feel him trembling same as me.

Then—a low, raspy voice, slurred with drink: “Who’s in there?”

It was Pap. No mistaking that voice, rough as a saw blade. My blood turned to ice. Jim’s grip on my arm tightened, and I knew we were thinking the same thing: if Pap found us here, there’d be hell to pay.

The door creaked open wider, and a shadow filled the doorway. I could smell the whiskey on him before I even saw his face. He swayed there a second, then took a step inside. Jim and I pressed back against the wall, hoping the darkness would hide us.

“Ain’t nobody here but the rats,” Pap muttered to himself. But he didn’t sound too sure. He took another step, and his boot kicked the empty bottle. It clattered across the floor, loud as a gunshot in the quiet.

That was all we needed. While Pap was cussing and stumbling after the noise, Jim and I slipped out the back way, running like the devil himself was on our heels. We didn’t stop till we were deep in the woods, the hut and Pap long behind us. 

Panting, I looked at Jim in the moonlight. “That was too close,” I said.

Jim just nodded, his face serious. “We best lay low awhile, Huck. Your Pap ain’t done with us yet.” 

And I knew he was right.

events.title: Encounter at the Hut and Tom's Deceptive Maneuvers
detailed_summary: At dawn, Tom and Huck visit the slave cabins to interact with the dogs and befriend the Black man responsible for feeding Jim, assuming it is indeed Jim being fed.
The man, Nat, appears good-natured but is deeply superstitious, his hair tied in bunches to ward off witches, whom he claims are severely pestering him.
When Tom asks about the food Nat is carrying, Nat replies with a slow smile that it is for a 'curious dog' and invites the boys to see it.
Huck whispers his concern to Tom about deviating from their plan by entering the hut in daylight, but Tom declares this is the new plan.
Inside the dimly lit hut, Jim immediately recognizes the boys and exclaims their names.
Nat, startled, questions how the 'runaway nigger' knows them.
Tom quickly feigns ignorance and bewilderment, asking who called out and what was said, then calmly asks Huck if he heard anything.
Huck plays along, denying that he heard anyone speak.
Tom then questions Jim, who, grasping the situation, also denies having spoken or having seen the boys before.
Tom attributes Nat's perception of voices to 'witches,' further playing on Nat's superstitions and distress.
Tom gives Nat a dime, advising him to buy more thread for his hair to protect against witches, and assures him they won't mention his troubles.

While Nat is momentarily distracted by the dime, Tom quickly whispers to Jim, instructing him not to reveal their acquaintance and to listen for digging sounds at night, signifying their rescue efforts.
Jim manages a brief, grateful squeeze of their hands before Nat returns.
Nat expresses his willingness for the boys to visit again, especially after dark, as he believes company helps deter the witches that trouble him most at night.

events.text_segment:
In the morning we was up at break of day, and down to the nigger cabins to pet the dogs and make friends with the nigger that fed Jim—if it was Jim that was being fed. The niggers was just getting through breakfast and starting for the fields; and Jim’s nigger was piling up a tin pan with bread and meat and things; and whilst the others was leaving, the key come from the house.
This nigger had a good-natured, chuckle-headed face, and his wool was all tied up in little bunches with thread. That was to keep witches off. He said the witches was pestering him awful these nights, and making him see all kinds of strange things, and hear all kinds of strange words and noises, and he didn’t believe he was ever witched so long before in his life. He got so worked up, and got to running on so about his troubles, he forgot all about what he’d been a-going to do. So Tom says:
“What’s the vittles for? Going to feed the dogs?”
The nigger kind of smiled around gradually over his face, like when you heave a brickbat in a mud-puddle, and he says:
“Yes, Mars Sid, a dog. Cur’us dog, too. Does you want to go en look at ’im?”
“Yes.”
I hunched Tom, and whispers:
“You going, right here in the daybreak? That warn’t the plan.”
“No, it warn’t; but it’s the plan now.”
So, drat him, we went along, but I didn’t like it much. When we got in we couldn’t hardly see anything, it was so dark; but Jim was there, sure enough, and could see us; and he sings out:
“Why, Huck! En good lan’! ain’ dat Misto Tom?”
I just knowed how it would be; I just expected it. I didn’t know nothing to do; and if I had I couldn’t a done it, because that nigger busted in and says:
“Why, de gracious sakes! do he know you genlmen?”
We could see pretty well now. Tom he looked at the nigger, steady and kind of wondering, and says:
“Does who know us?”
“Why, dis-yer runaway nigger.”
“I don’t reckon he does; but what put that into your head?”
“What put it dar? Didn’ he jis’ dis minute sing out like he knowed you?”
Tom says, in a puzzled-up kind of way:
“Well, that’s mighty curious. Who sung out? When did he sing out? what did he sing out?” And turns to me, perfectly ca’m, and says, “Did you hear anybody sing out?”
Of course there warn’t nothing to be said but the one thing; so I says:
“No; I ain’t heard nobody say nothing.”
Then he turns to Jim, and looks him over like he never see him before, and says:
“Did you sing out?”
“No, sah,” says Jim; “I hain’t said nothing, sah.”
“Not a word?”
“No, sah, I hain’t said a word.”
“Did you ever see us before?”
“No, sah; not as I knows on.”
So Tom turns to the nigger, which was looking wild and distressed, and says, kind of severe:
“What do you reckon’s the matter with you, anyway? What made you think somebody sung out?”
“Oh, it’s de dad-blame’ witches, sah, en I wisht I was dead, I do. Dey’s awluz at it, sah, en dey do mos’ kill me, dey sk’yers me so. Please to don’t tell nobody ’bout it sah, er ole Mars Silas he’ll scole me; ’kase he say dey ain’t no witches. I jis’ wish to goodness he was heah now—den what would he say! I jis’ bet he couldn’ fine no way to git aroun’ it dis time. But it’s awluz jis’ so; people dat’s sot, stays sot; dey won’t look into noth’n’en fine it out f’r deyselves, en when you fine it out en tell um ’bout it, dey doan’ b’lieve you.”
Tom give him a dime, and said we wouldn’t tell nobody; and told him to buy some more thread to tie up his wool with; and then looks at Jim, and says:
“I wonder if Uncle Silas is going to hang this nigger. If I was to catch a nigger that was ungrateful enough to run away, I wouldn’t give him up, I’d hang him.” And whilst the nigger stepped to the door to look at the dime and bite it to see if it was good, he whispers to Jim and says:
“Don’t ever let on to know us. And if you hear any digging going on nights, it’s us; we’re going to set you free.”
Jim only had time to grab us by the hand and squeeze it; then the nigger come back, and we said we’d come again some time if the nigger wanted us to; and he said he would, more particular if it was dark, because the witches went for him mostly in the dark, and it was good to have folks around then.

"You boys is up mighty early," he said.

The old man’s eyes flickered, but he didn’t let on much. "Ain’t no runaway nigger here," he said. "Just a thief what stole a ham from Massa’s smokehouse."  

I felt a twist in my belly. If that was Jim, he was in a worse fix than we thought. But Tom, he just grinned like it was all a game.  

"Well, we’d like to see him anyhow," Tom said. "We got a mind to help guard him, make sure he don’t get loose."  

The old nigger studied us again, then shrugged. "Suit yourselves. He’s in the shed yonder, chained to the wall."  

We made our way to the shed, a low, mean little building with a heavy padlock on the door. The old man fished a key from his pocket and swung the door open. Inside, it was dark and musty, and for a second I couldn’t see nothing. Then my eyes adjusted, and there was Jim, sitting on the dirt floor with his back against the wall, his wrists and ankles chained.  

He looked up when we come in, and his face went slack with surprise. Then he caught himself and dropped his eyes, like he didn’t know us.  

Tom, quick as a snake, played along. "Well, look at this big, ugly thief," he said, loud enough for the old nigger to hear. "Reckon he’ll steal again, chained up like this."  

Jim didn’t say nothing, just kept his head down. The old nigger stood in the doorway, watching.  

"We’ll keep an eye on him," Tom said. "You go on about your business."  

For a minute, I thought the old man wouldn’t leave, but finally he nodded and shuffled off. Soon as he was gone, Jim looked up, his eyes wide.  

"Marse Tom! Marse Huck! What you boys doin’ here?"  

"We come to get you out," Tom whispered. "But we got to be careful. That old man might be listening."  

Jim’s face twisted up like he was about to cry. "Oh, Lordy, I thought I was done for. They caught me ’bout two days back, been whuppin’ me regular."  

I felt sick hearing that, but Tom was all business. "We got a plan," he said. "But it’s gonna take time. You just hang on, and don’t let on you know us."  

Jim nodded, swallowing hard. "I’ll do whatever you say."  

We stayed a little longer, talking low, making sure Jim understood what was coming. Then we left, careful to act like we was just two white boys keeping an eye on a runaway nigger.  

Outside, the sun was full up, and the plantation was coming alive. Niggers was heading out to the fields, and the overseer was hollering orders. We slipped away, back to the woods where we’d camped, to figure out our next move.  

Tom was grinning like a possum. "This is gonna be the best adventure yet," he said.

events.title: Gathering Fox-fire and Tom's Frustration with Simplicity
detailed_summary: With breakfast an hour away, Huck and Tom ventured into the woods to gather fox-fire for a subtle light source, as Tom deemed lanterns too risky.
After collecting an armful of the glowing wood and hiding it, Tom expressed his dissatisfaction with the straightforward nature of Jim's current confinement.
He lamented the lack of typical escape-story obstacles, such as a watchman to drug or a dog to give a sleeping potion to.
Tom pointed out the ease with which Jim's chain could be removed from the bedstead and criticized Uncle Silas's trusting nature for not posting a guard.
He noted that Jim's only real impediment was the ten-foot chain itself, making escape otherwise too simple.
Tom concluded that they would have to invent all the difficulties themselves to make the escape honorable and challenging.
He considered it more prestigious to overcome self-created obstacles when none were provided by Jim's captors.
As an example, he stated they must pretend a lantern is risky, even though they could probably use a torchlight procession without issue.
He then declared their immediate need to find material for a saw.

events.text_segment:
It would be most an hour yet till breakfast, so we left and struck down into the woods; because Tom said we got to have some light to see how to dig by, and a lantern makes too much, and might get us into trouble; what we must have was a lot of them rotten chunks that’s called fox-fire, and just makes a soft kind of a glow when you lay them in a dark place. We fetched an armful and hid it in the weeds, and set down to rest, and Tom says, kind of dissatisfied:
“Blame it, this whole thing is just as easy and awkward as it can be. And so it makes it so rotten difficult to get up a difficult plan. There ain’t no watchman to be drugged—now there ought to be a watchman. There ain’t even a dog to give a sleeping-mixture to. And there’s Jim chained by one leg, with a ten-foot chain, to the leg of his bed: why, all you got to do is to lift up the bedstead and slip off the chain. And Uncle Silas he trusts everybody; sends the key to the punkin-headed nigger, and don’t send nobody to watch the nigger. Jim could a got out of that window-hole before this, only there wouldn’t be no use trying to travel with a ten-foot chain on his leg. Why, drat it, Huck, it’s the stupidest arrangement I ever see. You got to invent all the difficulties. Well, we can’t help it; we got to do the best we can with the materials we’ve got. Anyhow, there’s one thing—there’s more honor in getting him out through a lot of difficulties and dangers, where there warn’t one of them furnished to you by the people who it was their duty to furnish them, and you had to contrive them all out of your own head. Now look at just that one thing of the lantern. When you come down to the cold facts, we simply got to let on that a lantern’s resky. Why, we could work with a torchlight procession if we wanted to, I believe. Now, whilst I think of it, we got to hunt up something to make a saw out of the first chance we get.”

events.title: Tom's Elaborate, Book-Inspired Escape Fantasies
detailed_summary: Huck questioned the necessity of a saw.
Tom, invoking adventure novels, explained they needed to saw the leg of Jim's bed to free the chain, rather than simply lifting the bedstead.
Huck pointed out Tom's earlier observation that the chain could be slipped off by lifting the bed.
Tom chided Huck for his simplistic, 'infant-school' approach, asking if he'd ever read adventure stories featuring heroes like Baron Trenck or Casanova.

He asserted that respected authorities in escape narratives always saw the bed-leg in two, conceal the act by swallowing sawdust and camouflaging the cut, then kick the leg to break it on the night of escape.

Tom enthusiastically described a dramatic escape sequence involving rope ladders, moats (lamenting the cabin's lack thereof), horses, and loyal vassals, culminating in a flight to a romanticized foreign land.
He declared such an escape 'gaudy' and expressed a wish for a moat, suggesting they might dig one if time permitted.

events.text_segment:
“What do we want of a saw?”
“What do we want of it? Hain’t we got to saw the leg of Jim’s bed off, so as to get the chain loose?”
“Why, you just said a body could lift up the bedstead and slip the chain off.”
“Well, if that ain’t just like you, Huck Finn. You can get up the infant-schooliest ways of going at a thing. Why, hain’t you ever read any books at all?—Baron Trenck, nor Casanova, nor Benvenuto Chelleeny, nor Henri IV., nor none of them heroes? Who ever heard of getting a prisoner loose in such an old-maidy way as that? No; the way all the best authorities does is to saw the bed-leg in two, and leave it just so, and swallow the sawdust, so it can’t be found, and put some dirt and grease around the sawed place so the very keenest seneskal can’t see no sign of it’s being sawed, and thinks the bed-leg is perfectly sound. Then, the night you’re ready, fetch the leg a kick, down she goes; slip off your chain, and there you are. Nothing to do but hitch your rope ladder to the battlements, shin down it, break your leg in the moat—because a rope ladder is nineteen foot too short, you know—and there’s your horses and your trusty vassles, and they scoop you up and fling you across a saddle, and away you go to your native Langudoc, or Navarre, or wherever it is. It’s gaudy, Huck. I wish there was a moat to this cabin. If we get time, the night of the escape, we’ll dig one.”

“What do we want of a saw?” I asked, scratching my head.  

Tom Sawyer looked at me like I was the dumbest creature he’d ever laid eyes on. “Why, to saw Jim’s chain off, of course!”  

“But ain’t there a better way?” I said. “Seems to me a file would do the job quicker and quieter.”  

Tom sighed like I was testing his patience something awful. “Huck Finn, you got no imagination. This ain’t just about gettin’ Jim free—it’s about doin’ it right, like in the books. Prisoners always saw their way out. It’s the romantic way!”  

I reckoned Tom had read too many of them adventure stories again. “Seems to me the quickest way’s the best way,” I muttered.  

“Quick ain’t the point!” Tom said, waving his arms. “We got to make it an ordeal, full of hardship and danger. Why, if we just filed through that chain in five minutes, where’s the glory in that?”  

I didn’t see much glory in sawing for hours either, but I knew better than to argue once Tom got an idea stuck in his head. He’d just keep talking circles around me till I gave in.  

“All right,” I said, “but where we gonna get a saw?”

events.title: Debating Morbid Escape Tropes and the Necessity of a Rope Ladder
detailed_summary: Huck questioned the purpose of a moat since their plan was to extract Jim from beneath the cabin.
Tom, lost in thought, initially ignored Huck.
He then sighed, stating that a particular idea wouldn't work due to insufficient necessity.
When Huck inquired further, Tom revealed he was contemplating sawing off Jim's leg, citing precedents from 'best authorities' who amputated their own hands to escape chains.
Huck reacted with alarm, exclaiming there was no need for such a drastic measure.
Tom conceded that sawing off Jim's leg wasn't strictly necessary in this case and added that Jim, being a 'nigger,' wouldn't grasp the European customs behind such acts, so they would forgo it.
However, Tom insisted Jim must have a rope ladder, which they could make from torn sheets and deliver in a pie, as this was a common method in stories.
Huck argued that Jim had no use for a rope ladder.
Tom countered vehemently, stating Jim absolutely needed one because it was standard procedure for all prisoners in stories.
When Huck asked what Jim would do with it, Tom explained he could hide it in his bed, providing a clue for their pursuers after the escape, emphasizing the importance of leaving such clues.

“Why, to saw Jim’s leg off,” he says.

And I’ve et worse pies.”
“Why, Tom Sawyer, how you talk,” I says; “Jim ain’t got no use for a rope ladder.”
“He has got use for it. How you talk, you better say; you don’t know nothing about it. He’s got to have a rope ladder; they all do.”
“What in the nation can he do with it?”
“Do with it? He can hide it in his bed, can’t he?” That’s what they all do; and he’s got to, too. Huck, you don’t ever seem to want to do anything that’s regular; you want to be starting something fresh all the time. S’pose he don’t do nothing with it? ain’t it there in his bed, for a clew, after he’s gone? and don’t you reckon they’ll want clews? Of course they will. And you wouldn’t leave them any? That would be a pretty howdy-do, wouldn’t it! I never heard of such a thing.”

events.title: Practicalities vs. Regulations: Sheets, Shirts, and Prisoner Pens
detailed_summary: Huck acquiesced to the rope ladder if regulations demanded it, but worried about Aunt Sally's reaction to torn sheets.
He pragmatically suggested using a hickory-bark ladder, which would be free, waste nothing, and serve the same purpose of being hidden in a pie.
Tom dismissed Huck's idea as ignorant, questioning who ever heard of a state prisoner escaping with such a ladder, calling it ridiculous.
Huck relented, telling Tom to arrange it his way, but advised borrowing a sheet from the clothesline to avoid trouble.
This gave Tom another idea: to also borrow a shirt for Jim to use as a journal.
Huck pointed out that Jim couldn't write.
Tom countered that Jim could make marks on the shirt if they fashioned a pen from an old pewter spoon or iron barrel-hoop.
Huck suggested a goose feather would make a better and quicker pen.

Tom rejected this, explaining that prisoners in stories don't have access to geese and always make pens from difficult materials like brass candlesticks, a process taking months, because it's the 'regular' way.

“Well,” I says, “if it’s in the regulations, and he’s got to have it, all right, let him have it; because I don’t wish to go back on no regulations; but there’s one thing, Tom Sawyer—if we go to tearing up our sheets to make Jim a rope ladder, we’re going to get into trouble with Aunt Sally, just as sure as you’re born. Now, the way I look at it, a hickry-bark ladder don’t cost nothing, and don’t waste nothing, and is just as good to load up a pie with, and hide in a straw tick, as any rag ladder you can start; and as for Jim, he ain’t had no experience, and so he don’t care what kind of a—”
“Oh, shucks, Huck Finn, if I was as ignorant as you I’d keep still—that’s what I’d do. Who ever heard of a state prisoner escaping by a hickry-bark ladder? Why, it’s perfectly ridiculous.”
“Well, all right, Tom, fix it your own way; but if you’ll take my advice, you’ll let me borrow a sheet off of the clothesline.”
He said that would do. And that gave him another idea, and he says:
“Borrow a shirt, too.”
“What do we want of a shirt, Tom?”
“Want it for Jim to keep a journal on.”
“Journal your granny—Jim can’t write.”
“S’pose he can’t write—he can make marks on the shirt, can’t he, if we make him a pen out of an old pewter spoon or a piece of an old iron barrel-hoop?”
“Why, Tom, we can pull a feather out of a goose and make him a better one; and quicker, too.”
“Prisoners don’t have geese running around the donjon-keep to pull pens out of, you muggins. They always make their pens out of the hardest, toughest, troublesomest piece of old brass candlestick or something like that they can get their hands on; and it takes them weeks and weeks and months and months to file it out, too, because they’ve got to do it by rubbing it on the wall. They wouldn’t use a goose-quill if they had it. It ain’t regular.”
