“Well, it always is when it’s done right. You got any rats around here?”  

I looked around the old cabin, scratching my head. “Reckon there might be a few,” I said. “Why?”  

The stranger—a tall, lanky fellow with a sharp nose and eyes that darted around like a squirrel’s—grinned. “Why, I’m the best rat-catcher in three counties, that’s why. Name’s Jedediah Jones, but folks just call me Rat-Killer Jed.”  

I couldn’t help but laugh. “Rat-Killer Jed? That’s a mighty peculiar name.”  

He shrugged. “Ain’t no more peculiar than a boy livin’ in a cabin all by his lonesome. Where’s your folks?”  

I shuffled my feet. “Ain’t got none.”  

Jed’s grin faded a little, but he nodded like he understood. “Well, then, reckon you could use a hand with them rats. They’ll eat you out of house and home if you let ‘em.”  

I didn’t much care about rats, but Jed seemed harmless enough, and I was curious about his trade. “How do you catch ‘em?” I asked.  

He reached into his coat and pulled out a small wooden box with a wire contraption inside. “This here’s my secret weapon. Ain’t no rat alive can resist it.”  

I leaned in for a closer look. “What’s in it?”  

“Cheese,” he said, like it was the most obvious thing in the world. “But not just any cheese—special cheese. Got a smell to it that drives ‘em wild.”  

I sniffed the air but didn’t smell nothing. “Don’t seem all that special to me.”  

Jed winked. “That’s ‘cause you ain’t a rat.”  

He set the trap down in the corner of the cabin and motioned for me to step back. “Now we wait.”  

We didn’t have to wait long. Within minutes, a fat brown rat came scurrying out from under the stove, its nose twitching. It sniffed the air, then made a beeline for the trap.  

*Snap!*  

The wire slammed shut, and the rat was caught fast. Jed whooped and clapped his hands. “Told ya! Ain’t no rat can resist Jedediah Jones!”  

I had to admit, it was impressive. “How much you charge for a job like this?”  

He rubbed his chin. “For you? Free of charge. Consider it a neighborly favor.”  

I frowned. “Ain’t no such thing as a free favor.”  

Jed laughed. “Smart boy. Tell you what—you help me catch a few more, and I’ll teach you the trade. Might come in handy one day.”  

I reckoned it couldn’t hurt to learn something new, so I agreed. For the next hour, we set traps and caught rats, Jed spinning tall tales between each snap of the wire. He told me about the time he caught a rat so big it nearly dragged him into the river, and another time he outsmarted a whole pack of ‘em that had been stealing from a general store.  

Finally, when the last rat was caught, Jed packed up his traps and tipped his hat. “You’re a quick learner, son. If you ever take a fancy to the rat-killin’ business, you look me up.”  

I nodded. “Much obliged, Jed.”  

He grinned one last time and disappeared into the woods, whistling a tune.  

I sat back down by the fire, thinking about the strange afternoon. Maybe rat-catching wasn’t such a bad trade after all. At least it was honest work—and a sight better than some of the schemes I’d been mixed up in before.  

Then again, I reckoned I’d stick to floating down the river for now. There’s something to be said for a life without rats—or rat-catchers.  

But just in case, I tucked one of Jed’s traps under the bed. You never know when a skill like that might come in handy.

events.title: Rat-Trap Trouble and Creature Chaos
characters: Thomas Franklin Benjamin Jefferson Elexander Phelps
detailed_summary: Huck and Tom procure a wire rat-trap and catch fifteen rats, which they place under Aunt Sally's bed.
While they are away collecting spiders, young Thomas Franklin Benjamin Jefferson Elexander Phelps discovers the trap and opens it, releasing the rats.
Aunt Sally encounters the freed rats and reacts with great alarm, standing on her bed in distress.
Upon their return, Huck and Tom are disciplined by Aunt Sally with a hickory switch for the incident.
They spend another two hours catching a new batch of rats, though these are not of the same quality as the first.
The boys also gather an assortment of spiders, bugs, frogs, and caterpillars.
Their attempt to acquire a hornet's nest is thwarted by the family at home, resulting in the boys getting stung.
They apply 'allycumpain' to their stings for relief, though sitting remains uncomfortable.
Subsequently, they collect several dozen garter and house snakes, placing them in a bag in their room.
By suppertime, they reflect on their busy day, but later find the snakes have escaped due to an improperly tied sack.
The escaped snakes become a recurring nuisance in the house, frequently appearing in unexpected places like rafters, plates, or down people's necks.
Aunt Sally exhibits an extreme aversion to snakes, regardless of their harmlessness, and would flee dramatically at the sight of one.
Her reactions are so intense that she frightens her husband, who wishes snakes had never been created.
Even a week after all snakes were thought to be gone, Aunt Sally remained highly sensitive, startled by the slightest touch.
Tom remarks that such reactions are typical of all women, attributing it to their inherent nature.

events.text_segment:
In the morning we went up to the village and bought a wire rat-trap and fetched it down, and unstopped the best rat-hole, and in about an hour we had fifteen of the bulliest kind of ones; and then we took it and put it in a safe place under Aunt Sally’s bed. But while we was gone for spiders little Thomas Franklin Benjamin Jefferson Elexander Phelps found it there, and opened the door of it to see if the rats would come out, and they did; and Aunt Sally she come in, and when we got back she was a-standing on top of the bed raising Cain, and the rats was doing what they could to keep off the dull times for her. So she took and dusted us both with the hickry, and we was as much as two hours catching another fifteen or sixteen, drat that meddlesome cub, and they warn’t the likeliest, nuther, because the first haul was the pick of the flock. I never see a likelier lot of rats than what that first haul was.
We got a splendid stock of sorted spiders, and bugs, and frogs, and caterpillars, and one thing or another; and we like to got a hornet’s nest, but we didn’t. The family was at home. We didn’t give it right up, but stayed with them as long as we could; because we allowed we’d tire them out or they’d got to tire us out, and they done it. Then we got allycumpain and rubbed on the places, and was pretty near all right again, but couldn’t set down convenient. And so we went for the snakes, and grabbed a couple of dozen garters and house-snakes, and put them in a bag, and put it in our room, and by that time it was supper-time, and a rattling good honest day’s work: and hungry?—oh, no, I reckon not! And there warn’t a blessed snake up there when we went back—we didn’t half tie the sack, and they worked out somehow, and left. But it didn’t matter much, because they was still on the premises somewheres. So we judged we could get some of them again. No, there warn’t no real scarcity of snakes about the house for a considerable spell. You’d see them dripping from the rafters and places every now and then; and they generly landed in your plate, or down the back of your neck, and most of the time where you didn’t want them. Well, they was handsome and striped, and there warn’t no harm in a million of them; but that never made no difference to Aunt Sally; she despised snakes, be the breed what they might, and she couldn’t stand them no way you could fix it; and every time one of them flopped down on her, it didn’t make no difference what she was doing, she would just lay that work down and light out. I never see such a woman. And you could hear her whoop to Jericho. You couldn’t get her to take a-holt of one of them with the tongs. And if she turned over and found one in bed she would scramble out and lift a howl that you would think the house was afire. She disturbed the old man so that he said he could most wish there hadn’t ever been no snakes created. Why, after every last snake had been gone clear out of the house for as much as a week Aunt Sally warn’t over it yet; she warn’t near over it; when she was setting thinking about something you could touch her on the back of her neck with a feather and she would jump right out of her stockings. It was very curious. But Tom said all women was just so. He said they was made that way for some reason or other.

We got a licking every time one of our snakes come in her way, and she allowed these lickings warn’t nothing to what she would do if we ever loaded up the place again with them. I didn’t mind the lickings, because they didn’t amount to nothing; but I minded the trouble we had to lay in another lot. Jim didn’t like the spiders, and the spiders didn’t like Jim; and so they’d lay for him, and make it mighty warm for him. And he said that between the rats and the snakes and the grindstone there warn’t no room in bed for him, skasely; and when there was, a body couldn’t sleep, it was so lively, and it was always lively, he said, because they never all slept at one time, but took turn about, so when the snakes was asleep the rats was on deck, and when the rats turned in the snakes come on watch, so he always had one gang under him, in his way, and t’other gang having a circus over him, and if he got up to hunt a new place the spiders would take a chance at him as he crossed over. He said if he ever got out this time he wouldn’t ever be a prisoner again, not for a salary.
Well, by the end of three weeks everything was in pretty good shape. The shirt was sent in early, in a pie, and every time a rat bit Jim he would get up and write a little in his journal whilst the ink was fresh; the pens was made, the inscriptions and so on was all carved on the grindstone; the bed-leg was sawed in two, and we had et up the sawdust, and it give us a most amazing stomach-ache. We reckoned we was all going to die, but didn’t. It was the most undigestible sawdust I ever see; and Tom said the same.

So he said, now for the grand bulge! So the very next morning at the streak of dawn we got another letter ready, and was wondering what we better do with it, because we heard them say at supper they was going to have a nigger on watch at both doors all night. Tom he went down the lightning-rod to spy around; and the nigger at the back door was asleep, and he stuck it in the back of his neck and come back. This letter said:
Don’t betray me, I wish to be your friend. There is a desprate gang of cutthroats from over in the Indian Territory going to steal your runaway nigger to-night, and they have been trying to scare you so as you will stay in the house and not bother them. I am one of the gang, but have got religgion and wish to quit it and lead an honest life again, and will betray the helish design. They will sneak down from northards, along the fence, at midnight exact, with a false key, and go in the nigger’s cabin to get him. I am to be off a piece and blow a tin horn if I see any danger; but stead of that I will BA like a sheep soon as they get in and not blow at all; then whilst they are getting his chains loose, you slip there and lock them in, and can kill them at your leasure. Don’t do anything but just the way I am telling you, if you do they will suspicion something and raise whoop-jamboreehoo. I do not wish any reward but to know I have done the right thing.
UNKNOWN FRIEND

At the first light of dawn, the boys set to work, scribbling another ominous warning. They hesitated only briefly—rumors of guards posted at both doors had reached them. But Tom, ever the bold strategist, shimmied down the lightning rod to scout the situation. 

Peering around the corner, he spotted the guard at the back door slumped in sleep, his head lolling forward. A wicked grin spread across Tom’s face. Creeping closer, he slipped the folded letter beneath the man’s collar, where it nestled against his neck like a spider. Mission accomplished, Tom retreated, heart pounding. 

The letter, signed once more by that mysterious 'UNKNOWN FRIEND,' spun a tale of redemption and treachery. Its writer claimed to be a reformed outlaw, now seeking salvation by exposing his former gang’s wicked plot. That very night, he warned, a band of ruthless cutthroats from the Indian Territory would come for Jim. 

All the earlier frights—the cryptic notes, the bloodstained warnings—had been mere distractions, meant to keep the Phelpses cowering inside while the thieves worked. Now, with midnight approaching, the gang would creep along the north fence, unlock Jim’s cabin with a counterfeit key, and spirit him away. 

But the informant had a plan. His role was to sound a tin horn if danger neared—yet he vowed instead to bleat like a sheep ("BA!") once the villains were inside. No alarm would come. The family must wait, then tiptoe to the cabin, trap the gang within, and—here the letter grew grim—"kill them at your leasure." 

"Don’t you stray from these orders," the writer urged. "One wrong step, and they’ll smell a rat. Then it’s a whoop-jamboreehoo for sure." He signed off, asking no reward but the peace of a clear conscience. 

Tom, back in the loft, could hardly contain his glee. The stage was set. Now came the grand bulge—the climax of their audacious scheme.

events.title: Caught by Aunt Sally and a Room Full of Farmers
detailed_summary: Following Tom's departure, Huck descended into the cellar to fetch the butter.
He successfully located the substantial piece of butter, which was as large as a fist, resting on the slab of corn-pone where he had originally placed it.
After extinguishing his light source, Huck began to ascend the stairs with extreme caution.
He managed to reach the main floor without incident, but at that moment, Aunt Sally appeared, carrying a candle.
Reacting quickly, Huck concealed the food items under his hat and placed the hat firmly on his head just as Aunt Sally caught sight of him.
Aunt Sally immediately began to question Huck about his reasons for being in the cellar at such a late hour.
Huck initially provided vague and unconvincing responses, claiming he was doing "nothing."
Aunt Sally, already agitated and suspicious due to a series of unusual recent events, pressed Huck (whom she still believed to be Tom) for a more truthful explanation.
Despite Huck's continued insistence that he had not been engaged in any improper activity, Aunt Sally remained unconvinced and suspicious.
She sternly ordered him to go into the sitting-room and wait there until she could deal with him, expressing her determination to uncover his mischief.
Upon entering the sitting-room, Huck was profoundly shocked to discover it occupied by approximately fifteen farmers, each of whom was armed with a gun.
He felt intensely ill and, overwhelmed by the sudden realization of how serious the situation had become, sank into a chair.

The farmers in the room appeared restless and uneasy; they were constantly fidgeting, taking their hats off and putting them back on, scratching their heads, and changing their seating positions, all while attempting to project an air of composure.
Huck, too, felt deeply uneasy but consciously made an effort to keep his own hat on his head.

So out he went, and down cellar went I. The hunk of butter, big as a person’s fist, was where I had left it, so I took up the slab of corn-pone with it on, and blowed out my light, and started up stairs very stealthy, and got up to the main floor all right, but here comes Aunt Sally with a candle, and I clapped the truck in my hat, and clapped my hat on my head, and the next second she see me; and she says:
“You been down cellar?”
“Yes’m.”
“What you been doing down there?”
“Noth’n.”
“Noth’n!”
“No’m.”
“Well, then, what possessed you to go down there this time of night?”
“I don’t know ’m.”
“You don’t know? Don’t answer me that way. Tom, I want to know what you been doing down there.”
“I hain’t been doing a single thing, Aunt Sally, I hope to gracious if I have.”
I reckoned she’d let me go now, and as a generl thing she would; but I s’pose there was so many strange things going on she was just in a sweat about every little thing that warn’t yard-stick straight; so she says, very decided:
“You just march into that setting-room and stay there till I come. You been up to something you no business to, and I lay I’ll find out what it is before I’m done with you.”
So she went away as I opened the door and walked into the setting-room. My, but there was a crowd there! Fifteen farmers, and every one of them had a gun. I was most powerful sick, and slunk to a chair and set down. They was setting around, some of them talking a little, in a low voice, and all of them fidgety and uneasy, but trying to look like they warn’t; but I knowed they was, because they was always taking off their hats, and putting them on, and scratching their heads, and changing their seats, and fumbling with their buttons. I warn’t easy myself, but I didn’t take my hat off, all the same.

events.title: The Melting Butter Misunderstanding
detailed_summary: Huck anxiously wished for Aunt Sally to conclude her interrogation, even if it meant receiving a punishment, so he could quickly warn Tom about the dire escalation of their plans and the dangerous situation they had inadvertently created.
He recognized the urgent need to abandon their elaborate schemes and escape with Jim before the armed men lost their patience and acted.
When Aunt Sally finally arrived to question him, Huck was too disoriented and frightened to provide coherent answers.
The atmosphere in the room was thick with tension, as the assembled farmers grew increasingly agitated; some were eager to storm the cabin immediately, noting the late hour approaching midnight.
Others in the group urged caution and patience, preferring to wait for the pre-arranged sheep signal before taking action.
Amidst Aunt Sally's relentless questioning, Huck became progressively more terrified and overwhelmed by the circumstances.
The room grew increasingly hot, causing the butter concealed beneath Huck's hat to begin melting and trickling down his neck and behind his ears.
Just as one of the farmers declared his intention to enter the cabin immediately to capture the supposed desperadoes upon their arrival, Huck felt he was about to collapse.
At that critical moment, a noticeable streak of melted butter ran down Huck's forehead.
Aunt Sally witnessed this, turned deathly pale, and exclaimed in alarm that the child must be suffering from "brain-fever" and that his brains were literally "oozing out."
A commotion ensued as everyone rushed to see what was happening; Aunt Sally then snatched Huck's hat from his head, revealing the bread and the remnants of the butter.
Instantly relieved that Huck was not suffering from a serious illness, Aunt Sally embraced him tightly.

She expressed her profound gratitude that the situation was no worse, remarking on their recent string of misfortunes and how she had feared the worst upon seeing the substance on his head, thinking it resembled brains.
She gently chided Huck, saying she wouldn't have minded his trip to the cellar had she known it was merely for food.
Finally, she dismissed him, instructing him to go to bed immediately and not to let her see him again until the morning.

At last she come and begun to ask me questions, but I couldn’t answer them straight, I didn’t know which end of me was up; because these men was in such a fidget now that some was wanting to start right now and lay for them desperadoes, and saying it warn’t but a few minutes to midnight; and others was trying to get them to hold on and wait for the sheep-signal; and here was Aunty pegging away at the questions, and me a-shaking all over and ready to sink down in my tracks I was that scared; and the place getting hotter and hotter, and the butter beginning to melt and run down my neck and behind my ears; and pretty soon, when one of them says, “I’m for going and getting in the cabin first and right now, and catching them when they come,” I most dropped; and a streak of butter come a-trickling down my forehead, and Aunt Sally she see it, and turns white as a sheet, and says:
“For the land’s sake, what is the matter with the child? He’s got the brain-fever as shore as you’re born, and they’re oozing out!”
And everybody runs to see, and she snatches off my hat, and out comes the bread and what was left of the butter, and she grabbed me, and hugged me, and says:
“Oh, what a turn you did give me! and how glad and grateful I am it ain’t no worse; for luck’s against us, and it never rains but it pours, and when I see that truck I thought we’d lost you, for I knowed by the color and all it was just like your brains would be if—Dear, dear, whyd’nt you tell me that was what you’d been down there for, I wouldn’t a cared. Now cler out to bed, and don’t lemme see no more of you till morning!”

events.title: A Narrow Escape from the Cabin
detailed_summary: Huck moved with incredible speed, rushing upstairs, then quickly descending the lightning rod, and finally hurrying through the darkness towards the lean-to where Tom and Jim were waiting.

He was so overcome with anxiety that he found it difficult to speak, but he managed to quickly inform Tom that the house was filled with armed men and that they needed to make their escape without a moment's delay.
Upon hearing this news, Tom's eyes blazed with excitement rather than fear.
He expressed a thrill at the increased level of danger, even suggesting that if they had the chance to redo their plan, he could probably attract twice as many men.
Huck, focused on the immediate peril, urged Tom to hurry and asked for Jim's location.
Tom indicated that Jim was right beside them, fully dressed and prepared for their departure.
Just as they were about to give the pre-arranged sheep signal to indicate their readiness, they heard the distinct sound of men approaching the cabin door.
They then overheard the men fumbling with the padlock on the cabin and one man commenting that they had arrived too soon, as the "desperadoes" had not yet come and the door was still locked.

The same man instructed some members of his group to be locked inside the cabin, where they could lie in wait in the darkness and ambush their targets when they arrived; the rest of the group was told to scatter around the vicinity and listen for any sounds of approach.
The men subsequently entered the cabin but, due to the darkness, could not see Huck, Tom, and Jim, who were scrambling to hide; the men nearly trod on them in the process.

The trio successfully concealed themselves under the bed and then managed to escape through the hole in the wall, moving swiftly but silently. Jim went first, followed by Huck, and then Tom, in accordance with Tom's prior instructions.
Once they were all safely inside the lean-to, they could hear the sounds of men moving around very close by, just outside the structure.

I was up stairs in a second, and down the lightning-rod in another one, and shinning through the dark for the lean-to. I couldn’t hardly get my words out, I was so anxious; but I told Tom as quick as I could we must jump for it now, and not a minute to lose—the house full of men, yonder, with guns!
His eyes just blazed; and he says:
“No!—is that so? Ain’t it bully! Why, Huck, if it was to do over again, I bet I could fetch two hundred! If we could put it off till—”
“Hurry! hurry!” I says. “Where’s Jim?”
“Right at your elbow; if you reach out your arm you can touch him. He’s dressed, and everything’s ready. Now we’ll slide out and give the sheep-signal.”
But then we heard the tramp of men coming to the door, and heard them begin to fumble with the pad-lock, and heard a man say:
“I told you we’d be too soon; they haven’t come—the door is locked. Here, I’ll lock some of you into the cabin, and you lay for ’em in the dark and kill ’em when they come; and the rest scatter around a piece, and listen if you can hear ’em coming.”
So in they come, but couldn’t see us in the dark, and most trod on us whilst we was hustling to get under the bed. But we got under all right, and out through the hole, swift but soft—Jim first, me next, and Tom last, which was according to Tom’s orders. Now we was in the lean-to, and heard trampings close by outside.

events.title: The Chase and Freedom on the Raft
detailed_summary: Inside the lean-to, Tom positioned himself at the door and peered through a crack, but the darkness outside was too profound for him to discern anything.
He whispered to Huck and Jim that he would listen intently for the men's footsteps to recede and would give them a nudge when it was safe for Jim to slip out first, with Tom himself exiting last.
After a tense period of listening, during which they could hear the continuous sound of footsteps scraping around outside, Tom finally gave the signal.
They emerged from the lean-to, moving with extreme caution, holding their breath, and making not the slightest noise as they proceeded in single file towards the fence.
Huck and Jim successfully made it over the fence.
However, Tom's trousers became snagged on a splinter protruding from the top rail of the fence.
Hearing the sound of approaching footsteps, Tom was forced to pull himself free quickly, which caused the splinter to snap with a distinct noise.
As Tom landed on the other side of the fence and began to run, someone from the pursuing party shouted, demanding they identify themselves or face being shot.
The trio did not respond but instead increased their pace, running as fast as they possibly could.
A rush of pursuers followed, accompanied by the sharp reports of gunfire, and bullets whizzed alarmingly close to them.
They heard their pursuers shouting that the fugitives had broken for the river and calling for the dogs to be turned loose to aid in the chase.
The pursuing men, encumbered by boots and making a great deal of noise by shouting, inadvertently gave Huck, Tom, and Jim an advantage, as the three fugitives were barefoot and moved silently.
They found themselves on the path leading to the mill and, when the pursuers drew near, they deftly dodged into the bushes, allowed the men to pass by, and then quietly fell in behind them.
The dogs, which had initially been kept confined so as not to scare off the supposed robbers, were now released and rushed towards the sounds of the commotion, barking loudly.

However, these were their own dogs; upon recognizing Huck, Tom, and Jim, and realizing there was no real excitement or threat to engage them, the dogs merely offered a brief, familiar greeting before tearing off towards the ongoing sounds of shouting and clattering from the pursuing men.
The trio then quickly made their way upstream again, hurrying along after their dogs until they were nearly at the mill.

From there, they struck up through the bush to the location where Huck's canoe was tied, quickly hopped in, and paddled with all their might towards the middle of the river, taking care to make no more noise than was absolutely necessary.
Once in the current, they proceeded more easily and comfortably towards the island where Huck's raft was hidden.
They could hear the sounds of the men yelling and the dogs barking on the riverbank, but these noises gradually grew dimmer and eventually died out as they moved further away.
Upon stepping onto the raft, Huck triumphantly declared to Jim that he was a free man once again and expressed his belief that Jim would never be a slave anymore.

Jim enthusiastically agreed, praising the escape plan as beautifully conceived and executed, and marveling at its intricate and splendid nature, claiming no one could devise a more wonderfully complicated scheme.

So we crept to the door, and Tom stopped us there and put his eye to the crack, but couldn’t make out nothing, it was so dark; and whispered and said he would listen for the steps to get further, and when he nudged us Jim must glide out first, and him last. So he set his ear to the crack and listened, and listened, and listened, and the steps a-scraping around out there all the time; and at last he nudged us, and we slid out, and stooped down, not breathing, and not making the least noise, and slipped stealthy towards the fence in Injun file, and got to it all right, and me and Jim over it; but Tom’s britches catched fast on a splinter on the top rail, and then he hear the steps coming, so he had to pull loose, which snapped the splinter and made a noise; and as he dropped in our tracks and started somebody sings out:
“Who’s that? Answer, or I’ll shoot!”
But we didn’t answer; we just unfurled our heels and shoved. Then there was a rush, and a bang, bang, bang! and the bullets fairly whizzed around us! We heard them sing out:
“Here they are! They’ve broke for the river! After ’em, boys, and turn loose the dogs!”
So here they come, full tilt. We could hear them because they wore boots and yelled, but we didn’t wear no boots and didn’t yell. We was in the path to the mill; and when they got pretty close on to us we dodged into the bush and let them go by, and then dropped in behind them. They’d had all the dogs shut up, so they wouldn’t scare off the robbers; but by this time somebody had let them loose, and here they come, making powwow enough for a million; but they was our dogs; so we stopped in our tracks till they catched up; and when they see it warn’t nobody but us, and no excitement to offer them, they only just said howdy, and tore right ahead towards the shouting and clattering; and then we up-steam again, and whizzed along after them till we was nearly to the mill, and then struck up through the bush to where my canoe was tied, and hopped in and pulled for dear life towards the middle of the river, but didn’t make no more noise than we was obleeged to. Then we struck out, easy and comfortable, for the island where my raft was; and we could hear them yelling and barking at each other all up and down the bank, till we was so far away the sounds got dim and died out. And when we stepped onto the raft I says:
“Now, old Jim, you’re a free man again, and I bet you won’t ever be a slave no more.”
“En a mighty good job it wuz, too, Huck. It ’uz planned beautiful, en it ’uz done beautiful; en dey ain’t nobody kin git up a plan dat’s mo’ mixed-up en splendid den what dat one wuz.”

events.title: Tom's Wound and Jim's Noble Stand
detailed_summary: While everyone was relieved by their successful escape, Tom was paradoxically the most elated because he had sustained a bullet wound in the calf of his leg during the chase.
When Huck and Jim learned about Tom's injury, their initial feelings of triumph were tempered with concern.
Tom was clearly in considerable pain and his leg was bleeding, so they helped him into the wigwam on the raft to tend to his wound.
They tore strips from one of the duke's old shirts to use as makeshift bandages.
Tom, however, still caught up in the romantic thrill of the "evasion," insisted on bandaging his own leg and urged them to set the raft loose immediately and continue their flight.

He boasted about the "elegant" manner in which they had accomplished their escape and even launched into a fantastical monologue about how they would have handled historical figures like Louis XVI, implying they would have managed his escape far more effectively.
While Tom was exulting in his injury and their adventure, Huck and Jim quietly conferred with each other.
After a moment of thoughtful silence, Huck prompted Jim to articulate what was on his mind.

Jim then delivered a profound moral statement, arguing that if their roles were reversed—if Tom were the one being set free and one of his companions (Huck or Jim) had been shot—Tom would never abandon his injured friend to save himself without first securing medical attention.
Jim rhetorically questioned if such selfish behavior was characteristic of Tom Sawyer, confidently asserting that Tom would indeed prioritize the well-being of his friends.
Therefore, Jim firmly declared that he would not budge from their current location without a doctor for Tom, even if it meant waiting for forty years.
Huck deeply recognized and admired the inherent goodness, loyalty, and selflessness in Jim's principled stand, internally acknowledging that Jim was "white inside."
Huck had anticipated that Jim would react in this noble way, and with Jim's resolute decision, Huck felt a sense of rightness and immediately informed Tom that he was going to fetch a doctor.

events.title: Tom's Theatrical Plan for Fetching the Doctor
detailed_summary: Tom protested vigorously against the idea of fetching a doctor, but Huck and Jim remained steadfast in their decision, refusing to yield.
In his frustration, Tom even threatened to crawl out of the wigwam and set the raft adrift himself, but Huck and Jim prevented him from doing so.
Tom then delivered a tirade, expressing his displeasure, but his angry words had no impact on their resolve.
Seeing that Huck was already preparing the canoe for the journey, Tom reluctantly accepted their decision to seek medical help.
He then proceeded to give Huck a series of elaborate and highly theatrical instructions on how to fetch the doctor, drawing heavily on conventions from adventure stories and dime novels.

These detailed instructions included specific actions such as going to the doctor's house, shutting the door behind him, blindfolding the doctor tightly and securely, and making him swear a solemn oath to remain as silent as the grave about the entire affair.
Huck was also instructed to place a purse full of gold in the doctor's hand.
Following this, Huck was to lead the blindfolded doctor on a convoluted route through back alleys and various dark, out-of-the-way places.
He was then to transport the doctor to the raft by canoe, taking a deliberately roundabout path amongst the islands to further obscure their location.

Upon arrival at the raft, Huck was to search the doctor thoroughly and confiscate any chalk he might be carrying, not returning it until they had safely delivered the doctor back to the village. This precaution was to prevent the doctor from marking the raft's location for later discovery.
Tom concluded his instructions by explaining that this elaborate procedure was "the way they all do" in such clandestine operations described in his beloved books.
Huck agreed to follow Tom's complicated plan and then departed in the canoe.
It was arranged that Jim would conceal himself in the woods near the raft when he saw the doctor approaching and remain hidden until after the doctor had treated Tom and left again.

events.title: Huck's Deception and the Doctor's Departure for Tom
detailed_summary: Huck awakens an elderly doctor, presenting himself as the brother of a boy named 'Sid' (actually Tom Sawyer).
He concocts a story about 'Sid' accidentally shooting himself in the leg on Spanish Island during a supposed hunting trip, emphasizing the need for secrecy to surprise their 'folks,' the Phelpses.
The doctor, though expressing some skepticism about the 'dream' that supposedly caused the gunshot, agrees to help and prepares his lantern and saddle-bags.
When the doctor sees Huck's small canoe, he expresses concern about its safety for two people.
Huck attempts to reassure him by claiming it previously carried three people and guns, a slip he quickly tries to cover.
The doctor tests the canoe, remains unconvinced, and decides to look for a larger one, but finds others locked.
He ultimately takes Huck's canoe alone, instructing Huck to either wait, search for another canoe, or go home to prepare for the 'surprise.'
Huck chooses to wait and provides the doctor with directions to the raft where Tom is located.

The doctor was an old man; a very nice, kind-looking old man when I got him up. I told him me and my brother was over on Spanish Island hunting yesterday afternoon, and camped on a piece of a raft we found, and about midnight he must a kicked his gun in his dreams, for it went off and shot him in the leg, and we wanted him to go over there and fix it and not say nothing about it, nor let anybody know, because we wanted to come home this evening and surprise the folks.
“Who is your folks?” he says.
“The Phelpses, down yonder.”
“Oh,” he says. And after a minute, he says:
“How’d you say he got shot?”
“He had a dream,” I says, “and it shot him.”
“Singular dream,” he says.
So he lit up his lantern, and got his saddle-bags, and we started. But when he sees the canoe he didn’t like the look of her—said she was big enough for one, but didn’t look pretty safe for two. I says:
“Oh, you needn’t be afeard, sir, she carried the three of us easy enough.”
“What three?”
“Why, me and Sid, and—and—and the guns; that’s what I mean.”
“Oh,” he says.
But he put his foot on the gunnel and rocked her, and shook his head, and said he reckoned he’d look around for a bigger one. But they was all locked and chained; so he took my canoe, and said for me to wait till he come back, or I could hunt around further, or maybe I better go down home and get them ready for the surprise if I wanted to. But I said I didn’t; so I told him just how to find the raft, and then he started.

events.title: Huck's Anxious Planning and Belated Awakening
detailed_summary: Immediately after the doctor departs, Huck begins to worry about the potential consequences if Tom's leg injury requires extended care.
He fears the doctor might reveal their situation prematurely, thus 'letting the cat out of the bag.'
To prevent this, Huck devises a contingency plan: if the doctor indicates a need for further visits, Huck will swim to the raft.
His plan involves forcibly detaining the doctor, keeping him on the raft downriver until Tom no longer needs medical attention, and then compensating him before releasing him.
Having formulated this drastic plan, Huck seeks rest in a lumber-pile.
He oversleeps significantly, waking to find the sun high in the sky, indicating much time has passed.
Rushing to the doctor's house, Huck learns that the doctor had left sometime during the night and has not yet returned.

events.title: Neighbors' Speculation on Jim's Escape and Aunt Sally's Mounting Hysteria
detailed_summary: The Phelps' house is crowded with local farmers and their wives, all animatedly discussing Jim's escape and the bizarre items found in his cabin.
Old Mrs. Hotchkiss dominates the conversation, vehemently arguing that Jim must have been insane, citing the strange carvings on the grindstone as primary evidence.
Other women, like Mrs. Damrell and Sister Utterback, express bewilderment over the purpose of a rag ladder.
Brer Penrod and others question how the heavy grindstone was moved into the cabin and who dug the hole.
The discussion leads to a consensus that Jim must have had considerable assistance, with speculation on the number of helpers ranging from a dozen to forty.
They marvel at the tedious creation of case-knife saws, the effort to saw off a bed-leg, and the presence of a straw effigy of Jim.
Brother Marples highlights a shirt covered in what he calls 'secret African writ'n' done in blood, expressing a desire to have it deciphered.

Aunt Sally interjects, detailing a long list of stolen household items, from a shirt and sheet to flour, candles, spoons, and even her new calico dress, emphasizing that these thefts occurred despite her family's constant vigilance.
She concludes that spirits must have been involved in Jim's escape, as their highly skilled dogs never even found a trail, challenging anyone to explain it.
The neighbors react with various expressions of shock and fear at the audacity and mystery of the events.
Aunt Sally recounts her extreme fear the previous night, admitting she was so agitated she even locked her 'two poor boys' (Huck as 'Tom', and Tom Sawyer as 'Sid') in their room.
As she finishes speaking and her gaze falls upon Huck, he, realizing the implication of her statement for his earlier fabricated alibi, quietly excuses himself and leaves the room.

events.text_segment:
And the place was plum full of farmers and farmers’ wives, to dinner; and such another clack a body never heard. Old Mrs. Hotchkiss was the worst; her tongue was a-going all the time. She says:
“Well, Sister Phelps, I’ve ransacked that-air cabin over, an’ I b’lieve the nigger was crazy. I says to Sister Damrell—didn’t I, Sister Damrell?—s’I, he’s crazy, s’I—them’s the very words I said. You all hearn me: he’s crazy, s’I; everything shows it, s’I. Look at that-air grindstone, s’I; want to tell me’t any cretur ’t’s in his right mind ’s a goin’ to scrabble all them crazy things onto a grindstone, s’I? Here sich ’n’ sich a person busted his heart; ’n’ here so ’n’ so pegged along for thirty-seven year, ’n’ all that—natcherl son o’ Louis somebody, ’n’ sich everlast’n rubbage. He’s plumb crazy, s’I; it’s what I says in the fust place, it’s what I says in the middle, ’n’ it’s what I says last ’n’ all the time—the nigger’s crazy—crazy ’s Nebokoodneezer, s’I.”
“An’ look at that-air ladder made out’n rags, Sister Hotchkiss,” says old Mrs. Damrell; “what in the name o’ goodness could he ever want of—”
“The very words I was a-sayin’ no longer ago th’n this minute to Sister Utterback, ’n’ she’ll tell you so herself. Sh-she, look at that-air rag ladder, sh-she; ’n’ s’I, yes, look at it, s’I—what could he a-wanted of it, s’I. Sh-she, Sister Hotchkiss, sh-she—”
“But how in the nation’d they ever git that grindstone in there, anyway? ’n’ who dug that-air hole? ’n’ who—”
“My very words, Brer Penrod! I was a-sayin’—pass that-air sasser o’ m’lasses, won’t ye?—I was a-sayin’ to Sister Dunlap, jist this minute, how did they git that grindstone in there, s’I. Without help, mind you—’thout help! Thar’s wher ’tis. Don’t tell me, s’I; there wuz help, s’I; ’n’ ther’ wuz a plenty help, too, s’I; ther’s ben a dozen a-helpin’ that nigger, ’n’ I lay I’d skin every last nigger on this place but I’d find out who done it, s’I; ’n’ moreover, s’I—”
“A dozen says you!—forty couldn’t a done every thing that’s been done. Look at them case-knife saws and things, how tedious they’ve been made; look at that bed-leg sawed off with ’m, a week’s work for six men; look at that nigger made out’n straw on the bed; and look at—”
“You may well say it, Brer Hightower! It’s jist as I was a-sayin’ to Brer Phelps, his own self. S’e, what do you think of it, Sister Hotchkiss, s’e? Think o’ what, Brer Phelps, s’I? Think o’ that bed-leg sawed off that a way, s’e? think of it, s’I? I lay it never sawed itself off, s’I—somebody sawed it, s’I; that’s my opinion, take it or leave it, it mayn’t be no ’count, s’I, but sich as ’t is, it’s my opinion, s’I, ’n’ if any body k’n start a better one, s’I, let him do it, s’I, that’s all. I says to Sister Dunlap, s’I—”
“Why, dog my cats, they must a ben a house-full o’ niggers in there every night for four weeks to a done all that work, Sister Phelps. Look at that shirt—every last inch of it kivered over with secret African writ’n done with blood! Must a ben a raft uv ’m at it right along, all the time, amost. Why, I’d give two dollars to have it read to me; ’n’ as for the niggers that wrote it, I ’low I’d take ’n’ lash ’m t’ll—”
“People to help him, Brother Marples! Well, I reckon you’d think so if you’d a been in this house for a while back. Why, they’ve stole everything they could lay their hands on—and we a-watching all the time, mind you. They stole that shirt right off o’ the line! and as for that sheet they made the rag ladder out of, ther’ ain’t no telling how many times they didn’t steal that; and flour, and candles, and candlesticks, and spoons, and the old warming-pan, and most a thousand things that I disremember now, and my new calico dress; and me and Silas and my Sid and Tom on the constant watch day and night, as I was a-telling you, and not a one of us could catch hide nor hair nor sight nor sound of them; and here at the last minute, lo and behold you, they slides right in under our noses and fools us, and not only fools us but the Injun Territory robbers too, and actuly gets away with that nigger safe and sound, and that with sixteen men and twenty-two dogs right on their very heels at that very time! I tell you, it just bangs anything I ever heard of. Why, sperits couldn’t a done better and been no smarter. And I reckon they must a been sperits—because, you know our dogs, and ther’ ain’t no better; well, them dogs never even got on the track of ’m once! You explain that to me if you can!—any of you!”
“Well, it does beat—”
“Laws alive, I never—”
“So help me, I wouldn’t a be—”
“House-thieves as well as—”
“Goodnessgracioussakes, I’d a ben afeard to live in sich a—”
“’Fraid to live!—why, I was that scared I dasn’t hardly go to bed, or get up, or lay down, or set down, Sister Ridgeway. The place was plum full of farmers and farmers’ wives, to dinner; and such another clack a body never heard. The long table groaned under the weight of roast pork, cornbread, and sweet potatoes, while the air was thick with the smell of gravy and the sound of laughter. Every soul in that room seemed bent on talking at once, and none of them minded much whether anyone listened.  

Old Mrs. Hopkins held forth at the head of the table, her voice rising above the rest like a preacher on Sunday. "I tell you, them clouds yonder mean business," she declared, pointing a bony finger toward the window. "Mark my words, we’ll have rain before nightfall, and a hard one at that."  

Her husband, a grizzled man with a beard like a bramble patch, shook his head and muttered into his plate. "Woman’s been predictin’ rain since the day we married. If she was right half the time, we’d all be drowned by now."  

This set the whole table to laughing, except for young Sally Miller, who sat wide-eyed, clutching her fork like it might run off if she let go. Her ma nudged her and whispered, "Eat up, child, before the menfolk take it all," but Sally was too busy staring at the stranger who’d wandered in just before grace.  

He was a lean, sunburnt fellow with a hat pulled low over his eyes, and he hadn’t said two words since he sat down. The farmers paid him no mind—strangers came and went in these parts—but Sally couldn’t shake the feeling that there was something peculiar about him. Maybe it was the way his fingers drummed restless on the table, or how his eyes flicked toward the door every few seconds, like he was expecting trouble.  

Across the table, Jim Turner slapped his knee and launched into a story about the time he’d outwitted a peddler who tried to sell him a mule with three legs. "Swore up and down it was just restin’ one," Jim crowed, "but I says to him, ‘Mister, that mule ain’t restin’, it’s *missin’*!’"  

The room erupted again, but the stranger didn’t so much as crack a smile. Instead, he leaned forward, his voice cutting through the noise like a knife. "Anybody here know the way to Phelps’ place?"  

The chatter died down quick at that. The Phelps family lived a good ten miles west, near the river, and folks didn’t ask after them without reason.  

Old Man Hopkins wiped his mouth with his sleeve and squinted at the stranger. "What’s your business with the Phelpses?"  

The stranger’s jaw tightened, but his voice stayed steady. "Got a message to deliver. Private matter."  

A few of the farmers exchanged glances. Private matters in these parts usually meant one of two things: money or mischief.  

Before anyone could press further, the door burst open, and in stomped Sheriff Barnes, his boots muddy and his face red as a beet. "There’s been a robbery up at the mill," he announced, and the room went dead silent. "Feller took off with the payroll, and we got reason to believe he’s headed this way."  

Sally’s heart leapt into her throat. Her eyes darted to the stranger, who had gone still as a statue.  

The sheriff’s gaze swept the room, lingering on each face before stopping at the stranger’s. "You new around here?"  

The stranger nodded once. "Passing through."  

"Funny time to be passing through," the sheriff said, stepping closer. "Mind telling me where you’re headed?"  

The stranger’s hand inched toward his coat, and Sally’s breath caught. But just then, a clap of thunder shook the house so hard the plates rattled, and old Mrs. Hopkins let out a triumphant cackle. "What’d I tell you? Rain’s here!"  

In the commotion that followed—men jumping up to shut windows, women gathering up the tablecloth to keep it dry—the stranger vanished like smoke.  

The sheriff cursed and made for the door, but the rain was coming down in sheets now, turning the road to mud. He turned back to the room, his expression grim. "Reckon he’s long gone. But mark my words, we’ll find him."  

Sally stared at the empty chair where the stranger had sat, her supper forgotten. She didn’t know why, but she had a powerful feeling that the sheriff was wrong. That man wasn’t just running *from* something—he was running *to* something. And whatever it was, it was bound to be trouble.  

Outside, the storm raged on, and the farmers went back to their clacking, though the laughter didn’t come as easy now. The stranger’s question hung in the air, unanswered:  

*Anybody here know the way to Phelps’ place?*

events.title: Huck's Elaborate Alibi and Aunt Sally's Renewed Anxiety for 'Sid'
detailed_summary: Having slipped away, Huck formulates an explanation for why he and 'Sid' were not in their locked room that morning.
He later returns and tells Aunt Sally that the noise and shooting from Jim's escape woke them.
He claims that, finding their door locked but wanting to see the excitement, they climbed down the lightning rod, both sustaining minor injuries in the process, and resolved never to try it again.
Huck then recounts the fabricated story he had earlier told Uncle Silas about their supposed pursuit of the runaway slave.
Aunt Sally, mollified, forgives them, attributing their actions to the typical harum-scarum nature of boys.
She expresses relief that no real harm came of it and decides to be grateful they are alive and well rather than dwelling on the past.
After a moment of thought, Aunt Sally suddenly realizes with concern that it is almost night and 'Sid' (Tom Sawyer) has still not returned, questioning his whereabouts.

And then I went on and told her all what I told Uncle Silas before; and then she said she’d forgive us, and maybe it was all right enough anyway, and about what a body might expect of boys, for all boys was a pretty harum-scarum lot as fur as she could see; and so, as long as no harm hadn’t come of it, she judged she better put in her time being grateful we was alive and well and she had us still, stead of fretting over what was past and done. So then she kissed me, and patted me on the head, and dropped into a kind of a brown study; and pretty soon jumps up, and says:
“Why, lawsamercy, it’s most night, and Sid not come yet! What has become of that boy?”

So I slipped out the back door and made my way down to the riverbank, where I could think without interruption. The morning mist was still clinging to the water, and the air smelled of damp earth and old leaves. I sat on a log, turning the problem over in my mind like a smooth stone in my hand.  

If anyone asked why we weren’t in that room come morning, I’d have to spin a tale good enough to satisfy. Maybe I’d say we heard a noise—something stirring outside—and went to investigate. Or perhaps we’d been taken by surprise, overpowered before we could raise the alarm. But that wouldn’t explain why we hadn’t called for help.  

No, the best story was the simplest one: we’d been tricked. Someone—maybe that no-account king or the duke—had lured us out, and we’d been too green to see it coming. That way, folks would pity us instead of suspecting us.  

I chewed on a blade of grass, watching the river slide by. The truth was, I didn’t much care what they believed, so long as it kept them from looking too close. Sometimes, the best lies were the ones that let folks think they’d figured it out themselves.

events.title: Growing Concern for 'Sid,' Aunt Sally's Distress, and Huck's Guilt
detailed_summary: Huck quickly offers to go to town and find 'Sid,' seeing an opportunity.
Aunt Sally firmly refuses, stating that one boy lost at a time is enough and that if 'Sid' isn't back by supper, Uncle Silas will go.
When 'Sid' (Tom Sawyer) fails to appear for supper, Uncle Silas departs to search for him.
Uncle Silas returns around ten o'clock, somewhat uneasy, as he couldn't find any trace of 'Tom's track' (referring to Tom Sawyer, currently known as 'Sid').
Aunt Sally becomes considerably more anxious, though Uncle Silas tries to reassure her by saying boys will be boys and 'Sid' will likely turn up in the morning.
Though somewhat pacified, Aunt Sally resolves to stay up for a while and keep a light burning for 'Sid.'
Later, when Huck goes to bed, Aunt Sally accompanies him, tucks him in, and shows him such motherly affection that Huck feels guilty and finds it hard to look at her.

events.title: Aunt Sally's Plea, Huck's Internal Conflict, and a Night of Vigil
detailed_summary: As Aunt Sally is about to leave Huck's room, she looks at him gently and earnestly.
She tells 'Tom' (Huck) that the door will not be locked and mentions the window and lightning rod, then pleads with him to be good and not leave, for her sake.
Huck, who desperately wants to go check on the real Tom Sawyer and had fully intended to, feels he cannot leave after her heartfelt request, not even for 'kingdoms.'
His mind is troubled by thoughts of both Aunt Sally and Tom, leading to a restless night's sleep.
Twice during the night, he secretly climbs down the lightning rod and observes Aunt Sally still sitting by her candle in the window, her eyes fixed on the road, tears visible.
Huck wishes he could comfort her but feels helpless, only able to resolve never to cause her further grief.
Waking a third time at dawn, he slides down again to find her still there, asleep in her chair, her head resting on her hand, the candle almost extinguished.

events.title: Anxious Wait and Tom's Dramatic Return
detailed_summary: Uncle Silas and Aunt Sally are consumed with worry at the breakfast table, having not heard from Tom.
Uncle Silas remembers he received a letter from the post office the previous day.
Aunt Sally takes the letter and identifies it as being from her sister in St. Petersburg.

Before Aunt Sally can open the letter, a commotion interrupts them: Tom Sawyer arrives on a mattress, carried by several people, accompanied by the old doctor, and Jim, who is in Aunt Sally's calico dress with his hands tied.
Huck, witnessing the scene, quickly conceals the unopened letter.
Aunt Sally initially cries out in fear that Tom is dead.
Upon seeing Tom move his head and mutter, she is overcome with relief that he is alive, though clearly not lucid.
She kisses Tom and then hurries off to prepare a bed, shouting instructions to everyone around her.

The old man was uptown again before breakfast, but couldn’t get no track of Tom; and both of them set at the table thinking, and not saying nothing, and looking mournful, and their coffee getting cold, and not eating anything. And by-and-by the old man says:
“Did I give you the letter?”
“What letter?”
“The one I got yesterday out of the post-office.”
“No, you didn’t give me no letter.”
“Well, I must a forgot it.”
So he rummaged his pockets, and then went off somewheres where he had laid it down, and fetched it, and give it to her. She says:
“Why, it’s from St. Petersburg—it’s from Sis.”
I allowed another walk would do me good; but I couldn’t stir. But before she could break it open she dropped it and run—for she see something. And so did I. It was Tom Sawyer on a mattress; and that old doctor; and Jim, in her calico dress, with his hands tied behind him; and a lot of people. I hid the letter behind the first thing that come handy, and rushed. She flung herself at Tom, crying, and says:
“Oh, he’s dead, he’s dead, I know he’s dead!”
And Tom he turned his head a little, and muttered something or other, which showed he warn’t in his right mind; then she flung up her hands, and says:
“He’s alive, thank God! And that’s enough!” and she snatched a kiss of him, and flew for the house to get the bed ready, and scattering orders right and left at the niggers and everybody else, as fast as her tongue could go, every jump of the way.

events.title: Jim's Harsh Re-imprisonment and the Doctor's Defense
detailed_summary: Jim endures verbal abuse and some physical blows from the men but remains silent and does not acknowledge Huck.
He is confined to the same cabin as before, now dressed in his own clothes, and is more securely chained to a log, with his hands and both legs also bound.
The men declare that Jim will only receive bread and water until his owner claims him or he is sold at auction.
The escape hole Huck and Tom made is filled in, and a stricter guard routine is established, involving armed farmers at night and a bulldog during the day.
As the men are concluding their efforts, the old doctor arrives and addresses them.
The doctor urges the men not to be unnecessarily harsh with Jim, stating he is not a bad person.
He recounts how, upon finding Tom wounded, he realized he couldn't remove the bullet alone and Tom was too unwell to be left.
Jim, despite being a runaway, voluntarily came forward and provided excellent assistance in caring for Tom.

The doctor explains he was compelled to stay with Tom and Jim throughout the day and night, as he couldn't risk Jim escaping, and Jim proved to be a remarkably faithful and diligent nurse, even though it meant risking his own freedom and despite being clearly exhausted from recent hard work.
He emphasizes Jim's good character and considerable value, noting how Jim was eventually captured while asleep after his tiring vigil.
The doctor concludes by reiterating his positive assessment of Jim.

“Don’t be no rougher on him than you’re obleeged to, because he ain’t a bad nigger. When I got to where I found the boy I see I couldn’t cut the bullet out without some help, and he warn’t in no condition for me to leave to go and get help; and he got a little worse and a little worse, and after a long time he went out of his head, and wouldn’t let me come a-nigh him any more, and said if I chalked his raft he’d kill me, and no end of wild foolishness like that, and I see I couldn’t do anything at all with him; so I says, I got to have help somehow; and the minute I says it out crawls this nigger from somewheres and says he’ll help, and he done it, too, and done it very well. Of course I judged he must be a runaway nigger, and there I was! and there I had to stick right straight along all the rest of the day and all night. It was a fix, I tell you! I had a couple of patients with the chills, and of course I’d of liked to run up to town and see them, but I dasn’t, because the nigger might get away, and then I’d be to blame; and yet never a skiff come close enough for me to hail. So there I had to stick plumb until daylight this morning; and I never see a nigger that was a better nuss or faithfuller, and yet he was risking his freedom to do it, and was all tired out, too, and I see plain enough he’d been worked main hard lately. I liked the nigger for that; I tell you, gentlemen, a nigger like that is worth a thousand dollars—and kind treatment, too. I had everything I needed, and the boy was doing as well there as he would a done at home—better, maybe, because it was so quiet; but there I was, with both of ’m on my hands, and there I had to stick till about dawn this morning; then some men in a skiff come by, and as good luck would have it the nigger was setting by the pallet with his head propped on his knees sound asleep; so I motioned them in quiet, and they slipped up on him and grabbed him and tied him before he knowed what he was about, and we never had no trouble. And the boy being in a kind of a flighty sleep, too, we muffled the oars and hitched the raft on, and towed her over very nice and quiet, and the nigger never made the least row nor said a word from the start. He ain’t no bad nigger, gentlemen; that’s what I think about him.”

“Don’t be too rough on him, boys. He ain’t a bad n****r. When I found him, he was doing his best to tend to that runaway boy, Tom Sawyer, even though he was hurt himself. He could’ve run off, but he stayed right there, trying to help. That’s worth something.”

The men grumbled a bit but didn’t argue much with the doctor. They knew he was a decent man, and he’d patched up enough of their scrapes over the years that they respected him. Still, they weren’t about to let Jim go free. 

“He’s property, Doc,” one of them said. “Ain’t no way around that. His owner’ll want him back, or he’ll fetch a good price at auction. We can’t just let him loose on account of him being helpful once.”

The doctor sighed and shook his head. “I ain’t saying turn him loose. I’m just saying he don’t deserve to be treated worse than a dog. Give him a blanket, at least. It’s cold in that cabin at night.”

One of the farmers muttered something under his breath but went off to fetch an old horse blanket. They tossed it in the corner of the cabin, not bothering to hand it to Jim proper. 

Jim didn’t say a word. He just sat there, chained up, staring at the floor like he was trying to disappear into it. I reckon he was scared, but he wasn’t showing it. He had more grit than most men I ever seen.

The doctor gave me a long look before he left. “You best get on home, son,” he said. “Your aunt Polly’s been worried sick about you.” 

I nodded, but I didn’t move. I couldn’t just leave Jim like this. Not after all we’d been through. 

Once the men cleared out, leaving just the two farmers on watch outside, I crept a little closer to the cabin window. Jim’s head lifted when he saw me, but he didn’t make a sound. I pressed my finger to my lips, then pointed toward the woods. He gave me the smallest nod, understanding plain as day. 

I slipped back into the trees, my mind racing. I had to figure out a way to get Jim free—chains, dogs, armed men and all. It wasn’t going to be easy, but I reckoned Tom Sawyer himself couldn’t have dreamed up a trickier fix than this. And if there was one thing I knew, it was that I wasn’t about to let Jim down. Not now. Not ever.

events.title: Tom's Awakening and Grand Confession
detailed_summary: Huck notes that he has ample time to prepare his explanations, as Aunt Sally is constantly by Tom's side in the sick-room, and Huck manages to avoid encountering Uncle Silas.
The following morning, Huck learns Tom is significantly better and Aunt Sally has gone to take a nap.
He slips into the sick-room, hoping that if Tom is awake, they can devise a believable story for the family.
He finds Tom sleeping peacefully, his appearance much improved.
Aunt Sally quietly enters the room, motions for Huck to be still, and whispers her joy that Tom's symptoms are excellent and he appears to be recovering well.
They sit and watch Tom, who eventually stirs and opens his eyes, recognizing he is at home.
Tom immediately asks about the raft and then about Jim.
Huck confirms Jim is also there, though his tone is somewhat subdued, which Tom doesn't notice.
Tom, assuming their plan was a complete success, exclaims that they are all safe and asks Huck if he has told Aunt Sally about it.
When Aunt Sally inquires what Tom means, he proudly announces that he and "Sid" (Huck) were responsible for freeing Jim.
Aunt Sally is shocked and exclaims that Tom must be out of his head again.

Tom insists he is perfectly lucid and proceeds to give a lengthy, enthusiastic account of their entire elaborate scheme: the weeks of work, stealing supplies like candles and clothes, making tools and inscriptions, digging into the cabin, dealing with rats and snakes, and the final chaotic escape attempt where he was shot, culminating in his belief that Jim was now a free man thanks to their efforts.

But I had plenty time. Aunt Sally she stuck to the sick-room all day and all night, and every time I see Uncle Silas mooning around I dodged him.
Next morning I heard Tom was a good deal better, and they said Aunt Sally was gone to get a nap. So I slips to the sick-room, and if I found him awake I reckoned we could put up a yarn for the family that would wash. But he was sleeping, and sleeping very peaceful, too; and pale, not fire-faced the way he was when he come. So I set down and laid for him to wake. In about half an hour Aunt Sally comes gliding in, and there I was, up a stump again! She motioned me to be still, and set down by me, and begun to whisper, and said we could all be joyful now, because all the symptoms was first-rate, and he’d been sleeping like that for ever so long, and looking better and peacefuller all the time, and ten to one he’d wake up in his right mind.
So we set there watching, and by-and-by he stirs a bit, and opened his eyes very natural, and takes a look, and says:
“Hello!—why, I’m at home! How’s that? Where’s the raft?”
“It’s all right,” I says.
“And Jim?”
“The same,” I says, but couldn’t say it pretty brash. But he never noticed, but says:
“Good! Splendid! Now we’re all right and safe! Did you tell Aunty?”
I was going to say yes; but she chipped in and says: “About what, Sid?”
“Why, about the way the whole thing was done.”
“What whole thing?”
“Why, the whole thing. There ain’t but one; how we set the runaway nigger free—me and Tom.”
“Good land! Set the run— What is the child talking about! Dear, dear, out of his head again!”

But I had plenty time. Aunt Sally she stuck to the sick-room all day and all night, and every time I see Uncle Silas mooning around I dodged him. He was always wandering about, looking troubled, like a man with too much on his mind and not enough sense to sort it out. I reckon he was fretting over Tom’s condition, though the boy was mending slow but sure. Still, Uncle Silas had a way of turning every little thing into a grand worry, and I didn’t want to get caught up in his fretting.  

I had my own business to tend to, and it wouldn’t do to have him asking questions. There was still the matter of Jim being locked up in that shed, and though Tom was getting better, he wasn’t in any shape to be scheming just yet. That left it all to me, and I had to figure out how to get Jim free without raising suspicion.  

Now, Aunt Sally being so busy with Tom was a blessing in disguise. She didn’t have time to keep an eye on me, and Uncle Silas was too distracted to pay much mind to what I was up to. I took advantage of that, slipping around the place like a shadow, studying the lay of the land and figuring out my next move.  

One evening, when the sun was just dipping below the trees, I saw my chance. Uncle Silas had gone off to pray with some of the neighbors—he was mighty fond of praying when things got worrisome—and Aunt Sally was dozing in her chair by Tom’s bedside. I crept out to the shed where Jim was kept, careful not to make a sound.  

Jim saw me through the crack in the door and his face lit up. “Huck!” he whispered. “I was powerful worried ‘bout you. How’s young Mars Tom?”  

“He’s coming along,” I said. “But we ain’t got much time. I gotta get you outta here ‘fore they decide to sell you down the river.”  

Jim nodded, his eyes serious. “I’s ready, Huck. Just tell me what to do.”  

I’d been thinking on it hard, and I reckoned the best way was to wait till full dark, then sneak Jim out the back way, past the cornfield and down to the creek. From there, we could follow the water till we found a place to lay low till morning.  

But just as I was fixing to tell Jim the plan, I heard footsteps crunching on the gravel outside. My heart near about jumped out of my chest. I ducked down behind a barrel, holding my breath.  

It was Uncle Silas. He stood there a minute, sighing like the weight of the world was on his shoulders, then he walked right past the shed without even glancing at it. I let out a long breath when his footsteps faded away.  

Jim looked at me, his face tight with worry. “That was too close, Huck.”  

“Sure was,” I agreed. “We gotta move tonight, no mistake.”  

I told him the plan quick, and he nodded along. Then I slipped back to the house, keeping low and quiet. The moon was rising now, casting long shadows across the yard. It was going to be a clear night—good for traveling, bad for hiding.  

Back inside, I checked on Tom. He was sleeping peaceful, and Aunt Sally was still dozing in her chair. I reckoned she’d sleep till morning, worn out from nursing. That gave me the time I needed.  

I gathered up what little gear I had—some bread and meat I’d saved from supper, a knife, and an old blanket. Then I waited, listening to the sounds of the house settling for the night.  

When the clock struck midnight, I knew it was time. I crept out the back door, my heart pounding like a drum. The night was still, the only sound the rustling of leaves in the breeze.  

Jim was waiting. It was time to light out for the territory.

events.title: Aunt Sally's Outrage and Tom's Shocking News about Jim
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally, finally grasping the full extent of their escapade, expresses her utter astonishment and calls them "little rapscallions" for causing widespread panic and distress.
She vows to punish them severely once Tom has recovered his health.
Tom, however, is too proud and joyful to be subdued and continues to revel in their perceived success, even as Aunt Sally interjects with fiery exasperation.
Aunt Sally warns Tom that he should not meddle with "the runaway nigger" again.
Tom, looking surprised, asks whom she is referring to.
When Aunt Sally clarifies she means Jim, Tom turns to Huck with a grave expression, questioning why Huck hadn't told him Jim was alright and had gotten away.
Aunt Sally then informs Tom that Jim has indeed been recaptured, is currently confined to the cabin again, on a diet of bread and water, and heavily chained.

Upon hearing this, Tom sits bolt upright in bed, his eyes flashing and nostrils flaring, and passionately exclaims to Huck that they have no right to imprison Jim, because Jim is not a slave but as free as anyone.

“Well, I never heard the likes of it in all my born days! So it was you, you little rapscallions, that’s been making all this trouble, and turned everybody’s wits clean inside out and scared us all most to death. I’ve as good a notion as ever I had in my life to take it out o’ you this very minute. To think, here I’ve been, night after night, a—you just get well once, you young scamp, and I lay I’ll tan the Old Harry out o’ both o’ ye!”
But Tom, he was so proud and joyful, he just couldn’t hold in, and his tongue just went it—she a-chipping in, and spitting fire all along, and both of them going it at once, like a cat convention; and she says:
“Well, you get all the enjoyment you can out of it now, for mind I tell you if I catch you meddling with him again—”
“Meddling with who?” Tom says, dropping his smile and looking surprised.
“With who? Why, the runaway nigger, of course. Who’d you reckon?”
Tom looks at me very grave, and says:
“Tom, didn’t you just tell me he was all right? Hasn’t he got away?”
“Him?” says Aunt Sally; “the runaway nigger? ’Deed he hasn’t. They’ve got him back, safe and sound, and he’s in that cabin again, on bread and water, and loaded down with chains, till he’s claimed or sold!”
Tom rose square up in bed, with his eye hot, and his nostrils opening and shutting like gills, and sings out to me:
“They hain’t no right to shut him up! Shove!—and don’t you lose a minute. Turn him loose! he ain’t no slave; he’s as free as any cretur that walks this earth!”

events.title: Jim's Legal Freedom Revealed and Aunt Polly's Surprise Arrival
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally, bewildered, asks what Tom means by his declaration of Jim's freedom.
Tom emphatically states that he means every word: Miss Watson passed away two months ago, and feeling remorseful for ever planning to sell Jim down the river, she had set him free in her will.

When Aunt Sally, still trying to process this, asks why on earth Tom would then go to all the trouble of orchestrating an escape for a man who was already free, Tom begins to explain that he wanted the adventure of it.
Before he can continue, Tom suddenly exclaims, "goodness alive, AUNT POLLY!"
Huck confirms that Aunt Polly is indeed standing right inside the doorway, looking unexpectedly pleasant and satisfied.

events.title: Identities Unraveled and Complex Motivations Clarified
detailed_summary: Aunt Sally reacts with overwhelming joy, rushing to embrace Aunt Polly and crying.
Huck, sensing the escalating tension and potential for awkward revelations, decides to hide under the bed.
After a moment, Aunt Polly disengages from the hug and looks sternly across at Tom.
When Aunt Sally refers to the boy in bed as "Sid," Aunt Polly immediately corrects her, stating that it is Tom, and then asks for Huck Finn.
Huck reluctantly emerges from his hiding place.

Aunt Sally is depicted as utterly baffled, a state shared by Uncle Silas when he is later informed of all the events, leaving him so disoriented that he preaches an unintelligible sermon that evening.
Tom's Aunt Polly proceeds to explain Huck's true identity and his circumstances.
Huck then explains that when Aunt Sally mistook him for Tom Sawyer, he felt compelled to maintain the charade, knowing Tom would relish the mystery and adventure of the situation.
He adds that Tom subsequently pretended to be Sid to make things easier for Huck.
Aunt Polly confirms Tom's earlier statement that old Miss Watson had indeed freed Jim in her will.

This revelation brings a moment of clarity for Huck, who finally understands how Tom, given his upbringing, could have participated in freeing a slave: Tom knew Jim was already legally free, thus turning the entire elaborate escape into a risk-free adventure for himself.

Aunt Sally jumped for her, and most hugged the head off of her, and cried over her, and I found a good enough place for me under the bed, for it was getting pretty sultry for us, seemed to me. And then she says:
“Yes, you better turn y’r head away—I would if I was you, Tom.”
“Oh, deary me!” says Aunt Sally; “is he changed so? Why, that ain’t Tom, it’s Sid; Tom’s—Tom’s—why, where is Tom? He was here a minute ago.”
“You mean where’s Huck Finn—that’s what you mean! I reckon I hain’t raised such a scamp as my Tom all these years not to know him when I see him. That would be a pretty howdy-do. Come out from under that bed, Huck Finn.”

events.text_segment:
Well, Aunt Polly she said that when Aunt Sally wrote to her that Tom and Sid had come all right and safe, she says to herself:
“Look at that, now! I might have expected it, letting him go off that way without anybody to watch him. So now I got to go and trapse all the way down the river, eleven hundred mile, and find out what that creetur’s up to this time; as long as I couldn’t seem to get any answer out of you about it.”
“Why, I never heard nothing from you,” says Aunt Sally.
“Well, I wonder! Why, I wrote you twice to ask you what you could mean by Sid being here.”
“Well, I never got ’em, Sis.”
Aunt Polly she turns around slow and severe, and says:
“You, Tom!”
“Well—what?” he says, kind of pettish.
“Don’t you what me, you impudent thing—hand out them letters.”
“What letters?”
“Them letters. I be bound, if I have to take aholt of you I’ll—”
“They’re in the trunk. There, now. And they’re just the same as they was when I got them out of the office. I hain’t looked into them, I hain’t touched them. But I knowed they’d make trouble, and I thought if you warn’t in no hurry, I’d—”
“Well, you do need skinning, there ain’t no mistake about it. And I wrote another one to tell you I was coming; and I s’pose he—”
“No, it come yesterday; I hain’t read it yet, but it’s all right, I’ve got that one.”
I wanted to offer to bet two dollars she hadn’t, but I reckoned maybe it was just as safe to not to. So I never said nothing.
